PETITION.TITLE: Sporting, Cultural and Community Groups: Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The Hawke Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill concerning Credit Reference Reporting will:

(1) prohibit many legitimate uses of credit information by organisations such as real estate agents, mortgage underwriters, insurance companies, businesses selling goods on credit, and companies renting or leasing goods and equipment;
(2) add to the cost of business and increase interest rates, and insurance charges and lead to over commitment by borrowers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
Reject Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill to enable businesses to have access to credit information they require to make sensible commercial decisions.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate assembled:
We, the undersigned, oppose changes to general medical practice contained in Community and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, on the following grounds.

1. We oppose legislation which creates two classes of general practitioners and two classes of patients. Medicare is for all Australians. All Australians should receive the same Medicare rebates when consulting the doctor of their choice in any general practice or specialised area of general practice.

2. We oppose this legislation as it ignores the needs of women as patients and as doctors. It devalues women's health, and it will discourage women from, not only becoming general practitioners, but entering medicine.

3. We oppose this legislation as it jeopardizes the confidentiality of the patient-doctor consultation. Doctors on this Vocational Register must release patients' confidential clinical records for examination by the Independent Peer Review Organization and also, information may be further released to other `relevant' authorities.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
The Senate will reject the proposed changes to general medical practice contained in the Community and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
That in 1987/88 alone Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $6.4 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by Western Australia Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament Party, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War II and the Korean War, the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that:
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government, and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of Warrant Officer Kevin Conway, Australian Army Training Team Vietnam, be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Federal Police Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully shows that the Bill for an Act to amend the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 and the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981, due to be presented on the 26th of September 1989, is to the detriment of Australian public servants currently employed by the Australian Federal Police. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate now has before it the National Health Amendment Bill 1989, the purpose of which is to increase the maximum general patient contribution for prescribed drugs supplied under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) from the present $11 to a new level of $12. I should say at the outset that the Opposition does not oppose this piece of legislation but I make--
—That is the only reference you are going to make to it too, isn't it?

—No. But I make it clear that in the committee stage of this Bill we will move to insert an additional clause to bring about the overturning of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal (PBRT) decision of 28 August 1989, which was the subject of a Bill introduced into the Senate by me and passed a couple of weeks ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's proposal to increase the maximum patient contribution from $11 to $12 is estimated by the Government to achieve savings of $10m in 1989-90 and $17m in the full financial year. The Bill also provides for the indexation of the patient contribution so that there will be an automatic increase in the maximum general patient contribution calculated according to a formula which is set forth in the legislation now before us. This will be another example of the way in which this Government continues to increase imposts and charges on the Australian people by a system of automatic indexation rather than coming back to the Parliament from time to time in order to front the Parliament with its views about increases in charges. Honourable senators will recall that taxes on petroleum products and retail taxes on items such as tobacco and alcohol are now increased by automatic indexation so that prices increase automatically at set periods during the year in accordance with a formula, which very few people actually understand. Australian taxpayers and consumers are required to pay more without the Government having to come to the Parliament on a regular basis to justify its seeking to increase these taxes and its revenue in this fashion.

Nevertheless, the Opposition does not propose to seek to strike out the automatic indexation provisions within this legislation. As I said, we do not oppose the Bill. We are committed to the preservation of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme as an effective and efficient means of delivery to the community of the most modern and up to date medications at subsidised and affordable prices. It is true, nevertheless, that some aspects of the system ought to be more thoroughly investigated. For example, it is quite clear that a large number of people in receipt of subsidised pharmaceuticals could well afford to pay more realistic prices. Some of the people who hold health care cards which allow them the maximum rebate under the scheme are nevertheless in a position to pay more out of their own resources rather than be subsidised to the extent that they are by the taxpayers of Australia.

To come back to the central issue in this legislation, I pose the question: What will consumers get for the extra dollar that they have to pay for their PBS prescriptions? Will they receive the same level of service from pharmacists that they currently enjoy? Will they continue to have convenient access to the services of a pharmacist? I say that, if the Government continues down the path that it is currently pursuing in relation to pharmacies, the answer to both of those questions will undoubtedly be no.

In its April 1989 economic statement the Government set PBS savings at $31m in 1989-90, $96m in 1990-91, and $156m in 1991-92. Obviously, some of these savings will result from the matter which is before the Senate this morning, that is, the increase in the maximum general patient contribution. I remind the Senate, however, that the Government's own estimate is that it is looking here at a saving of only $10m in the current financial year and $17m in a full year. That falls far short of the $31m this year, the $96m in the next financial year and the $156m in the financial year after that which the April 1989 statement said was going to be saved. The principal way in which the Government aims to make these cuts, and which will be the subject of the debate in the committee stage, is by the attack which it is making on the remuneration of individual pharmacists. That debate in the committee stage will allow us to explore some of those issues in greater detail.

I think it appropriate at this point to put on the record some of the proposals which the Liberal and National parties have advocated in terms of the way in which we would operate the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, which is the subject of change in this legislation. I say quite clearly that we would seek to maintain the PBS, endorsing its underlying principles of subsidising the provision of the safest, most effective and modern therapeutic goods and services and directing the greatest assistance to those in greatest need. We would act in a way which is totally consistent with the view that pharmacists are both highly skilled and the most accessible health care professionals in the community. They are uniquely qualified and well placed to deliver a most comprehensive service, elements of which include the dispensing of prescribed medications, counselling patients on medication regimes, public education on drug use and abuse and assistance in preventive medicine programs.

As I said on the last occasion when this matter was before the Senate, the primary health care advice which is given by pharmacists to people who come into their retail outlets is of enormous benefit to the whole community. It saves government considerable amounts as people seek advice from their pharmacists instead of going to medical practitioners and paying for that advice. They feel quite safe, quite secure, in going to their local pharmacy to seek that advice. Very often they go into a pharmacist's shop seeking advice, not necessarily making any purchases but using the pharmacist as a health care adviser, if not provider, in those circumstances.

We would be seeking to achieve improvements in the PBS by measures such as amendment of the National Health Act, which governs the operation of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, to create a body which has better understanding of the role of community pharmacy-again, that was the subject of an earlier debate in this place-developing a formula for the calculation of remuneration based on allowances for mark-up, dispensing costs and professional services and for the regular adjustment of remuneration in line with changes in the consumer price index; the removal of price controls on items costing less than the maximum patient contribution, and acceptance on the part of the Government that pharmacists' manual and computerised claims must be processed and paid without delay; an active consultative arrangement between government and pharmacies involved in the supply and delivery of pharmaceutical goods and the services to deal with matters outside the scope of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal or its replacement; and, finally, a review of the activities of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority to ensure that they make effective and efficient contributions to the national health care system.

Part of the problem which we are now facing in terms of pharmacy in Australia results from the Government's bandaid policies in terms of the way in which the pharmaceutical benefits scheme now operates. During this current debate the Government has made changes on a number of occasions. Following the determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal of 28 August and the outcry which that produced, the Tribunal itself has realised that it needs to undertake reviews in a number of areas. It has agreed that it needs to undertake a review of the cost of dispensing high-priced drugs as a result of its decision. It has clearly indicated that the criteria required for the special essential pharmacy allowance that the Tribunal recommended should be paid to pharmacies which may not be economically viable but which are needed to supply the PBS drugs benefit to the community need to be reviewed and that there ought to be a review of the $15 an hour used by the Tribunal in calculating notional pharmacy salaries-a ridiculous decision for it to have come to.

Honourable senators know full well that the Pharmacy Guild of Australia is proceeding in the Federal Court of Australia for a review and an overturning of the PBRT decision. It is expected that that case will be heard on 12 October. I remind honourable senators of the previous determination of the Federal Court by His Honour Mr Justice Northrop in relation to the last occasion an attempt was made by the Government to cut the remuneration to pharmacists. His Honour held in that case that the decision arrived at by the Tribunal should be struck down because it was a decision which no reasonable person acting on the facts available to him could have made. He believed that the decision of the Tribunal was manifestly unfair and should not have been made.

On a previous occasion I drew attention to the comment made in the 28 August determination of the Tribunal, which took a sideswipe at His Honour Mr Justice Northrop. It quoted what His Honour had had to say in relation to the Tribunal's duty. His Honour said:
The Tribunal is not concerned to determine the remuneration of approved pharmacists.
The Tribunal, at paragraph 6.2 of its report, said:
This comment by his Honour is not to be taken too literally.

One can see that the attitude of the Tribunal, even when rebuked by the judiciary, is one of telling the judiciary exactly what it thinks of it, treating the judiciary with the same degree of contempt with which it treats the pharmacists-and, indeed, the same degree of contempt with which the Minister treats the pharmacists; I shall return to that in just a moment.

It takes a great deal, as honourable senators would know, for pharmacists to motivate themselves to do such things as go out and doorknock individual electorates, but honourable senators would be aware that in Melbourne pharmacists have doorknocked in the electorates of Aston and Jagajaga to indicate the extent to which they have community support for the maintenance of their position against the attempts of the Government to disadvantage them substantially.

The Government has already changed its mind on one aspect, and that is the special allowance to be paid to pharmacies in remote locations. It was announced on 25 September, or thereabouts, that the Government was moving to placate the country pharmacists in the dispute over cuts to dispensing fees. It announced that chemists with small businesses more than 10 kilometres from approved pharmacies will receive a special allowance worth about $12,000 a year. It is understood that about 400 of Australia's 5,600 pharmacies will benefit, most of them in country areas. The allowance will be available to pharmacists who are at least 10 kilometres from the nearest approved pharmacy, dispense fewer than 15,000 claimable prescriptions a year and are open at least 20 hours per week. That was a recognition that the Government had got that element of the determination on pharmacy remuneration wrong and needed to correct it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can change that bit.

—As my colleague Senator Knowles says, as soon as the Government is put under a little pressure it can change that bit. Indeed, we will see in a moment that it is prepared to change other bits. The Senate will recall that the determination of the Tribunal proposed that the 25 per cent wholesale mark-up under the scheme should be abolished, thereby making it uneconomical for a number of high cost pharmaceutical products to be stocked and carried by pharmacies. The Government realised it had made another error and is now proposing that, instead of being reimbursed by the Government for the surcharge currently levied on drugs by wholesalers, as recommended by the Tribunal at an additional hearing on this issue last week, a new fee will come through a 3 per cent increase on wholesalers' margins, going up, therefore, to 13 per cent. This will cost the Government an additional $3m to $5m each year. This new 13 per cent margin will replace the existing surcharge levied by wholesalers and will apply only to drugs costing more than $45.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government thinks that will solve the problem of pharmacies having to carry high cost drugs at their own expense, it is in for a rude shock. As Mr Robert Davies, the Chief Executive of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, has made clear, there is still no incentive for pharmacists to carry these drugs, and people are still likely to have to wait for pharmacists to buy in these higher priced items in order to secure their proper remuneration, and not be required to carry the cost of subsidising the Government's scheme out of their own pockets.

The key to the whole dispute between the Government and the pharmacists lies in the attitude which this Government, in particular the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), has taken towards this highly skilled and dedicated group of professionals in the community. The approach which Mr Staples, the Minister responsible for the scheme, has taken towards the pharmacy profession and individual pharmacists has been absolutely disgraceful. They have been threatened, bullied and intimidated. For example, an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 25 September states:
Mr Staples warned that the $12,000 handout-
which was proposed as part of a rationalisation scheme for pharmacies-

would be withdrawn if the Federal Court overturned the Tribunal's decision. He said chemists faced the added risk that an adverse court decision would make pharmacists even worse off by returning remuneration to 1981 levels.

I draw attention to this whole question of the court's arm's length principles and the role of the Tribunal and the Government in this matter. Senators will recall that when the pharmacists rejected the Minister's offer in May, and said that the matter ought to be determined differently, the Minister told them, `If you reject my offer you will end up being worse off under the recommendations of the Tribunal'. At the same time he has pretended that the Tribunal is entirely independent of and at arm's length from the Government. Yet he was in a position to say `You either take this offer now or else you will be worse off as a result of the Tribunal's determination'. That clearly indicates that the Tribunal is not properly independent of the Government. The myth which the Minister has tried to peddle that dealing with the Tribunal is dealing at arm's length is simply not correct.

We now have a situation where the Minister says `If you go to the Federal Court and you seek from the court a proper protection of our position you will be worse off'. In other words, he is threatening people that they should not seek to use those legal remedies which they have available to them. If they do seek to secure protection under the rule of law, they will be financially worse off if this Minister has anything to do with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is blackmail.

—Not only is that blackmail, as Senator Knowles says, but I was absolutely staggered to see a statement made by a public servant, Dr Jeff Harmer, who is apparently Assistant Secretary of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Division within Mr Staples's Department, a statement which the Sydney Morning Herald reports in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Harmer said chemists could be big losers from a win in the Federal Court, in line with a recent precedent where pathologists won in court but ended up worse off. He said the chemists were `risking absolute disaster' by appealing.

When public servants get into the business of acting as agents for Ministers in the process of threatening people who seek to access their proper legal rights through the court system, Ministers have responsibilities to deal with those public servants. I doubt whether this Minister will do so, but he ought to, because that is a disgraceful sort of threat for a public servant to make against citizens seeking protection of their rights under the judicial system of this country.

The Government has sought to split and divide the pharmacy profession. Earlier this month the Government moved to establish a new body which it expected to provide it with advice. Mr Staples said that he would be approaching people whom he described as more moderate members of the Guild and other influential pharmacy groups which he believed would cooperate with him in undermining the position of the Guild and allow him to negotiate with them in a way which would suit the Government's agenda. He said:
There are a lot of people, particularly older people, who think the hotheads are going to cause them a problem.

By `hotheads' Mr Staples was referring to the elected officials and the senior members of the Guild. He said that they were concerned that `hardliners' were going to destroy the viability of the profession and, therefore, he was going to isolate what he regarded as the big, tough pharmacists and find a group of `moderate' pharmacists, so-called, to cooperate with him in splitting the profession. The Australian on Wednesday, 13 September, under the heading `Split in pharmacy guild may end row' commenced its article with these words:
The Federal Government claimed yesterday it had forced a split in the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and was now confident of a quick resolution to the industrial dispute over cuts to dispensing fees.

That is the typical approach of the Hawke Labor Government-divide, separate and set people at each other's throats. The Government tries to split people; it tries to set one group of professionals against another to achieve its overall aims. But the Federal Government's attempt to split the Pharmacy Guild of Australia backfired badly. One member of the Government's new advisory panel of so-called moderate pharmacists, which was announced on 12 September, indicated that he might pull out in disgust along with other members. The Chairman of the Community and Pharmacy Support Group, Mr Jim Jackson, predicted the collapse of the advisory panel because it had been formed by the Minister in haste and even without the consent of some of the people named to be on it. Mr Rod Hammond, a member of the new advisory panel which included presidents of the State branches of the Guild, said that he had not formally agreed to join the panel and would be reconsidering his position. He said:
I will not be party to anything which divides the profession.
On 15 September 1989 in the Sydney Morning Herald it was reported:

The president of the Queensland branch of the guild, Mr Richard James, wrote to the minister responsible for the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, Mr Staples, yesterday saying he had looked forward to making a `positive contribution' to resolving the dispute.
The article went on, however, to indicate that Mr James had decided to resign from the advisory committee and he is quoted as saying:
However, I was subsequently concerned and dismayed at statements attributed to you-
that is, Mr Staples--
by the media-statements that my membership of the panel represented `a split in the Pharmacy Guild of Australia'.

People quit this so-called advisory panel because they saw that the Minister was making an attempt to split their profession, to divide their Guild and to set people against each other. That has not worked and it will not work. At a meeting of pharmacists held on 7 September in Parramatta where some 5,000 employees in the pharmacy profession met a resolution was passed which had several parts to it, the first of which was:
That this meeting endorses the actions that are today taking place in all states of the Commonwealth-
I interpolate that that was the two-hour shutdown of pharmacies-
. . . to show the Hawke Government and in particular his minister Staples that we are unified and refute his statement that we are a group of HOTHEADS.

Of course they are not; they are dedicated, skilled, professional people who object to being abused by the Minister, to being threatened by his public servants and to having their remuneration cut by his so-called arm's length tribunal in a fashion which is detrimental to their economic welfare at a time when they are under considerable pressures, when threats are being made by the Minister to transfer more and more pharmacy business into supermarket arrangements and when they know that the basis upon which the Tribunal came to its determination was fundamentally flawed.

I am not alone in this view, as my colleague Senator Knowles will undoubtedly be saying much the same later in the debate. Mr Graeme Campbell, a member of the House of Representatives for the electorate of Kalgoorlie, a member of the Australian Labor Party, wrote a letter to Mr Jim Snow, the Chairman of the Caucus back bench pharmacists liaison committee. We should remember that this was the great committee Mr Snow and Mr Lee were to get together. They were going to fix up the Government on behalf of the pharmacists. By gee, they had that all lined up; they had promises; they had Senator Aulich telling everybody in Tasmania that he would look after their interests in northern Tasmania by fixing up the Minister too. Mr Lee from the electorate of Dobell and Mr Snow from the electorate of Eden-Monaro were going to set out the facts and they were going to straighten out Mr Staples. What did it all come to? Absolutely nothing.

Mr Campbell, however, wrote to Mr Snow indicating that he believes that Mr Peter Staples is treating backbenchers `like idiots'. Those words were contained in Mr Campbell's letter relating to the pharmaceutical benefits issue. The letter goes on to say that it was Mr Campbell's view that `the confrontationist and emotional atmosphere being generated by some of the absurdities coming from the Minister's office'-those are his words-were central to the way in which this debate was being unveiled in the community. Mr Staples therefore stands condemned by one of his own backbenchers for the divisive role that he has played in this particular area.

I conclude by drawing attention to the point with which I started, namely, the service provided by pharmacies to the Australian community. I refer to an article by Hammarstrom and Westerholm, two Swedish policy specialists, which appeared in a publication called the World Health Forum last year. That is a publication of the World Health Organisation in Geneva. Under the heading `Pharmacists to the fore' the article makes the point that in Sweden, as in Australia, pharmacists are becoming increasingly a part of the front line battle against community ill health. If we fail to understand that, then we will be short-changing the public and, indeed, the Australian taxpayer. Ultimately, we will be prejudicing those policies which are needed to improve community health. The article indicates that pharmacists come into contact with far more patients than do other primary care centres and ought, as a result, to be regarded as one of the cornerstones of primary health care in this country. We cannot afford to have a government which continues to make pharmacists and the pharmacy profession the scapegoats for its own financial problems in terms of the cost of the PBS and the confusion which exists in the national and public health schemes around this country at the moment.

As I said, we will not oppose the National Health Amendment Bill 1989 because we accept the arguments that the Government has put forward about the increase in the maximum contribution rate from $11 to $12. We draw attention to the fact that the Bill also indexes these contributions so that in fact the cost to individual consumers will creep up, unbeknown, surreptitiously, quarter by quarter or half year by half year, without the Parliament being asked to approve those increases. That is a policy decision which the Government has made. We will not seek to interfere with that. We will, however, in the committee stage come back to the question of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal determination of 28 August. We will seek to overturn that once again and require the House of Representatives to deal specifically with that matter, unlike the legislation which the Senate has already passed and which the House of Representatives can simply decline to debate. For those reasons, we will support the Bill and move the committee stage amendment in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the face of it, the National Health Amendment Bill 1989 is a very simple Bill. As has already been explained, it seeks merely to increase in line with the cost of living the maximum patient contribution for pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) drugs from $11 to $12 and then, moving on from that, to put in place a system of continuing indexation so that that maximum patient contribution can be kept in line with the cost of living over the succeeding months and years. However, as simple as it may seem on the surface, the introduction of this legislation in the Senate does open up the question of the adequacy of the way in which the Government has been dealing with pharmaceutical benefits, not only in regard to this Bill and the recent debates on the Opposition's private member's Bill in relation to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal determination, but also in regard to other debates late last year in relation to the movement of drugs from the general list to the authority only list. This resulted in a number of those drugs being subsequently moved back to the general list as it was realised that the basis for the decisions in relation to some of those drugs was inappropriate. At that stage I called for a review of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme in toto. I gave notice of a motion in the Senate calling for that review. When I sought to move that as a formal motion the process was objected to, so it remains on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise again the very important need totally to review the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, not just in the context of the cost of this drug against that drug, but in relation to the alternative modalities of treatment which are available. Is it appropriate to look at the costs of expensive drugs vis-a-vis cheaper drugs in isolation from what other things might happen to the patient being treated with those drugs? For instance, it may well be that the use of more expensive drugs on some occasions causes a patient to spend less time in hospital. There is some controversy regarding the Federal Government's allowance to the States in relation to patient bed days in hospital, but the average figure would be about $150 per day. Clearly, we make a very substantial saving if we use a drug which causes a patient to spend one day less in hospital, but that saving does not accrue to that area of accounting which covers the PBS; it accrues in other areas such as hospital costs, part of which may well be borne by private health insurance. Nonetheless, it is a real cost that has to be borne in the community somewhere. It is that total social costing in relation to the PBS which needs to be reviewed.

As we have frequently debated in this place, there may be alternative modes of preventative action which may be a great deal more effective than allowing people to become ill and then having to treat them with drugs. For instance, we still allow, without restriction, the promotion of a whole raft of unhealthy foods on the market which contain large amounts of sugar, fat or salt. The companies that manufacture and promote the sale of these things claim their advertising as a tax deduction. So until recently 49 per cent of the cost of that advertising was borne by the public through avoided tax. Now, a substantial portion of that cost is borne by the community through avoided tax even with the lower rate of tax. At the same time, we run relatively minuscule programs, in terms of cost, to convince the public that it is desirable that they avoid those foods. Would it not be more desirable to do something about the amounts which are spent to promote more healthy diets in the community and to avoid later the more expensive drugs which are necessary to treat patients with coronary heart disease, patients who need coronary bypass operations, and patients suffering from hypertension and a whole range of other diseases? As I understand it, no study along those lines has been done, but that is precisely the sort of investigation that is needed if we are to come up with a pharmaceutical benefits scheme which is integrated and dovetails into a total health care program which is strongly oriented towards health care and not illness treatment. By the very nature of things, the majority of drugs are oriented towards sickness treatment rather than health care and health protection.

When we look at the distribution of costs of drugs on the PBS-I took these figures out this morning-we find that a very large proportion of drugs which are now listed on the PBS fall below the $12 cost. This Bill seeks to introduce a maximum patient contribution of $12, the presumption being that the Government considers that $12 is a reasonable amount for a patient to pay. When I look at these figures I find that of the drugs on the general list, 74 per cent cost less than $12, 26 per cent of those on the authority only list cost less than $12 and, in total, nearly 60 per cent of all the drugs on the schedule cost less than $12. In other words, it may well be appropriate, if the Government considers that $12 is a reasonable amount for a patient to pay as a maximum contribution, to simply remove some 60 per cent of the drugs on the PBS-namely, those that fall below that $12 mark-and allow patients to pay the full cost of those drugs. The total costs may well be less than having a doctor write out a PBS prescription with all the associated costs of remuneration of the pharmacist and so on.

Interestingly, when one moves up the cost scale, 14 per cent of the drugs on the general list cost between $12 and $20; 15 per cent of the authority only drugs and 14 per cent of total drugs cost between $12 and $20. In the expensive class-drugs costing over $100-only 2 per cent on the general list cost more than $100; 16 per cent on the authority only list and 7 per cent of the total number of drugs on the PBS. I recognise that these figures do not represent the cost to the Government, because clearly fewer or more of the cheaper drugs, or fewer or more of the more expensive drugs, may be prescribed. Therefore, we need to look at the cost of a single prescription, multiplied by the number of times prescriptions for those particular drugs are written, in order to determine the total cost of those drugs to the PBS, the Government and the community. However, it would seem that a substantial reduction in both government and overall costs could be achieved if a large number of cheaper drugs were simply removed from the list.

The purpose of the Bill, as has been pointed out in the second reading speech and by Senator Puplick, is simple and straightforward, but it does open up the way in which the Government has dealt with the pharmacists in the recent past through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal determination. Honourable senators will recall that several weeks ago the Australian Democrats introduced a private member's Bill into the Senate to disallow the result of that determination. That private member's Bill was superseded by a similar Bill from the Opposition. The Opposition's Bill was debated and passed through this chamber. As Senator Puplick has pointed out, that Bill now resides in the other chamber and has little chance of being debated there.

I admire the Opposition for introducing a similar amendment to this Bill, because it will force the Government to consider the matter properly in the parliamentary context. Therefore, the Australian Democrats will support the Opposition's amendment in relation to the disallowance of the Tribunal's determination when we reach the committee stage. We certainly express the hope that when the Bill goes to the House of Representatives in an amended form, the House of Representatives will see fit to set in place the appropriate and comprehensive review of the PBS and pharmacists' remuneration which should have been carried out.

The Government has stated that the purpose of the recent determination was to remove 23 per cent of the PBS costs as they relate to pharmacists' remuneration. Interestingly, according to the explanatory memorandum, the Bill will have the effect of increasing the patient contribution-or conversely of decreasing the Government's cost-by $10m in 1989-90; $35m in 1990-91; $55m in 1991-92; and $78m in 1992-93. Clearly, the Government is very keen to reduce its contribution to the health care costs expressed through the pharmaceutical part of health care in Australia, but that is not to say that the total costs to the community are not rising. Again, it is disturbing-and I stress this-that we appear not to be doing total social costing. What is health care costing the community as a whole? Whatever channel that cost proceeds through, whether it be through private sources or by way of taxation to the Government and then remuneration, in the final analysis does not make a great deal of difference. We should be looking at the total cost to the community and attempting to arrive at a health care system which is based on health care and which seeks to reduce the total costs, not simply shifting the burden from the Government to private sources.

The Government has also said that it is seeking to reduce the number of pharmacies. I repeat that that is a complete red herring. It has nothing to do with the cost of drugs to the community. I again draw to the Senate's attention Senator Giles's contribution in the debate of 7 September on the Opposition's private members' Bill in which she talked about essential pharmacies. She said:

. . . pharmacies in outer urban areas, pharmacies where there are people with very little mobility, pharmacies in rural areas where there are no others within some distance-will have the capacity to attract an essential fee. There will also be an extra fee for essential pharmacies of $5.40 payable on and from 1 October 1989 to be adjusted in the same manner as is prescribed for other prescriptions.

The point I made during that debate, and I repeat it, is that the identification of an extra fee for essential pharmacies in my mind clearly implies that those pharmacies would simply not be able to continue without that extra fee. It follows that, through the mechanism which the Government now has in train, it will be possible for the Government essentially to determine which pharmacies will continue in business and which will not. That is a power which I believe the Government should not take to itself. Again, I stress that it really has nothing to do with the overall cost of the PBS, which is what this Bill is about. One could use the extreme example: it would not matter if there were only one pharmacy in Australia. If all the pharmaceuticals were dispensed through that one pharmacy the cost to the Government would be identical, so the number of pharmacies does not make a great deal of difference.

I return to the point at which I began. I believe that the whole of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is in a mess. It is a system which has been in place for many decades. The list has been added to and subtracted from and the philosophy which has guided the addition or removal of drugs from that list has changed over time. There has not been an assessment of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme in relation to alternative modalities of treatment and their cost and effectiveness. It is extremely important to undertake such an assessment at this stage.

I believe that the Government has recognised that the matter is in a mess. Senator Puplick quoted both Mr Staples and Mr Robert Davies, the Chief Executive of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. I believe that he was probably quoting from the editorial in today's Australian Financial Review which I have in front of me. In relation to the slight alteration which the Government has now acceded to concerning the $3m to $5m extra each year in relation to the surcharge Mr Davies said:
. . . it would remove the ridiculous situation where pharmacists were paying more for a drug than they were paid by the Government.

Of course, he was merely referring to the cost differential. It does not go to the heart of the matter-that is, most businesses would have some financial incentive to buy, stock and hold drugs against the time when patients walk in off the street with a prescription and require those drugs. Certainly it is a ridiculous situation if pharmacists have to pay more to buy and hold drugs than they get back when those drugs are dispensed. Clearly, they should also get some sort of a fee for actually buying and stocking those drugs, particularly the expensive drugs which are perhaps prescribed less frequently. In today's Financial Review Mr Davies is quoted as saying:
. . . there was still no incentive for pharmacists to carry these drugs and people would still have to wait for pharmacists to buy-in these higher-priced items.
I believe that that is a completely accurate statement. The editorial goes on:
However, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Peter Staples, said yesterday the move would-
this is presumably a quotation from Mr Staples-
``put an end, once and for all'', to claims by pharmacists that they would be unable to carry these drugs because of tribunal's decision.

That is simply not a fair statement. The concern being expressed by pharmacists very strongly and vociferously in recent weeks has not been properly dealt with or properly allayed. It does not represent a small number of pharmacists. I remind the Senate that at the various rallies that were held in the major mainland capital cities around Australia roughly 1,000 pharmacists, or 80 per cent of the pharmacists in each State, turned up at each of those rallies expressing their concern. In addition, I personally received some 800 letters from pharmacists expressing a great deal of concern. It is not appropriate for Mr Staples to claim that this concern being expressed by pharmacists represents only a small group, a vocal minority or, in any sense, a ratbag element. The Government is attacking the whole basis of the pharmaceutical dispensing business in Australia. Clearly a far more thorough review of the remuneration of pharmacists through the PBS is called for.

In summary we, like the Opposition, will be supporting this Bill in relation to the increase in the maximum patient contribution from $11 to $12. We will be supporting the indexation of that contribution. We have no quarrel with that at all. We believe that the other more significant and substantial matter in relation to the remuneration of pharmacists has not been properly dealt with. It is appropriate to deal with it within this legislation. We express the hope that the Government has been sufficiently chastened by the opposition which has been mounted by pharmacists in recent weeks so that when this Bill is amended, as it will be, and when it goes to the House of Representatives it will support the amended Bill and set in place the proper and appropriate review of pharmacists' remuneration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the National Health Amendment Bill 1989. The purpose of this legislation, as my colleagues have already said, is to increase the consumer contribution under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) from $11 to $12. Quite frankly, it is not really a matter of great significance. What is of great significance is what this Government is doing to pharmacy in other areas and why the Government made this minor adjustment while continuing to direct its cost cutting programs towards pharmacy incomes. It hides behind the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, as it did vociferously when opposing the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits Determination Revocation and Tribunal Membership) Amendment Bill 1989. The cynical standpoint on the pharmacy policy of the Hawke Labor Government is the hope that there are more votes among consumers than there are among pharmacists, who are the scapegoats for the costs of the system. I do not believe that members of the Australian public are fools. They have given pharmacists a 76 per cent approval rating. They will not thank any government, much less this Government, that deprives them of access to pharmacies and diminishes the quality of health services.

SPEECH.PARA: Let it be said that Australian pharmacists are not just concerned about their own viability. These pharmacists happen to be professionally trained people who take pride in what they do, who take pride in the delivery of a good quality service and who want to continue that service to those who need it. Australia has an ageing population and, therefore, more and more people are needing pharmacy and more and more people are requiring drugs to keep them out of hospital. Yet this Government is hell bent on wrecking the pharmacy industry. I cannot understand the logic of that. One needs to look only at the cost of keeping people out of hospital; that should be the incentive on its own. The cost of a one-day bed in a public hospital equals the yearly prescription drug bill of eight people. Surely that is enough reason for this Government to see reason.

It is the fault of pharmacists that the system delivers an average prescription price of 2 per cent of average weekly earnings. They are the ones who are providing a very efficient system. When I say 2 per cent of average weekly earnings, that compares with 4.3 per cent in the United States of America and 4.2 per cent in Great Britain, which has a supposedly free health service.

The Opposition knows what the Government is wanting to do here. It also is trying to bring in a free health service. But, pensioners and low income earners aside, the PBS has been increasingly structured to provide a massive subsidy to consumers, regardless of need. What Australia needs is availability of drugs, not some hypothetical, mythical case of the Government saying, `We are going to provide a free service to all, regardless of what is really required'. Of course, the Government is threatening, in its aim to close down community pharmacies, that people can go to public hospitals to get their scripts filled. What a nice old clog-up that will cause in the public hospital system. It is already clogged in all other areas, so why not clog it up in pharmacy as well! If the Government means to persevere with a policy that has reduced the cost of prescriptions from 6.6 per cent of average weekly earnings in 1955 to 2 per cent today, it should be honest with the electors and tell them that their taxes will continue to rise in order to provide such a general subsidy.

Of course, the alternative is to crush the pharmacists, in the hope of reducing demand by the old socialist tactic of cutting supply and quality. Increasingly, Australian pharmacists and their customers can conclude only that the Hawke Labor Government has developed a total hostility towards community pharmacy. The evasions by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) were bad enough but now we have the spectacle of his boss, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), telling us all, with a straight face I might add, that pharmacists have enjoyed `a real bonanza'-they are his words, not mine-in extra income and that their earnings have risen well above everybody else's in the community. That simply is not so.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is.

—Senator Giles has just interjected and said that it is. I will get back to that in a little while. It is interesting because Senator Giles obviously has not bothered to talk to representatives of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia; nor has she checked back on the figures of what has really happened to pharmacy incomes. The Opposition can conclude only that the Minister has taken leave of reality, if not of his senses, or that he is banking on the fact that if a senior Minister says in effect that black is white he will get reported in the media and some people will be silly enough to believe him. It is, however, an incredibly misleading statement coming from a government that has done its very best, its utmost, to reduce pharmacy incomes.

SPEECH.PARA: The old story put out by Labor against the mythical wealthy doctor is now being re-run against the mythical wealthy pharmacist. There is at least some truth in the fact that Medicare gave an opening to a few medical entrepreneurs. But I defy this Government to point to any pharmacist who has grown wealthy through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme under which pharmacists depend upon the decisions of governments, tribunals and the prescribing habits of doctors. To a very large degree they are not masters of their own destiny and this Government is seeking to wipe them out.

If the threat to community pharmacy were not so serious, the Minister's outburst would be quite hilarious, coming from a government that last year cut the real income of pharmacists by 12 per cent by a combination of measures such as the reduction in professional fees, the 5 per cent cut in wholesale margins, the doubling of the maximum prescribable quantity of drugs per prescription and the removal of drugs from the PBS list on the grounds of expense rather than efficacy. All along the line the Government has decided what is best for the consumer-not what is best for the patient or the industry. It has decided what is best for itself and its penny-pinching habits.

Despite all the reductions that have been made, Senator Giles had the courage not only in the Senate today, but also previously when debating our Bill to overturn the Tribunal's decision, to say that pharmacies are on a real winner. One could believe that they are megamillionaires by listening to her. It is about time she got out there and talked to a few of those pharmacists. They have not been allowed to share in the gains created by their improved administrative efficiency in switching to computerised returns. I add that the cost of switching to computerised returns has been borne by the pharmacists-nobody else. No fairy godmother swooped down and dumped a computer into their pharmacies. They had to go out and buy the wretched things. Yet the Government says that they have been allowed to share in the gains. They jolly well should be allowed to share in the gains! It is the pharmacists who have achieved a 5 per cent productivity gain over the last 20 years and who have cost this Government nothing in the past eight years by retraining 20,000 people in computer use to save the PBS. They have saved the Government $20m each year. The thanks they get for forking out the money is to have their incomes cut. Pharmacists have never known the meaning of restrictive work practices. But their reward has been an attack on their incomes.

Supposedly, thanks to the policies of this Labor Government, the gross income of pharmacists over the last five years has risen by 81 per cent. That is what Senator Giles will be carping on about again today, as she did a couple of weeks ago. Their incomes have risen by 81 per cent. That is not bad, is it? But let us look at the rest of the story. The cost of pharmacy goods has increased by 125 per cent and the cost of labour has increased by 90 per cent. That is not bad, is it? But whacko, the pharmacists got 81 per cent, plus all the other decisions of this Government that have cut their incomes. I note that Senator Giles on the other side is mumbling away.

Is it any wonder that there are more and more untruths being told by a Minister, who, quite frankly, is about as bright as a blown globe in this respect, who will not tackle the issue and will not look at the problems for the consumer, let alone the pharmacist? But we are expected to believe that the pharmacists have had this great windfall and have never had it so good. The actual increase to pharmacists, prior to the Tribunal's decision of a further reduction of 23 per cent, was an increase of 46 per cent. People on average weekly earnings have had an increase of 52 per cent. The consumer price index has risen by 51 per cent. Yet the Government has the audacity to say that pharmacists are wealthy.

This Government, of course, when it is not abusing the pharmacists, hides behind the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, declaring that the decision that it made to cut pharmacy incomes by 23 per cent had nothing to do with it at all; it is holier than thou. The Government says, `It is not our decision; it is an independent reneration tribunal's decision'. But what a lot of people do not know is that the Government actually put an ambit claim to the Tribunal to reduce the income and remove the mark-up. That is what the Government did. But it says, `It is not us, we did not make the decision; we cannot overturn the Remuneration Tribunal's decision'. What rot! For sheer political gain, it has overturned the independent-and I emphasise the word `independent'-Remuneration Tribunal's decision on parliamentary incomes. Needless to say, most people would think that that is the greatest idea that has ever come out. But how can the Government say on the one hand, `We cannot overturn the independent remuneration tribunal's decision on pharmacies because it is independent', yet, on the other hand, for sheer political gain with regard to the pilots dispute, overturn the independent Remuneration Tribunal's decision on parliamentary incomes? It not only overturned it; in another area it went outside what it should be doing.

Let us look at why it cannot overturn the Remuneration Tribunal's decision. It has already overturned part of it. It has already said, `We will give pharmacies in remote locations, in country areas, an allowance of about'-and I emphasise the word `about'-`$12,000. We will also give an allowance to those who are at least 10 kilometres from the nearest approved pharmacy, those who dispense fewer than 15,000 claimable prescriptions a year and are open at least 20 hours a week'. That is fine. At least it has seen the light of day in one respect, but that has gone against the Remuneration Tribunal's decision. Yet when it comes to the real crux of the issue, it says, `Oh no, we cannot change that, that is not within our province'.

What our amendment seeks to do yet again is to try to have the decision of the Tribunal of 28 August 1989 overturned. As the Senate would know, the Opposition put forward a Bill 2 1/2 weeks ago to have this decision overturned. It was actually carried in the Senate, but, of course, one does not need to be cynical to realise that that Bill will never see the light of the day in the House of Representatives. This time, the Government has to decide what it is going to do, whether it is going to continue to persecute the pharmacists and the consumers.

It is interesting to note that it is not only the Opposition that is very angry about what is happening to the pharmacists and the consumers. Even one of the Government's own backbenchers, as my colleague Senator Puplick mentioned earlier, has left a message in no uncertain terms for Minister Staples about the Minister's treatment of the Government's back bench. He has said that Minister Staples is treating backbenchers like idiots. It reminds me of a little story someone told me yesterday about the kid in class who had given the wrong answer to a question and was called up to the teacher who said, `You know, you are one step away from an idiot', and the kid said, `Do you want me to take a step back?'. This could well be said about what Minister Staples is doing, because the letter of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Campbell, to the chairman of the caucus back bench pharmacists liaison committee, Mr Jim Snow, attacks Mr Staples's handling of the dispute and says that his attitude has inflamed every pharmacist. That is quite right, from the very simple basis that Minister Staples has not the faintest idea what the pharmacists are talking about, even when he goes to listen to them, which I might add is not very often. Mr Campbell also accused Minister Staples of circulating incorrect figures about remuneration and causing a worsening of the dispute. He said:
It is my view that this confrontationist and emotional atmosphere is being generated by some of the absurdities coming from the Minister's office.

Not coming from anyone else, but from the Minister's office. That really tells the whole story, does it not? The fact is that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal makes its decision taking into account data that is supplied to it by this Government, with a database survey drawn from a response of less than 0.3 per cent of pharmacists and using unacceptable criteria for assessing incomes.

This Hawke Labor Government believes that an independent community pharmacist is worth only $14.30 per hour, which is less than half the hourly rate for a middle range government salaried pharmacist. One may well ask: How does this compare with incomes of other health professionals? I would suggest not too well at all. If we asked the whole of the health community to work for $14.30 per hour, the whole thing would be shut up. It is fair to assume that, by its actions, the Government is aiming for a situation where pharmacists that survive will only do so as public servants. Why else is Labor so blind to the advantage of the current system whereby the independent pharmacist is not subject to the outside pressure of a non-pharmacy employer? How hypocritical for the Minister in charge of pharmacy remuneration to have stated last year at the annual dinner of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia that `the Australian Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme has been one of the best such schemes in the world'. Gee whiz, has he not changed his tune now? He now wants to see the end of it.

Despite the expressed concern of the Government as to the cost of pharmaceuticals, an item that in 1970 consumed 19 per cent of the health budget comprises 11.3 per cent of health expenditure in 1989-90. Rises in the cost of drugs are not the responsibility of the pharmacists. They have absolutely nothing to do with it. But the pharmacist is the one who, nonetheless, is called upon by the Government and its agencies to act as scapegoat while the cost of the big ticket items of Medicare continue to rise.

By its actions and evasions, this Labor Government will bear a massive responsibility when pharmacies close up and deprive Australians of an essential, respected and, I might add, user friendly health service. Closures will impact not only upon country towns-in Western Australia several smaller but far from insignificant centres are now without a pharmacist, and more have closed in the last couple of weeks-but also upon great numbers of the elderly who will no longer be within walking distance of a pharmacist. They will find that remaining pharmacists can no longer afford the time to advise them free of charge and monitor their drug usage.

What right does this Government have to decide where any pharmacy or any business, whether it be a delicatessen, a newsagent, a supermarket or whatever, should be established? It has no right at all. Yet the great carrot that the Government is now using is, `We'll give you extra money as long as you're further than 10 kilometres away from the next recognised pharmacy'. How dare it say that. If it is someone else's choice to decide to fork out the money to establish any business, he should be the master of his own destiny. He should not have the Government saying, `We're going to rationalise the availability of pharmacies'. It is not a case of rationalising pharmacies; it is a case of closing pharmacies.

If we want an illustration of how consumers feel about pharmacy we need only look at one instance of an elderly lady who spoke on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation talkback radio in Perth on 8 September. She stated that a pharmacist had in fact corrected an error in a prescription for tranquillisers and had warned her of the danger of addiction. She asked the question, `Who else would give me this free advice?'. It is a very good question. The other day I heard of a pharmacist who drove a sick patient home. The Government, of course, would say that that is not his job, and it is right-it is not his job. But the pharmacists happen to care about the destiny of their patients, not just their own. Those pharmacists who do put in that extra effort should be admired, not belittled and done out of business. That is the very important aspect that the Minister is missing.

Rubbish from a senior Minister about rises in the earnings of pharmacists is a mockery to a chemist in another Perth suburb who netted $31,000 last year, a figure for which most people in real professions who have had to gain university qualifications and many years of experience would not even work. It is also worth noting that for this modest income of $31,000 the pharmacist happened to have worked 60 hours a week. And this Government wants to take away 23 per cent of his income. This pharmacist employs one full time and two part time assistants but can no longer afford the services of another qualified pharmacist attending one day per week. This is a very familiar story. It is no wonder that the staff of pharmacists, who are also experienced and dedicated people, feel compelled to write to honourable senators and honourable members expressing a fear that both their jobs and a necessary service will disappear.

Typically, the honourable member for Canning, Mr George Gear, self-appointed critic of doctors and other health professionals, who has had a field day in the last few years bashing all those people, responded to such a letter by accusing the writer of not having written the letter herself and declaring, `I take no notice of these threats'. That is the concern expressed by Mr Gear. I also saw a letter sent to a constituent by the honourable member for Brand, Ms Wendy Fatin. It was absolute and utter gobbledegook. Four of us read the letter and still did not understand it. She was trying to respond to a complaint by saying nothing and doing nothing. The Minister for Health in Western Australia says, `I'm going to get all my colleagues over there and I'm going to tell Minister Staples what to do about this. This has to be overturned'. But what has he done? Absolutely nothing. I understand that he has not even spoken to his Federal colleagues. This is getting beyond a joke. Those opposite are trying to calm people down while at the same time sticking hard and fast to a decision which they claim is not theirs and which they can do nothing about. That is simply not true; they can do something about it.

Only last week the honourable member for Canning, Mr Gear, tried to beat up a story that Western Australian pharmacists were threatening to charge pensioners for their prescriptions. The truth, which of course we would not expect from him, is that pharmacists have properly advised pensioners to order medications in advance since the policies of this Hawke Labor Government will make it very difficult for pharmacists to afford to keep many drugs in stock. These divisive petty tactics only show up the failure of the Government and will not divert pensioners from the real issue, which is that their continued access to user friendly pharmaceutical services is under real threat.

The pharmacists do not want to penalise anybody. All they want to do is continue running the very good show that they have been running for years and years. The Government is making decisions that are now forcing the pharmacists to look at other means of income. One may well ask the question: What would happen to the Medicare blow-out that has already blown right out of the water if the pharmacists kept on sending people back to doctors for the advice that the pharmacists are now giving them for free? The doctors would have to charge them. What sort of blow-out would we get then?

It is also sadly significant that fewer young men-who may after all be expected to function as sole breadwinners during the crucial years of family life-are entering pharmacy because they do not see it as providing adequate rewards for the professional training involved. It is very sad but nonetheless highly understandable. Many women are also reassessing their careers and their ambitions with regard to pharmacy. Why should they, or anyone else for that matter, put up their money to own a pharmacy only to have this Labor Government take it away? They cannot even sell the business because there is no money for people to buy it; there is no incentive for people to buy it. Do they put the business up for sale? Instead of selling goodwill they would have to say to the new buyer, `Don't worry, you will be out of business in six months time'. Who will buy a pharmacy? What will the pharmacists do? The Opposition will neither condone nor lie down and take the wholesale destruction of community pharmacy. The future of Australian health care will be very much the poorer, but maybe that is the continued ambition of this Government. I call upon the Government on this occasion to see reason and agree to overturn the Tribunal's decision by supporting our amendment to this Bill. The future of community pharmacy relies upon that decision. It is the right and proper course to take.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health Amendment Bill amends the National Health Act to increase the maximum general patient contribution for prescribed drugs supplied under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) from the present $11 to $12. The increase in the general patient contribution from $11 to $12 is estimated by the Government to achieve savings of $10m in 1989-90 and $17m in a full financial year. With indexation of the patient contribution, estimated savings are $35m for next year, $55m for the year after and $78m for 1992-93. Annual indexation of the general patient contribution will be in line with the March quarter all-group consumer price index (CPI). Many may wonder what pressure the Australian Statistician will come under when the Government wants to change the general patient contribution or its method of indexation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone in this chamber on 7 September this year, speaking on the Australian Statistics Advisory Council annual report of 1988-89, said that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) put obvious pressure on the Statistician to change the method of calculating the CPI after a disastrous December CPI result of 2.1 per cent in 1988. The ABS changed the method of calculation and made the hollow claim that no political pressure had been involved in the decision. There is fancy footwork in this Bill and the index may change for reasons quite other than those that have to do with the real state of inflation. That is one issue that concerns the Opposition.

Over the last two years the Government has bungled changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Instead of getting to the roots of cost increases in the PBS and consulting the industry, the Government has continually made changes that have threatened the viability of the community pharmacy. As often as those changes have been made, the Opposition has called on the Government to carry out a total review of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. On 1 January 1989, the Government cut wholesale margins from 15 per cent to 10 per cent. The cost to the average pharmacy was approximately $250 a week. The effect of this was that a surcharge was introduced by the wholesalers and the full cost of this was borne by the pharmacists.

In May 1988 the Government added 53 drugs to the authority only list. This was an attempt to get doctors to prescribe alternatives. One pharmacist I spoke to said that it seemed as though someone in the Department had simply run through the list and picked out the 53 most expensive items. Some of the 53 drugs had no alternative-for example, the anti-cancer drugs. The result was a bureaucratic nightmare for doctors, pharmacists and patients alike. A loud scream to modify the system was heard and changes had to be made. The Government also doubled the maximum quantities on many PBS items on 1 August 1988. This resulted in an average loss of $120 per week per pharmacy. Included in this were most psychoactive drugs and the resultant outcry from this change was so great that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) quickly changed his mind. One of the things that forced him to change his mind was a letter sent by every pharmacy board in Australia to all pharmacists reminding them of their responsibilities under the various State health Acts not to dispense inappropriately large quantities of drugs, especially large quantities of psychoactive drugs. I have said this before and I will say it again: pharmacists are not shopkeepers handing out lollipops. As drugs have become more potent, pharmacists' responsibilities have increased. They feel a great responsibility when they are ordered, instructed or through legislation are required to hand out large amounts of drugs that they believe should not be handed out in those quantities.

In September 1987 the Government also announced a series of changes in the PBS. One of these was to delist a number of drugs and substitute them for the cheaper generic alternative. The result was shortages and a large number of people having difficulty with the supply of medicine as the generic alternative was often unavailable. The Minister refused to admit that there were problems. There was also the added result that many older people were faced with being prescribed the generic drugs which had different packaging, different labelling and different names. Many older people who had been taking these drugs for a long time became quite confused. In fact, there were examples of some people taking wrong drugs as a result of these changes. A number of the generic drugs were alternatives to anti-depressants. When the generic alternatives were supplied in bottles instead of the strip packs of the original product there was the potential for drug overdoses. A psychiatrist picked that up and complained.

The next decision which threatened community pharmacies was made by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal (PBRT). It reduced the fee paid to pharmacists to 10c from February 1989. This decision has been overturned by the Federal Court and the Federal Government has appealed against the decision. With respect to the PBRT's decision, the Federal Court said that it was `so unreasonable that no reasonable person would have so exercised the power'. Further, it said that it was difficult to see how, at a time of general inflation, the amount of the professional fee should be reduced.

The latest decision made by the PBRT on 28 August 1989 will cut pharmacists' incomes by 23 per cent. This decision was based on a survey conducted by Deloitte Haskins and Sells in 1988 that was statistically flawed and invalid. Less than 10 per cent of pharmacies in Australia were surveyed and only 32 per cent of that sample group responded. So 0.3 per cent of pharmacists were surveyed and responded. As a Victorian senator, I was fascinated to find that only two pharmacists in Victoria were in that sample. The President of the PBRT felt that the sample was insufficient, so he rang a number of pharmacies, not those in the original sample, and supplemented the results. Wonderful methodology! Most of what comes into this chamber would be failed on the basis of methodology, if it were presented by any second year student doing a research project in a university on any subject I could name. Absolutely appalling methodology is used.

The Tribunal has reduced from 1 October 1989 pharmacists' remuneration by $1.05 per prescription and has abolished the mark-up on cost of goods. The average loss per pharmacy will be in the region of $20,000 to $25,000. As this is prescription based, the loss will depend on the number of scripts the pharmacy dispenses. The Tribunal's decision will mean that at least 1,500 pharmacies face the very real possibility of closure. This estimate is based on the number of pharmacies dispensing fewer than 15,000 PBS and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme (RPBS) scripts per annum. This represents 28 per cent of all pharmacies. The remaining 72 per cent will have to reduce services and shed staff in a drastic way.

I will just tell the chamber a story I heard last night. I went home depressed last night. The hire car driver who drove me home told me she was working day and night. She drove a taxi in addition to the hire car because of the pilots strike and the lack of business here in Canberra. That story can be repeated throughout Australia. As Chairman of the Halls of Residence committee at Monash University, I know, for example, that students' rents will go up next year because conferences had to be cancelled. The ramifications are enormous. The hire car driver told me not only about the problem, but also about how her husband was told yesterday afternoon that his services would no longer be required after 5 o'clock on Friday night. He has a heart condition and had sold his pharmacy a year ago and went to work for another pharmacy. He was told his services would no longer be required because the Government is to change the remuneration for pharmacists on Sunday. The driver to whom I spoke had not only one burden, that resulting from the pilots dispute and the Government's mishandling of it, but also the burden of the retrenchment of her husband. That is what is happening; it is not something that will happen next year or sometime down the track, but at 5 o'clock on Friday. I felt very good going home to bed knowing that at least until the election I have a safe job, while this person had to go on working 15 hours a day seven days a week driving a cab and pulling a hire car out of the garage in the evening to do a few jobs for the Commonwealth, and her husband did not have a job. I bet that many Australians are in that sort of situation today.

The 23 per cent cut in pharmacists' remuneration came about after the Government last year cut pharmacists' real incomes by 12 per cent. It plans a further cut of 8 per cent this year. Over the past five years costs of pharmacy goods increased by 101.5 per cent and labour costs by 87 per cent. Pharmacists' gross income increased by only 81 per cent.
