This year we would expect wages to increase by 7 per cent-that is the Budget estimate-statutory charges to increase by 7 per cent, stock prices by 7 per cent and in Victoria, which is another case altogether, it is more than likely that WorkCare rates will increase also. But the Tribunal sees fit to reduce the pharmacists' remuneration by 23 per cent. One can imagine the result if this happened to the waterside workers or any other union or group. There would be mayhem.

A large part of the increased costs in the PBS is going to the manufacturer. Between 1985 and 1988, 62.3 per cent of the increased costs went to the manufacturer and 13 per cent to the pharmacist. The CPI in this period rose by 27.2 per cent, yet the pharmacist is the one who is being expected to bear the brunt of cost cutting in the PBS. The Tribunal created such ridiculous anomalies that from 1 October 1989 pharmacists would have been expected to stock and sell certain drugs at a loss. It is just unbelievable. For example, the cost to the pharmacist of 20 milligrams of Roaccutane is $157.72. The payment to the pharmacist was to be $153.20, resulting in a loss of $4.22 before taking any account of holding costs or any of the other things that go into stocking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Interest on overdrafts.

—Such as interest on overdrafts. I can go on. There are the costs of refrigeration for drugs that require it. I do not need to enumerate the costs that are involved in holding drugs. In this PBS the Government and the Tribunal have yet again been forced to back down and back-pedal from this part of the decision. Since I have been in this chamber the whole of the PBS has had a history of on again, off again-drugs on, drugs off, rules in, rules out. The Tribunal said that it did not realise that its decision would have created such a situation. The Tribunal should have found out what the consequences of its decision would be for every drug. The Tribunal ordered the Government to pay a gap fee to the pharmacists in the interim until a change was made to wholesalers' margins. As the decision stood, PBS listed drugs with a wholesale cost greater than $50 would not be dispensed because of losses involved. There are 171 brands and/or strengths of PBS listed items in this category. These drugs include all insulins for diabetics, most anti-cancer drugs, some antibiotics, some drugs to treat high blood pressure and some drugs for asthmatics.

SPEECH.PARA: A report in the Age yesterday said that the Federal Government appeared to have struck a deal with wholesalers about the issue of whether pharmacists will stock expensive drugs once their fees are cut-an agreement that wholesalers would stop surcharging pharmacies but instead increase their margins from 10 per cent to 13 per cent. This would be done by increasing the agreed price of drugs, a price set by the Government and paid to pharmacists, wholesalers and manufacturers. Pharmacists I have consulted have said that items with a high turnover will be held and sold, and that, although the pharmacists may make little profit on these items, at least they will not be making a loss. But items with low turnovers will be able to be held only at a loss to the pharmacist. Although the pharmacist will be charged the correct manufactured price and will receive payment from the Government based on that price, the costs of holding that item will still not be covered. We do not do it with magic. Pharmacists have to have somewhere to hold the drug, they have to have insurance and they have to pay all the other costs that I outlined before. There are overdraft costs; there is stock wastage on some drugs which, because they have a low usage rate, may have an expired out of date code; and there are freight and other costs. The pharmacist will still lose on these items, so they will not be stocked. The public will have to wait for them to come in. Some of these drugs are for asthmatics and diabetics.

Pharmacists are presented with a moral and ethical dilemma. They want to be able to supply these drugs. They are there to offer a service to the community. But if they continue to do so, they will make a loss. Anybody with any economic sense will know that one can only do that for a limited amount of time and then one goes out of business. An unreasonable demand is being made on pharmacists.

The effects of the Tribunal's decisions are many, and Senator Knowles outlined a number of them. We have already got the loss of employment. We will see increased costs to Medicare. How often have people in this chamber gone to a pharmacist and said, `I have this little rash here. What should I do about it?'. The pharmacist will say, `You could use such and such but I recommend that if it is not healed within so many days you go to your doctor'. The rash then heals and one does not go to the doctor. Pharmacists offer a primary care to people who come in seeking advice. Senator McKiernan smiles. I bet he has been to a pharmacist to ask for advice. As pharmacies close there will be time pressure on remaining pharmacists because they will be dispensing a large number of drugs and that will impinge on their ability to act as health care givers. Pharmacists see themselves as health carers, and I think that they deserve to do so. The very role the Government has said it is trying to enhance and encourage is being reduced. There will be less time for pharmacists to counsel patients on medication, thus increasing the risk of drug interaction, and less patient compliance, increasing the risk of overdose.

Before I came into the Senate my area of interest was gerontology, the study of ageing. Some 82 per cent of the people who use the pharmaceutical benefits scheme are pensioners. Most of those are older people. It is a known fact, demonstrated scientifically, that as people get older-and I am talking now about the old, old people of 75 years plus-their ability to comprehend instructions declines, and this condition is exacerbated if they are ill. One of the things about which older people get instructions is taking drugs. Not only does our ability to comprehend instructions decline as we get older but also, from 40 years of age onwards, the half life of drugs in our system-the length of time for a drug to be excreted-increases. So older people are more likely to suffer from drug interactions, especially if they take the wrong drugs at the wrong times in the wrong quantities.

So it is particularly important that pharmacists have the time when they are dispensing drugs to older people to go over what has been said to them in the doctor's surgery. We are all nervous when we go to a doctor's surgery. We almost forget to tell him about the wart on our toe or something else. He gives us instructions but we are anxious because we are worried about what his prognosis or diagnosis will be. When we go out, the pharmacist is there and can tell us again. I am sorry to say that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) the other day referred to an elderly gentleman in South Australia as `a silly old bugger'. All those older people who get that sort of respect from the Prime Minister of our country-and I would not use that term for older citizens, who deserve better treatment-will not have a pharmacist who has time to go over the way they should take drugs.

Country pharmacies will be particularly affected. The greatest concern centres around 450 country towns that have only one pharmacy. Those pharmacies are under the same cost pressures as others. The closure rate of these pharmacies will increase. Once pharmacies close they will not re-open. Nobody will want to re-open a pharmacy with the uncertainty caused by Government decisions to make changes in the PBS. We have seen many of those on again, off again changes. Many small country town pharmacies service pensioners in close proximity to where they live. These people will suffer most if pharmacies close. Pharmacies cannot mark up their prices like other businesses to compensate for low turnover. The Government has canvassed the idea of an isolated pharmacy allowance for pharmacies at least 10 kilometres-it was much further before but the Government has reduced the distance-from their nearest competitor. This would apply only to pharmacies dispensing fewer than 1,500 scripts per year. There is some doubt as to whether in the present climate this measure would ensure the viability of these vital pharmacies.

I have not mentioned the effect on women. Twenty per cent of pharmacy owners are women, and 60 to 70 per cent of graduates of pharmacy colleges are women. It seems amazing to me that this Government attacks two of the courses which have the highest intake of women. We have just had a recent attack on medical education and medical students. One of the Queen Elizabeth II Silver Jubilee Trust for Young Australian students, a young girl from Portland, said to me yesterday, `You know, I am now having to think about whether or not I will be able to have a family'. This 18-year-old was saying, `I do not know whether I will be able to have a baby because it will take me 11 years before I can get the full rebate on Medicare'. The Minister says, `Don't worry. They wouldn't worry about whether they can have a family; they will be able to stop off and have a family'. This 18-year-old girl, wanting to go into medicine-a Victorian, one of my constituents-was thinking, at 18, about whether she can have a family.

This is yet another attack on women. Ninety-eight per cent of assistants in pharmacies are women, many in part-time employment; 82 per cent of pharmacy employees are women; and 85 per cent of customers in pharmacies are women. I am glad that Senator Reynolds is here and I hope she is listening to me because I ask her: Which group will be most affected by this legislation? It will be older people and women-and the majority of older people in Australia are women. The Government is attacking women in two fell swoops-the employees in the pharmacies and the people who use the pharmacies.

At the beginning of this year the Pharmacy Guild of Australia made a submission to the Government which looked at the whole structure of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. That submission cost the Pharmacy Guild $100,000 to produce. What has been the Government's response? The Pharmacy Guild tells me it has had scant recognition from the Government and all the negotiations have been about the almighty dollar-the bottom line, the dollar cost of the scheme. What the Government has not done is take up the pharmacists' offer-and they have offered-to work towards a total restructuring of this sick scheme. Only last Tuesday I sat in the Victorian office of the Pharmacy Guild and talked to pharmacists. They said, `We have got suggestions to make about how to reduce the cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. We know that there are some anomalies and problems. We want to work with the Government to address and redress them. We wanted to do that so much that we actually prepared a submission which cost us a lot of money and the Government has given it almost no consideration'. Let me turn to the advertisement in yesterday's Australian which has this heading:
Is your local chemist leading you down the garden path?

When Minister Staples put out an advertisement about nursing homes not being conned-many senators will know that I am interested in nursing homes-he was game enough to put on it, `Authorised by Peter Staples, Commonwealth Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Parliament House, Canberra'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you try ringing up? They could not give you any answers?

—Yes, we did ring up and were given no answers. We are waiting for them, and hope to get them in the mail. With regard to the advertisement dealing with the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, changes in drugs and brand names, entitled `Prescription drugs-important news', the pharmaceutical benefits scheme had the good grace to put the Commonwealth pharmaceutical benefits scheme logo on the bottom, but no authorisation. As far as yesterday's advertisement is concerned, unless one is in the know one would not have a clue who authorised it. All that is shown are the letters `PBS', with no authorisation. It seems to me to be almost a political statement. It says that the Australian Government is concerned about the health of all Australians. If that is not a political statement, what is? I suppose one could make up all sorts of names using the initials PBS, but I will not do so. In this advertisement the Government says that chemists are worried about how much money they make. All Australians, in the economic mess we are in, are worried about how much money they make. Pharmacists have businesses to run, staff to pay, mortgages to meet and families to support. They have a right to be worried. Members of parliament on both sides of the chamber are not so slow to go to their remuneration tribunal when they are worried about how much money they make.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, the advertisement states that the Government is concerned about the health of all Australians, and the implication is that pharmacists are not concerned about the health of all Australians. The Government, the PBS or whoever authorised this advertisement, is wrong. Where is the proof that pharmacists are not concerned about the health of all Australians? If they were not concerned, would they provide the level of service they do-services which are not supported in the funding arrangements, like free deliveries and free advice? Pharmacists are not a group of people who do not care about the health of all Australians. The PBS advertisement was, I suppose, authorised by the Minister, but we do not know that. What else do we see in this advertisement? It states:
Every Australian will continue to have ready access to chemists. And all Australians will continue to be protected by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
These facts are guaranteed by the Australian Government and by law.

Pharmacists have said that in order to compensate for the price reductions forced on them by Government without any offset savings they will have to make those savings internally by cutting services such as free pickup and delivery of scripts. If, then, they cannot afford to maintain the services they provide, they will have to withdraw from the pharmacy business. What do the Government's fighting words in this advertisement mean? Are pharmacists to be subject to civil conscription? Are they to be denied the right to withdraw their labour? Is the Government intending to socialise the pharmacy area? I remind the Senate of section 51 of the Constitution which states:
The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to-
Section 51 (xxiiia) states:

The provision of maternity allowances, widows' pensions, child endowment, unemployment, pharmaceutical, sickness and hospital benefits, medical and dental services (but not so as to authorise any form of civil conscription), benefits to students and family allowances . . .

I emphasise that section in brackets because it has been considered in two cases, one concerning the British Medical Association in 1949 and one concerning the General Practitioners Society in 1980. The advice I received as to the judges' decision is as follows:

The result is that a majority in both cases decided that, as a matter of grammatical construction, the prohibition against civil conscription only applied to the phrase ``medical and dental services''. If this interpretation is upheld by future High Courts the unemployment benefit payments which are made conditional upon some form of civil conscription would not breach that pl. 51 (xxiiiA).
Neither of the two cases gives a conclusive definition of what would constitute civil conscription.
The legal advice that I received on this section of the Constitution went on to state:

Five Judges in the General Practitioners Society case considered that a law could impose civil conscription even if it did not create a legal liability to perform a medical service. Thus a law could have economic or other results which would force doctors to practise even if the law did not specifically do so itself. The court was of the view that this practical compulsion also amounted to civil conscription.

Here we have a threat hanging over the heads of the pharmacists that every Australian will continue to have ready access to chemists, all Australians will continue to be protected by the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, and that these facts are guaranteed by the Australian Government and Australian law. I am sure when it was written, it was known exactly what was meant by that. Who is leading whom down the garden path? We may yet see pharmacists being forced down the garden path by civil conscription. It is not just the pharmacists but all Australians who are being forced down, not a garden path, but possibly a dangerous path which involves the erosion of the free right of citizens to withdraw their labour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up very much of the time of the Senate today but there are a few points which have been raised in the debate which deserve a response. We are debating the National Health Amendment Bill 1989 which is quite narrow in its application and simply refers to the amendment of the National Health Act to increase the maximum general patient contribution for prescribed drugs supplied under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) from the present amount of $11 to $12. It is estimated that this will achieve savings of $10m in 1989-90 and $17m in a full financial year. There is no disagreement between the Opposition and the Government concerning that Bill, but, predictably, the debate this morning has concentrated on the controversy surrounding the Government and the pharmacists subsequent to the recent decision of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: I find the most recent point made by Senator Patterson, that we are talking about civil conscription of pharmacists, a somewhat long bow to be drawing in this context, and in any other, I might add. It is certainly completely unlikely to be on the agenda, that is, if Senator Patterson is serious about it. In view of the fact that pharmacists on average receive only 30 per cent of their income from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, it seems to me very strange to assume that there was any justification whatsoever for civil conscription of pharmacists or anybody else involved in pharmaceutical services.

I want to correct a statement that I made on the previous occasion we debated this issue in the Senate. On the basis of a newspaper report-which I did not check; I must be more careful-I said that it was strange to discover that about 20 per cent of all Australian pharmacies were to be found in Western Australia. I was surprised about this. On checking, I found that the newspaper report was incorrect and that, more predictably and more credibly, the number of pharmacies in Western Australia is a little less than 10 per cent of the number of pharmacies in the nation.

Some of these pharmacies are doing very well. I did not, as Senator Knowles suggested, insist that all pharmacists were making high profits. That is not the case. None of us have ever suggested that was the case. Obviously, where competitive, the pharmacy industry can be very financially rewarding. Why else, for example, would there be in Fremantle a pharmacist on each of the four corners of a very busy intersection? Clearly, they must be competitive to stay there, and to provide the services they provide in a very busy part of town. I cannot imagine many of them staying at that level of competition if they were not viable.

A number of statements were made about the new advisory body that the Minister has established since negotiations with the Guild broke down completely. It seems to me that, contrary to what Senator Puplick suggested about divide and rule, et cetera, the only sensible and responsible decision was the one that the Minister made, in view of the strong disaffection that pharmacists from all over the nation were indicating with their own Guild.

All pharmacists who were invited to join the advisory body joined it, with the exception of Mr Rick James of Brisbane who, I understand, initially accepted the invitation on 12 September and sent a letter of resignation on 14 September, although the letter itself was dated 12 September. One could make one of two assumptions from that set of facts. One could assume that he initially never intended to accept and was simply using the occasion to make a political statement or, more likely, that a considerable amount of pressure was placed on those individuals who were invited to join that advisory body and that Mr Rick James was the only one to yield to that pressure.

I am happy to say that he was replaced by Mr MacAnuff of Shenton Park in Western Australia, a pharmacist for whom I have a great deal of respect. He was put on the advisory body as a representative of CAPS, a group of pharmacists in Western Australia which is considered to be strongly militant. It was an indication of the Minister's very good sense that he sought a member from Western Australia and someone who will put a strong position on behalf of what I understand is the unanimous view of Western Australian pharmacists. Mr MacAnuff also takes a very principled professional stand as a leading member of a Western Australian professional association of pharmacists. The first meeting of the advisory group occurred last week and I understand that each member of the group made a fine and constructive contribution to the group's deliberations. As a result of the meeting a number of statements have been made by the Minister.

I turn to the criticisms of the Tribunal. There is still considerable confusion in the minds of some Opposition members about the Tribunal's role over the years, the effects of its decision, and the possible effect of any High Court decision which rejected the legitimacy of the Tribunal. Senator Puplick expressed his view that statements that were made in relation to this matter were a threat to or intimidation of pharmacists who had decided to appeal the Tribunal's decision. That is not the point at all. If such an appeal were successful it would remove the legitimacy, not only of the Tribunal, but of all the Tribunal's decisions for the last eight or nine years. That would return us to the position that existed in 1981 before the Tribunal's establishment. We totally reject allegations of hostility and contempt of pharmacists as a whole. That certainly is not the case and, as I have said, we are working closely and constructively with a new advisory body which appears to have strong support amongst the pharmaceutical community generally.

The Tribunal's decision has also been criticised on the grounds that since the decision itself other decisions have been made. The Tribunal did what it was required to do. It rejected the bandaid approach which has been taken over the years and which, as Senator Patterson acknowledges, has led to its own anomalies and to a cost escalation which is certainly of concern. We must take measures to stop this escalation. I remind the Senate that a couple of years ago the cost was $700m. Last year it was over $1 billion. This year it will be well over $1,200m, or a 17 per cent increase.

We anticipate that in three years the cost of our pharmaceutical benefits scheme will have risen to $2 billion. That cost escalation has been partly-there are a number of elements, of course-as a result of the fact that the decisions of the Tribunal have been blanket decisions. For example, there were the decisions about a blanket mark-up fee which has been removed. There is considerable concern-we knew that there would be-about the extra costs to pharmacists of very expensive drugs. That matter has now been dealt with. Nobody ever anticipated that it would not be dealt with. Right from 11 May, when the Government package was put to the Pharmacy Guild, it was known that the Commonwealth would need to negotiate with wholesalers in regard to surcharging. As a result of these negotiations, in return for an end to surcharges, the Government is to increase the wholesalers' margin on drug prices from 10 per cent to 13 per cent. This will be done by increasing the agreed price of the drugs, a price set by the Government and paid to pharmacists, wholesalers and manufacturers. It does not affect the price paid by consumers.

The increase of 10 per cent to 13 per cent will provide a degree of compensation for the loss of the 25 per cent blanket mark-up for drugs. The Government will pick up the surcharge for drugs which cost over $45. It will remove the cost pressures on small pharmacies especially, which would have had real difficulties maintaining their stocks, as has been said this morning on a number of occasions. It will involve the expensive drugs such as insulin, and drugs that are used for the treatment of cancer and high blood pressure. That is the issue of the surcharge. Nobody doubted that that issue would have to be dealt with subsequent to the Tribunal's decision.

The question of essential pharmacies has also been dealt with. I will not go through that again in detail but as a result of the advisory body meeting last week we were able to announce that a new Government allowance for chemists would start on 1 October to assist those pharmacies which were adjudged to be essential pharmacies because of their geographical isolation and which were handling a relatively small number of prescriptions. We have added to those criteria. Now special cases outside those criteria will also be considered by a review committee which will include several community pharmacists. So the door is not shut to pharmacies which believe that they are essential pharmacies and which believe that they should be eligible for that extra assistance. This is an ongoing process; it will not stop on 1 October or at any time in the near future. Right from the beginning, it was known that the issue would have to be dealt with subsequent to the Tribunal's decision. It is not an overturning of the Tribunal's decision but an addition to it, a decision which is open to the Government to make.

The third issue, which is one which will also receive a great deal of consideration over the next few weeks and months, is the professional role of pharmacists. It is on the agenda of the new advisory body but there will be wider consultations as indeed there should be about this important issue. Pharmacies vary greatly in the populations that they serve and in the demands that are placed upon them. For example, a pharmacist who serves a complex of aged people's homes is providing a service to individuals who, in many cases, are really quite frail but because of the drugs that they have been prescribed are able to be kept mobile. We know this is extremely important for the quality of their lives and also to maintain them as independent of expensive nursing home services. The pharmacist in this position is dispensing almost inevitably very costly and very potent drugs and in such situations he is required to give a great deal of advice and counselling to the client.

Other pharmacists have large populations of quite fit pensioners with whom they deal; so the demand for day-to-day counselling is not quite so great. The drugs that are being dispensed tend not to be so potent and so forth. Other pharmacists are dealing with young families and particularly mothers with young children. Children contract frequent infections, all sorts of bumps and bruises, rashes, coughs, colds and all the rest of it and mothers are very grateful for extra advice which the pharmacists willingly give. I will quote what I think is a very good description given by Mr Jim Snow, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, during this debate in the House of Representatives. He said of pharmacists:
They know more about the actions of drugs than do the prescribers of drugs-
that is a pretty grim comment on people who prescribe the drugs-

They know more about the side effects of drugs. They know more about the need for patient compliance and how to encourage the patient to comply with the taking of medication. They know more about drug incompatibility. They know more about what drugs should not be taken with others.

Those are statements with which none of us would argue and with which none of us has ever argued. We appreciate the fact that in order to encourage and to recognise that particular role of the pharmacists we must be prepared, after due consideration and wide consultation, to provide some financial recognition of that particular role. I believe the bona fides of the Government are impeccable in this matter. The Tribunal has done its job. As I said, it has rejected the bandaid approach which has existed for about 30 years. It has given a decision which the pharmacists are at liberty to appeal but that decision, as everybody knew, was only on one issue and that was the prescription fee. All these other issues that have been taken up subsequently have always been on the agenda. They could have been agreed with the Guild in May when the Government made an offer of a package.

It looks as if, after a great deal of heat and excitement and not a little anguish, the offers-or at least some modification of them-that the Government made in May are gradually coming to be accepted by the majority of the pharmacists. The point has been reached where the discussions that we are having are seen to be constructive. The majority of pharmacists find them acceptable and they are certainly nowhere near the dangerous interpretation of Senator Patterson-that we might be moving to conscript the pharmaceutical industry.

We in the Government of course oppose the amendments that are being proposed today by the Opposition which not only would have the effect of postponing the 1 October commencement of the Act in relation to the National Health Amendment Bill but, I suppose, might even throw into question the date of application of a number of these other issues about which there has been so much discussion. The other effect of the Opposition's amendment would be that the determination of the Tribunal of 28 August 1989 should be of no force or effect. Naturally we believe that that decision should go ahead. We also believe that the other measures that have been accepted and are seen to be acceptable should also go ahead on 1 October for the benefit not only of the pharmaceutical industry but also, much more importantly, of all those people in the community who depend so strongly, and so justifiably too, on the excellent services that they receive from the pharmacists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the National Health Amendment Bill 1989 whereby the Government seeks to increase the contribution that a person will pay on obtaining a prescription from $11 to $12. We are also looking at an Opposition amendment, which I support, which is an amendment also to the National Health Amendment Bill that the decision of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal dated 28 August 1989 shall be of no force or effect. That, of course, is to reiterate a decision that has already been made by the Senate that that decision of the Tribunal should be of no force or effect. This is a means of requiring the Government to have a much closer look at that decision of the Senate than otherwise would be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Giles has spoken of the fact that only 30 per cent of pharmacy income comes from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). That may be the average figure but it is quite clear that that is an average figure and there are many pharmacies, many of them small, for whom the income from the scheme represents a much higher proportion of their income and it is of great significance to them. Undoubtedly to some others earning less than that average figure it has less significance. Senator Giles also seemed to take great comfort from the fact that the advisory committee which the Government at last has set up is looking at the Government's offer to pharmacists made in May of this year. Compared with the Tribunal finding, the May offer may be slightly more attractive but that is not an attractive settlement and it is not a proper settlement. It is interesting to note that the Government has now set up an advisory or consultative committee. I say to the Senate: what a great pity it is that the Government did not think of doing that a long time ago; that it did not talk to those in the pharmacy industry about problems and about the situation and their claims.

In discussing these matters which we have before us today we should do so in light of the fact that pharmacies' incomes in this regard were cut last year by 12 per cent and this year by an extra 8 per cent. Pharmacists are one group in the community whose incomes have gone down quite dramatically. At the same time, the costs of running a pharmacy have escalated. Over the past five years the cost of goods that they purchase has gone up 100 per cent and the cost of labour has gone up by 90 per cent. The Government's claim that their income from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme has risen by 81 per cent is a tampering with the figures to get an attractive outcome rather than an accurate look at the actual costs of running a pharmacy and keeping it going. I believe that the average income over the last six years from the scheme has increased by 46 per cent, but average weekly earnings have gone up by 52 per cent; there have been consumer price index increases. The cost of drugs has gone up by 125 per cent, and that of qualified staff has risen by 90 per cent. The Government's claim as far as income is concerned is totally wrong.

The other aspect of the Tribunal decision of 28 August, which I have raised previously, is the question of the methodology used by the Tribunal. I raised the matter in the Senate on 5 September when I moved a motion requiring the Government to obtain from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, and table in the Senate, a full statement of the methodology employed and the details of the information it used, but the Government declined to do that. It implied that it was not in a position to require the Tribunal to provide such details. I think that that is somewhat of a joke. The Government is becoming very coy about it, and in the light of statements that we all remember vividly of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in relation to the Government's relationship with the Reserve Bank of Australia-that is only one example-we know that the Government is in a position to say to the Tribunal, `This information ought to be supplied and ought to be made public'. There is little doubt that the Tribunal would comply with such a request, or hint even, from the Government. After all, the Tribunal has leant very heavily on the Government's own submission to it in relation to this matter and that is why we have this final outcome. In my opinion, it does not rest easily with the Government to say that it cannot require the Tribunal to provide the details.

We are then left with the situation of looking at the report and drawing our own conclusions as to the methodology that was used. I will refer to a very few passages by way of illustration. Paragraph 2 of the report states:
The decisions reached are the result of a considered judgement of the available material, all of which has been given appropriate weight and used with due caution.
Whatever those expressions might mean. The report continues:
The result has not been reached by a series of arithmetical calculations without regard to the consequences which are likely to follow.
I interpose and say that that obviously is not the case. It is now clear that many of the consequences have not been perceived and foreseen. Paragraph 2 continues:

Rather, the final conclusion is the result of balancing the findings of the studies and the available material on the cost of dispensing pharmaceutical drugs under the National Health Scheme on the one hand and a proper consideration of the likely effects of the adoption of these findings on the operation of the current pharmaceutical benefits scheme on the other.

Is it any wonder from that language that pharmacists say, `Hey, come on, let's know the real methodology that was used in coming to this conclusion'. I refer to section 13, entitled `Fee Determined', and invite honourable senators to read paragraphs 13.6, 13.7 and 13.8 and, further on, paragraphs 13.10 and 13.12. Paragraph 13.6 states:

The Tribunal has not determined this level of fee as a result of a simple arithmetical exercise but has made a judgement based on the evidence in its totality and after having regard to all of the submissions which were made by each of the principal parties . . .
I remind honourable senators that one of those parties was the Government, which wanted the reduction which finally came about. Paragraph 13.7 states:
The total fee will be constituted by the two elements . . .
This was referred to, firstly, in paragraph 13.8, which states:

The first element in the new base fee will be an amount of $2.45 which is to cover the cost of labour in supplying an item covered by the NHS. This amount contains a factor for each of the various labour costs . . .
Paragraph 13.10 states:
The second element in the new fee will be concerned with non labour costs and has been fixed at $1.05 per item dispensed.
Paragraph 13.12 states:
The Tribunal has estimated the average remuneration per prescription . . .
Is it any wonder that pharmacists want to know more about how this came about.

I now refer to the cost of labour. We get a little bit of help on page 10. In paragraph 3.6, under the heading `Cost of Dispensing per Prescription' there is the amount of $15 for the proprietor's salary. I find that absolutely remarkable. Pharmacists can certainly earn a great deal more as pharmacists in the Public Service than at that rate per hour which is the figure used by this Tribunal in coming to a conclusion. Again, pharmacists are entitled to know why that figure was chosen as the relevant figure. The $15 referred to is about the middle of the range salary for a government pharmacist, and it is certainly less per hour than many tradespeople receive.

The Tribunal's decisions have, in the past, been reviewed. This has been referred to today and I shall refer to it again because I believe that it is significant. In June the Federal Court rejected the Tribunal decision to cut pharmacists' professional fee by 10c per script. The court said at the time that the Tribunal decision was `so unreasonable that no reasonable person would have so exercised the power' and that `it was difficult to see how at a time of general inflation the amount of the professional fee should be reduced'. It is absurd to say that there should be no criticism of the Tribunal's findings or that they cannot be rejected.

I believe that the livelihood of many pharmacists is threatened and they are entitled to know the basis of the decision. This group in the community has already been squeezed financially. We have heard today that most will not be able to afford the expensive items and patients may have to wait many days before they are able to obtain drugs that have been prescribed for them. It is interesting to note, though, that in spite of the Government saying that the Tribunal decision cannot be changed, there is an article in today's Canberra Times headed, `Government move to pacify pharmacists'. It is encouraging at least to know that the Government recognises what it has done to the pharmacists. The article states:
The Government moved yesterday to encourage pharmacists to keep stocking high-cost drugs by setting a fixed surcharge on drugs costing more than $45.

Many drugs cost $45 and more; many cost less than that. So the pharmacist is still being required to stock those drugs at his own expense-he is paying the interest on his overdraft to have drugs on his shelf for this purpose. At least this will be changed for drugs costing more than $45. I take that as a recognition of the fact that it was wrong of the Tribunal not to include in its finding a fee for the cost of the drugs being purchased by the pharmacists in advance so that they are available when required.

In future pharmacists will have much less time to give advice to people who come into the shop on little matters and to give comfort and encouragement, perhaps, to some who are ill, are taking drugs, or who do not quite know what to do. I believe that that is a valuable part of what a pharmacy provides. I do not see a pharmacy merely as a place where a customer puts a prescription in a slot in one spot and then stands at another spot and waits for the pills to pop out. There is much more to the relationship between customers, patients, and the pharmacist when they go into a pharmacy. It is a pity that that is being overlooked completely.

There is talk that the Government wants more closures. That is an interesting matter. The Government seems almost to be laying the blame on the fact that there are too many pharmacies. The Tribunal report also refers to that in paragraph 12.9 on page 19, which states:
The structure of pharmacies, particularly their size and location, is a matter which should be considered by an appropriately designed inquiry and we recommend that this be undertaken.

I wonder where the Government gets its information that causes it to say, `There are too many pharmacies. That is the real problem. There should be closures'. It even offers a paltry $50,000 to some pharmacists if they are prepared to walk away from their livelihood. The Government should tell us how it has come to that conclusion when, as recently as 28 August, the Tribunal said that it is a matter that ought to be looked into. It is not really the number of scripts that determines the viability; the number of scripts will be much the same. There is much more to it than that. There are high costs in the medical system. There will be even higher costs if people are forced to go to doctors and hospitals instead of being able to talk to their pharmacists first.

I remind the Senate again that the cost of one bed day in a hospital equals the yearly prescription bill of eight people. Surely, anything that keeps down the cost of hospitals and the occupation of beds ought to be looked at and is the first line of health care. There is the question of the loss of pharmacies in the country which service the needs of those living in isolated areas. Those people are entitled to expect to receive those vital services. I believe that this decision discriminates against low income earners and pensioners by the lack of convenience and the additional expense of travelling, maybe only to the next suburb, in getting a prescription filled.

The real cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is affected by a number of things. The Government, I believe, is going the wrong way about trying to find the solution. It relates to the number of scripts which are written. It relates to the age of the population-and we are an ageing population. It relates to the expansion of the number of concessions that are provided for users as against those who are not receiving the concessions. It relates to the growth of the population and it most certainly relates to the new and sometimes very costly drugs which are now available.

The Government is taking a very short term view of what it is trying to do. Prompted by the failure of Medicare to cover the cost of health services, it is attempting to wind back costs by cutting into the pharmacy services. There have been cutbacks, and these have been referred to. In 1987 a limit was put on the number of visits to consultant physicians for which Medicare would pay. In 1988 the Government halved the number of items for which pathology benefits would be paid, including the removal of sun spots. We had the authority only listing issue and the generic drugs issue. Presumably, we have not heard the last of it. We know all about the number of people who have to wait a long time for hospital care and about the poor relationship between the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and the doctors. We have had many problems in Canberra with health care. I shall not go through them again, but until we attained self-government a few months ago, health care in Canberra was totally a matter of the way Medicare functioned. We in Canberra have seen very clearly how it has failed while at the same time the Medicare levy has increased from one per cent of taxable income to 1.25 per cent. We all know that Medicare costs a great deal more than that.

I think the Government has begun to realise that its own submission in requiring a reduction of income has been wrong. I have referred to the one concession it has made. One newspaper article is headed `Government gives country chemists a break'. It refers to what is now being done to assist those who live 10 kilometres from an approved pharmacy and to a special allowance, et cetera. The only disappointing part of that article is that it refers to a `Government subsidy'. I do not believe it is helpful to the debate for it to be referred to in that way. I do not believe that it is accurate. Last week the Minister announced an isolated allowance worth about $4,000 a year to pharmacists in far-flung areas. It is very clear that the Tribunal's finding does not meet the needs of pharmacies or those whom they are servicing.

Senator Giles at least has joined in and contributed to the debate. She is the only member of the Government who has. I hope that when the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health (Senator Cook) comes in he will deal with the issues more fully and answer some of the questions that have been put. In the light of the facts which exist, the questions which the pharmacists are asking ought to be dealt with by the Minister. I refer to them in the words in which the pharmacists themselves have put them: that the gross margin be restored to the 1988 level in real terms, adjusted for increases in costs; that a mark-up separate from the dispensing fee be restored and the impact of wholesaler surcharges dealt with; that professional services be recognised and rewarded; that there be regular updating of the dispensing fee according to appropriate indices, with no offsets for the impact of mark-up; and that essential pharmacies be given special assistance to maintain viability. The last point has been looked at, at least in part, in relation to some of the remote pharmacies. The Minister owes it to the Senate to deal with these matters when he speaks in this debate today. I support the amendment which the Opposition has moved. I believe it is important that it be passed by the Parliament and that the matter be looked at afresh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health Amendment Bill 1989 is piffling. The Government should be aware that if it has generated this amount of heat in the Senate there is a bushfire raging outside in the electorate. The Bill itself is not designed to increase pharmacists' income at all. All it does is put the patient contribution up from $11 to $12. All that money goes to the Government; it does not go to the pharmacists. It is a new tax on the sick. It is a sick tax. It is a tax on the halt, the lame and the blind. People who need medication are being taxed more. Not only that, the Bill indexes the tax so that it goes up surreptitiously as time goes on, I presume in accordance with the consumer price index. It goes up according to a formula that nobody understands very well. It will increase the tax on the sick for their pharmaceuticals. It does not increase at all the remuneration of chemists. It is the chemists' remuneration that is causing the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Over recent years the Government has been trying to reduce the cost of its pharmaceutical benefits scheme and no-one can blame it for that. It has promised the best, fairest and most equitable health system in the world and it is attempting to deliver it but, of course, it cannot deliver that sort of a scheme when it has created an unlimited demand for its services and when it has only a limited budget from which to satisfy that demand. It has to either increase the health budget or decrease the services. This is what it is doing. It has been doing it for years. The target it has picked this time is the chemists' remuneration. If we have a wages system in the country and we want to start a revolution, the easiest way to do it is to reduce people's incomes. The Government has been reducing the incomes of the pharmacists recently. If the Government is going to run the fairest, best and most equitable health system in the world, on top of everything else it needs a network of pharmacies and pharmacists who are happy and busy in delivering pharmaceuticals to the people. Under the guise of rationalising the system it is rationing the system. The Government has announced that it wants to see fewer pharmacies and better services. It wants to decide, by financial incentives, where people will have their pharmacies.

This sort of caper, this social engineering, is just not on when it comes to the delivery of pharmaceutical services. For example, the first pharmacies that will be hit by a reduction in their incomes will be those in poor economic areas. They might be busy pharmacies but because they are in an area that is supplying pharmaceuticals to, say, many pensioners they are marginally economic. The same applies to pharmacies in the country. They may be marginally economic but they are providing a reasonable and good service. The pharmacists providing that service have been happy enough with the remuneration they are getting, but they are not happy with what is happening now. For the Government to use such terms as greedy, money hungry, money grubbing pharmacists reminds me of the argument it used against the doctors. I will take that up when the sitting resumes.

—I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It refers to the current situation in Chile. Has the Government been approached by Chilean or international human rights groups seeking Australian observers during the 14 December elections? If so, what has been the Government's response to such approaches? Would the Government consider sending observers if such approaches were made?

—The Government has not been approached directly on this question. However, the International Parliamentary Assembly for Democracy in Chile, which is a Chilean non-governmental organisation supporting the return of democracy, has written to the Speaker of the Australian Parliament inviting Australian members to observe the presidential and congressional elections which are to be held in Chile on 14 December. The Australian Government believes that the forthcoming elections in that country are a crucial step in Chile's return to democracy-a process which Australia has strongly and consistently supported. I have therefore advised the Speaker and Mr President that the Government does see value in members of the Australian Parliament accepting invitations to act as observers at the 14 December elections. Questions about decisions to attend, who should go, the necessary travel arrangements and who should pay for it will, of course, be a matter for you, Mr President, and the Speaker to resolve in conjunction with the members so interested.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Has the Minister been made aware of the recent Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee statistics showing that there have been reductions in higher degree enrolments of nearly 7 per cent in the field of science and nearly 4 per cent in the field of engineering? Given that the Government has classified these two fields as areas of national priority, what measures is the Government considering to address this situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The relevant table shows that there has been a fall in higher degree enrolments in those two faculties. It also shows that there has been an increase, approaching 10 per cent in both cases, in enrolments for bachelor degrees in the same faculties. However, another couple of points have been drawn to my attention. Principally, the table on which Senator Macklin's question is based relates to universities only and, therefore, does not include institutions in the former advanced education sector, which accounted for almost 20 per cent of higher degree commencements in science and engineering in 1988.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the Department is not yet in a position to check in detail statistics collection data on commencing students provided by all institutions in their educational profiles, but it appears to show a rise of some 270 or 11 per cent in higher degree commencements in the fields of science and engineering-150 and 120 respectively in 1989-which suggests that there may be different patterns of growth between the former universities and colleges of advanced education. TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Justice to the widely publicised allegations that Australians are involved in mercenary activities in Colombia. Can the Minister inform the Senate of progress in the investigation of these allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only a fortnight or so ago I wrote to the then Minister for Justice of the Republic of Colombia, Mrs Monica De Greiff, who has since resigned, informing her of the support of the Australian Government for her efforts to combat the war declared on the legitimately elected Government in Colombia by the drug barons and war lords of that country. I said in that letter that I offered the fullest cooperation of our national agencies, especially the Australian Federal Police and the National Crime Authority. Imagine my shock and some shame as an Australian on being informed yesterday that allegedly certain Australians were prostituting themselves to those drug barons and war lords and making their military skills available for the training of the private armies of those drug barons, which are being used against the Government and the people of Colombia with the perpetration of a terrorist campaign of violence and intimidation against those people and that Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The Parliament itself has indicated its view of Australians going abroad to engage in this sort of activity by passing a law some 11 years ago which makes it an offence for Australians to engage in hostile activities or to train others to engage in hostile activities against the government of a foreign state. Honourable senators will recall that heavy penalties of 14 years and 10 years imprisonment were provided in relation to those offences. In so far as mercenary activity is concerned, payments made under the shamefully concocted contracts between those employing these mercenaries and the soldiers or terrorists involved would prima facie be available to be confiscated under the Proceeds of Crime Act-legislation also passed recently by this Parliament. So I believe that the Government and the Parliament of Australia have indicated their general policy in relation to the abhorrence in which we hold those Australians who go abroad and engage in this sort of mercenary activity.

Since being informed of this incident the Australian Federal Police, the Department of Defence and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have been engaged in following up the matters which are alleged to have occurred. Substantial progress has been made in identifying several Australians apparently involved in these mercenary operations and in locating them. That process of investigation is continuing, as I know honourable senators would wish it to do. It is intolerable that Australians should be involved in any collaborative effort working with the drug barons and the war lords, who are targeting Australia with their cocaine shipments. Of course, other Australians are aiding and abetting these drug barons and war lords-those Australians who, at some trendy party, engage in the snorting of cocaine. They are helping to finance, through the criminal syndicates that operate in Australia, by cash flow back to the barons, those very terrorist operations which they see reported on their television sets every night. I wish they would make the connection between what they see on their televisions and what they do when they go to their trendy parties later the same evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. When did the Minister first become aware of the threat by Eastman Kodak to close down parts of its Australian operations? What processes of expert analysis and review were undertaken by the Minister's Department, the Minister or his office which led to Cabinet deciding that financial support would be given to Kodak? Why was the issue of possible assistance to Kodak not examined by the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) or even by the Minister's own Bureau of Industry Economics?
—I am not sure of the precise date on which I became aware of the Kodak problem, if I can call it that.
—Your problem more than Kodak's.

—Do not let us get into people's personal problems or I will start on the honourable senator and go for a long time. It was about five days before the senior executives of Kodak here had been summoned to Rochester in the United States of America to consider with the executives in Rochester the essential closure of the Kodak plant here. I had a discussion with the Australian chief executive and other senior officers of Kodak about five days before that date. I think the date was 24 August; I am not sure.
—Before they went to the US.

—Before they went to the United States, yes, having had notice from the parent company about this issue. That is when I first saw Kodak executives about that. The honourable senator asks when the process was set in train before the Government's decision.
—What, not when.

—There has been a process of discussion and information exchange with Kodak and that process is still continuing. The honourable senator asked why I did not refer the matter to the IAC. It is simply because a decision about this matter could well have been made in the last week of August or the first week of September and the IAC process is not amenable to quick decisions of that kind. In so far as the Bureau of Industry Economics is concerned, that Bureau prepared an analysis for the Australian Manufacturing Council of relative productivity at Kodak and a variety of matters relating to its management style and so on which is now in the possession of the Government. That was prepared for the Manufacturing Outlook Conference which took place-Senator Lewis will remind me-I think a fortnight ago. That is what has taken place and is still going on.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In light of reports of renewed diplomatic efforts by Thailand to seek a solution to the Cambodia problem, can the Minister give an updated account of the current Australian approach to this issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australian policy is to work for a comprehensive solution to the Cambodian problem-in fact, any kind of solution which will stop the killing once and for all in that country. We are looking at a solution which would enable all Cambodians to participate in a process of national reconciliation and the reconstruction of their country. In common with member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations, the United Kingdom, Canada, France, the United States of America, India and other participants at the Paris conference, we have taken the view that the prospects for such a durable settlement to the Cambodian problem are better with the Khmer Rouge participating in at least a transitional solution, despite its appalling record, rather than continuing to operate as a guerilla force fighting a prolonged insurgency. It is a matter, on the one hand, of weighing the certainty of continued conflict with the Khmer Rouge if it is left out of any such settlement process against, on the other hand, the very strong possibility, at least, of being able to avoid further bloodshed if it can be brought within such process accompanied by safeguards, reassurances and mechanisms to ensure that it will not be able in the future to exercise the kind of evil influence that it has in the past.

ANSWER.PARA: There was agreement at the Paris conference among the Cambodian parties on the need for a new constitution for the country and the formation of a duly elected government following a transitional period. It was recognised that all factions ultimately would need to test their popularity at the polls. That much was agreed. As everyone knows, the stumbling block was the inability of those factions to reach accommodation among themselves on the sharing of power and the arrangements generally during the transitional period. The conference was suspended but the co-presidents, France and Indonesia, were empowered to begin consultations within six months with a view to reconvening the conference. I certainly hope that that may prove possible. We have always been concerned that failure to achieve agreement in Paris could lead to a continuation of the fighting in Cambodia. There are already reports of intensive fighting near the Cambodian town of Palin, close to the Thai-Cambodian border. That lends real urgency to efforts to achieve compromise among the factions and a comprehensive political settlement of the kind I have described, in particular, involving acceptable transitional arrangements and some international supervision, preferably under the United Nations, through an international control mechanism.

As I have said previously in this Parliament we will continue to support efforts which maintain pressure on all parties, both internal and external, which have the capacity to influence and bring about a comprehensive settlement. Prime Minister Chatichai of Thailand has held discussions in the last few days with leaders of the coalition Government of Democratic Cambodia and Hun Sen about a possible ceasefire. He is also exploring, as has been made public, the possibility of a technical mission being sent to Cambodia under United Nations auspices to explore the country's reconstruction needs. Our Embassy in Bangkok was informed of these proposals but was not involved in their preparation despite what some reports have said.

Australia supports all efforts to achieve a comprehensive political settlement and we certainly hope that Prime Minister Chatichai's efforts will facilitate that. Whether or not his specific proposals do lead to progress depends in the first instance on their acceptability to all Cambodian factions. Regrettably, at the moment that does not seem very likely. I will keep the Senate informed from time to time of further developments on this matter. I hope that next week at the United Nations I will have the opportunity to have a large number of conversations with other involved foreign Ministers in the hope that we can begin to see some daylight in what at the moment is proving to be a distressingly intractable situation.

—Is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware of a hunger strike currently being held outside the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet by Mr John Berechet and a number of other Romanians? Can the Minister tell the Senate whether their protests have any merit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Berechet, of the Australian Romanian Human Rights Society, is pretty well known to my Department. He has made prolific representations over the years, has been an organiser of several hunger strikes and protests of different kinds and occasionally has made threats of self-immolation by himself or persons whom he represents. Mr Berechet has announced his hunger strike and that of others by putting very detailed file numbers in a press release, which I would have thought would probably be a breach of the Privacy Act. His current campaign revolves around a view that my Department has refused to grant entry visas to their relatives in Romania.

ANSWER.PARA: In response, let me give some examples, without mentioning any names, of the merits of the cases. A number of the applicants were rejected simply because they failed the points test. Mr Berechet seems to think that there is some automatic right of these people to come to Australia without the need to meet normal requirements that apply to everyone else. Other cases are still under consideration by my Department, either awaiting a primary decision or, in some cases, until the appeals are resolved. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Budget decision to bring forward the collection of company tax. Has the Minister noted the article by Mr Ross Gittins in Monday's Sydney Morning Herald in which Mr Gittins describes the decision as looking innocent but pernicious to bring forward the collection of company tax and suggests the measure was dreamt up in the Treasurer's office as `a little gimmick to plug a hole in the Budget'-that is, to help Mr Keating come up with a bigger surplus? Does the Minister disagree with the assessment quoted by Mr Gittins that in the calendar year 1990 there will be a $2 billion increase in company tax, equivalent to a one-off surcharge, taking the company tax rate back to 47c? In view of the continuing and well-founded opposition to the decision from the business community and the accountancy profession which, unlike the Government, can understand the practical and financial burdens which will flow from this decision, I further ask the Minister: What did the Treasurer mean last week when he talked about possible changes to the decision as it affects smaller companies? How does the Government intend to define smaller companies? Is the Government prepared to reconsider the decision for all companies because, as Mr Gittins points out, this measure will impose an additional severe squeeze on company cash flows at a time when the economy will be slowing under the Government's high interest rates policy?

—First of all, let me make the historical point that company profits and tax flows have been better than they have ever been-certainly better than they ever were under the Fraser Government-so let us get that straight right from the beginning. I have read the article by Ross Gittins and I am no more capable than he is of placing that interpretation on the changes to the company tax regime that were announced in the Budget. In terms of the intrinsic merit of the decision, we are putting Australian companies in the same position as pay-as-you-earn taxpayers and provisional taxpayers. We are putting Australian company taxes in the same sort of environment with which international corporate taxpayers are confronted. Senator Watson is engaging in special pleading, as he has done all his life. He wants us to be internationally competitive except in the way corporations pay their taxes. That is his problem, not mine. As to the Treasurer saying that he would examine the matter, Senator Watson is as capable as I am of reading the transcript of the Treasurer's press conference.
—You are supposed to be closer to him.

—I thank Senator Chaney; I always have him as a coach here. The shadow Minister is advising me from the ice plateau that he inhabits, remote from everything. The fact is that the Treasurer has said that the issue is being re-examined. Senator Watson asked me what criteria are being used for that re-examination and so on. I repeat only what the Treasurer said. The issue in respect of small and medium sized companies is being re-examined. When that re-examination is complete, if Senator Watson can possess his soul in patience for a little while longer, he will find out the results of the re-examination.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and is consequent upon the official opening of the enormous North West Shelf gas project by the Prime Minister last week. Has this project actually been in operation, shipping liquefied natural gas (LNG) to Japan, ahead of the official launch? Can the Minister inform honourable senators of any projections that have been made of the potential of the North West Shelf project for the economies of both Western Australia and Australia as a whole?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was pleased to accompany the Prime Minister on Tuesday of last week at the official opening of the export phase of the North West Shelf gas project in Perth. It is regrettable that, because of the pilots strike, the ceremonial opening did not occur in the Pilbara where it was scheduled to take place. Nevertheless, the opening was attended by representatives of the Australian joint venture partners, the present and past Premiers of Western Australia and the Japanese utility customers in the power industry and the gas industry. It was a significant event in the history of energy trade in Australia. Overall, the North West Shelf project is worth $12 billion. It is the biggest single project of its kind ever undertaken in Australia and is arguably the biggest single project of its kind in the world. Ahead of schedule, it commenced exports of liquefied natural gas to Japan; some two months earlier than previously targeted. The project came in under budget, which is a significant achievement for the project managers, the engineers employed and the workers engaged in its construction and development.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the 20-year export phase of its life the project will earn $41 billion in revenue in 1989 dollar terms. Its exports are valued at between $1.5 and $1.8 billion a year in 1986 dollars. The joint venture partners will pay $10 billion in royalties and company tax, split on a 25:75 basis between royalties and company tax. The Government will also receive revenue from customs duties and taxes derived from project employment. As at June 1989 a total of $6.182 billion has been committed to the project, of which 74 per cent was Australian content. The joint venture partners for phase two have restructured so that each has a one-sixth share. The Australian participation is 27 per cent.

All associated with the development of this project deserve the commendation of the Australian people. It heralds for us two quite outstandingly important issues. The first is that, because of this development, Australian engineering competence and major resource development project expertise is recognised as being of world class and, indeed, outstandingly so. For Australian project tenderers to major resource developments overseas and in this country, the North West Shelf is a symbol of what Australians can do in major resource development and by any terms is a massive tribute to them.

The second element that is vitally important is that the Japanese have signed long term 20-year contracts to consume LNG exported from the North West Shelf. There are precious small reservoirs for stockpiling of gas at the wharf in Tokyo. Thus, in signing a long term contract, the Japanese wanted to be absolutely certain of reliability of supply. Those LNG vessels have to appear in silhouette over the horizon of Tokyo Bay with a regularity that has the precision of a Swiss watch. The fact that the Japanese, as consumers, see in Australia an ability to deliver that reliability is a tribute to Australia in the sense that our major export market recognises Australia as a reliable source of supply of a key energy input, essential in terms of its regularity for day to day energy demand in Japan. In terms of our other resources exported out of this country, that is a significant tribute to the Australian work force, to the Australian resource managers and to Australian exporters. It is a powerful argument for Australia to win a greater share of these significant markets overseas for resources and for other elements of our trade exports.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Does the Minister agree that the Government has the power to cancel the two-airline agreement because of the failure of the airlines to provide regular scheduled services on the main trunk routes? Does the Minister also agree that the Government has the power under the two-airline agreement to allow other operators to fly services on the trunk routes which are obviously not now being serviced by Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines? If the Government does have these powers, will it take action to permit the entry of other parties to restore air services to something approaching normality?

—As I recall, there is a provision in the two-airline agreement enabling its cancellation in the event of failure by the airlines to fly regular trunk routes, as Senator Durack has said. I would be very surprised indeed-without offering a legal opinion off the cuff, which I am not entitled to do in this place anyway-if that kind of provision were applicable in a circumstance like this, which it is manifestly beyond the capacity of the airlines to influence, given the resignation of their pilots and their obvious inability at the moment to provide more than 50 per cent of the services that they normally provide. The threshold to the question has its own answer in that respect. If there is anything the Minister wants to add, I will supply such information. If the threshold fails, the rest of the question is inapplicable. Certainly, the entry of other parties into the Australian airline system is contemplated in the context of deregulation next year. Whether it would be possible for anyone to get into the market in the present circumstances, with the time leads and lags that are involved, is of course another practical question. On any view, the dispute is likely to be sorted out before it would be possible for some new operator to make any significant difference to the number of aircraft that are flying. Again, I will seek a further comment from the Minister if he wants to add something to what I have said.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does Senator Cook have total faith in any wildlife studies conducted by the New South Wales Forestry Commission?

The reply that I have reported to the Senate is the reply that the New South Wales Forestry Commission gave. TALK.START.PARA: —Developers can approach the Hawke Government with complete confidence in its processes. Perhaps the greatest feature of the Government in the last seven years is that it has presided over phenomenal employment growth while being commended by the World Heritage Bureau as having had the greatest commitment to the World Heritage Convention.

—Has the Minister for Resources seen reports of concern amongst pig producers about the Government's decision to permit the import of pig meat from Canada? Is there any real basis to the anxieties that have given rise to this opposition? Has the Government taken the fullest possible advantage of all relevant expertise before reaching its decision? Can the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will take all necessary steps to prevent the possibility of imported Canadian pig meat endangering our domestic pig population, including those opposite? What is the Minister's response to various pig meat industry spokesmen's criticism on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that I should comment on the reference to the honourable senators opposite, but I do note that no-one has raised an objection, so they must accept the reference that Senator Burns made. There have been some reports in the paper about representatives of the pig industry--
—How long ago?

—Just recently. Senator Walters may not read the rural press, but then I guess that she is ignorant on a lot of other fronts as well. There have been reports in the press recently concerning industry anxieties about the import of uncooked Canadian pig meat. The decision made by the Government to not obstruct the importation of uncooked Canadian pig meat on health grounds was made after extensive triallings by the Australian Animal Health Laboratory, in which it trialled the possibility of the transmission of the disease transmissible gastroenteritis in pig meat, and after five years of consultation with the industry and various scientists associated with veterinary disease. In addition, I am advised that a scientific study team has concluded that there is a one in 3.3 million possibility that there may be a transmissible gastroenteritis transmitted by the importation of uncooked Canadian pig meat. Indeed, some industry spokesmen have alleged that that is not a reasonable representation of the odds and that in fact the possibility is one in 15,500. On that basis, I have asked the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to investigate that second claim. They tell me that it is not valid and that the one in 3.3 million possibility is the proper ratio of risk. Even if it were one in 15,500, that would be according to their precepts of acceptable risk, within the terms of that acceptability.

ANSWER.PARA: There is here an important question for Australia. We are the only country in the world that has had a barrier to the importation of uncooked Canadian pig meat on health grounds. Since we have conducted the trial and consulted with the industry, there is no reason why we should maintain that barrier. If we were to, we would be doing so artificially, and thus be in breach of our General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) responsibilities because we would be putting in place an artificial barrier to trade which is contradictory to our free trade stance in the world.

On the 11th of this month Bruce Lloyd, the shadow spokesman for primary industry, alleged that if Australian herds of pigs contracted transmissible gastroenteritis, up to 90 per cent of suckling pigs would die in less than three weeks. We say that that is just rubbish. We stand by the one in 3.3 million prospect. We also say that there is very little chance, if any, of the mixing of herds. Indeed, if an infection did break out, the area would be quarantined immediately, the pigs involved slaughtered and the piggery disinfected.

There is some sort of very insipid background campaign to beat up the issues in this area of trade. Given our GATT responsibilities and the acceptable level of risk that has now been determined, there is no--

TALK.START.PARA: —But you admit there is a risk though?
—There is an acceptable risk-a one in 3.3 million risk.
—But that is a risk.
