QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AIRLINE PILOTS DISPUTE: OVERSEAS PILOT QUALIFICATIONS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Archer asked me a question about pilot qualifications in the context of the present dispute. I am now able to give a further supplementary answer from the Minister for Transport and Communications. Advice from the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) is that the various claims that the Authority is relaxing normal requirements for foreign pilots are not true. Where pilots are obliged to sit examinations of any kind, the only essential requirement is that the examinations be successfully passed. The setting of minimum periods at which unsuccessful candidates may resit examinations is an administrative provision aimed at encouraging candidates to prepare themselves adequately for examination. Provision that the specified minimum periods could be varied if circumstances warranted was introduced and notified to the aviation industry in February 1989. The CAA is therefore in this respect applying provisions that were widely notified months before the present pilots dispute arose.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of the number of hours required to be flown before pilots can be approved to operate on Australian registered aircraft, the CAA has advised that the essential requirement is that a competent and approved person be satisfied as to the competence of a pilot before he is approved to operate an aircraft. That is the criterion. The normal role of the CAA is to exercise surveillance over the adequacy of an operator's training and to act as a checking organisation. This role is being maintained. In addition, appropriately qualified CAA officers may independently certify the competence of a pilot to perform a particular flying role.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator MacGibbon proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The personal suffering and financial hardship inflicted on tens of thousands of Australians, particularly those living in more remote parts of the country, by the government's gross mismanagement of the airline pilots' dispute.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 September, only seven days ago, the Sydney Morning Herald reported that the Chairman of the Japan Association of Travel Agents, Mr Manabu Kanematsu, at a luncheon which was attended by the Managing Director of the Australian Tourist Commission and senior executives of all of Japan's major travel companies, said that the pilots strike in Australia ranked with the killings in China's Tiananmen Square and the Chernobyl nuclear accident in the Soviet Union in 1986 in its ability to deter tourists. That is a striking statement, but it does not understate the importance to Australia of the current airline pilots strike. The Australian Tourist Commission has estimated that as a consequence of this strike we will have a 40 per cent fall in Japanese tourists in the next year. Japan is Australia's second biggest and its fastest growing source of tourists. These are extraordinarily serious consequences of the strike. We in this country become inured to strikes because we are brought up in the Labor culture, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) culture, that we can strike whenever we like for as long as we like. I believe we have become blase about the present airline pilots strike and we have lost perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to put two points before the Senate. The first is that by Australian standards it is now a very long strike. We are into our sixth week. The second point is the more important one. It is probably the most devastating strike this country has ever suffered in economic terms. The consequences of the strike will be with us for years. The national interest demands that we have an immediate resolution to this problem. This country is not so extraordinarily wealthy that it can go on with this sort of political and economic nonsense. The country is actually bankrupt.

The strike had its origins in an inappropriate centralised wage fixing system that has failed-the accord. The Government, by its own admission, had knowledge that this strike was coming. It did nothing about it. It did nothing to pre-empt it. It had no contingency plan for when the strike arose. When it started all the Government did was dump fuel on the fire and guarantee that it got out of hand completely. The ego of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) overcame his limited powers of judgment. The Prime Minister was looking for a quick dramatic fix: kill the pilots off; knock the strike over; go to a snap poll and avoid the consequences of the economic morass that he has got this country into. All he has done is prolong the strike, particularly with his means of paying compensation and the prohibition that there will be no negotiation outside the 6 per cent wage guidelines, despite the fact that the Government knows very well that the pilots are being offered by both Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines more than the 29 per cent increase the pilots are asking for. We have no policy from this Government other than the seige mentality that is comparable to that of the generals in the First World War. The Prime Minister is prepared to fight to the last drop of Australia's economic blood on this issue. He just will not give in. He will not negotiate. The Labor Party is quite incapable of running a modern complex industrial society, with the inevitable interdependence between the members of that society. In the process it is sending this country absolutely bankrupt.

The consequences of this strike are being felt today at a personal level by the families and many small businesses that support the tourist industry in Australia. It is true that the big companies are suffering. Unlike the airline employees and the airline companies, people involved in the tourist industry are getting no compensation at all. Remember that they are paying historically the highest interest rates that this country has ever seen-again another consequence of the economic policy of this Government.

Tourism is very important to Australia. Last year, at $6.5 billion, it became our single biggest export industry, eclipsing coal at $6 billion. It has an aggregate turnover within the country of about $26 billion. It is our biggest foreign exchange earner and our biggest employer outside the Public Service, with over 480,000 employees, many of them youths and women. Last year we attracted to this country over 2.2 million overseas visitors. Some 628,000 of those come from Oceania, mainly from New Zealand, and 660,000 from Asia, mainly Japan. Every one of those Japanese tourists that comes to Australia is here for six days on average and spends between $3,700 and $5,000 while here-nearly $1,000 a day. We had 404,000 tourists from North America and 529,000 from Europe, mainly from the United Kingdom.

As the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, has said repeatedly in his press releases this year, tourism is Australia's fastest growing industry, employing 6 per cent of the work force and generating about $25.5 billion of our gross domestic product (GDP). In one press release Senator Richardson said that every overseas tourist coming to Australia is worth as much as six tonnes of sugar, 10 tonnes of wheat, 27 tonnes of coal or 64 tonnes of iron ore.

In the recent past the Australian tourism industry has made a huge investment. It is a new industry on the scale on which it is practised today in Australia. But that investment has been made at today's prices and at today's interest payments. We are suffering devastating publicity on a worldwide basis because of the inability of the Government to overcome this strike. The projections of the Australian Tourist Commission are that we will be down one million tourists next year and $3 billion in the next decade as a consequence of the Government's inability to cope with the strike. Tourists who come here from overseas must have predictability in their travel arrangements. They must know that if they come to Australia for 10 or 14 days they can get on a plane at the end of that time and get back to their place of employment in Europe, North America or Japan. They cannot be held hostage. If they do not get back they lose their jobs. If they do not lose their jobs they know that their budgets blow out.

A consequence of the present strike is that the package tour operators in North America, Japan and Europe, who work 12 to 18 months ahead, are just writing Australia right out of their programs. They are a very significant part of the Australian overseas tourist trade. When this strike ends, as it must, the costs to Australia will be enormous. We will need time to recover. We will have to demonstrate our performance as a safe market for people to come to and not get stranded and we will have to spend massive amounts of money in overseas advertising-and this at a time when the Government is busy running down its advertising budget overseas.

It will be very interesting in this debate to see how the Labor Party handles the schism within its ranks over the airlines strike. In the last week we have seen the great split between the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, (Mr Holding). In my files I have many extracts from the papers. There is one from the Sydney Morning Herald which says:
Keating disputes tourism's ruin.
It goes on:
The pilots' dispute will cost the tourism industry $250 million in lost revenue from international visitors alone in the run-up to Christmas, the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) claimed . . .
But the Treasurer-he always knows best-Mr Keating, was sceptical of the industry's warnings of impending ruin. Another article said:
Pilots not damaging tourism yet-Keating.
Another article said:
Keating claims tourism not hurting yet.
The Australian Financial Review of 22 September said:
Keating questions harm.
What was the response from the industry? `Tourism rage at slap-down from Keating.' ` ``Keating wrong'', says fellow Minister, Mr Holding'. `Pilots: Labor left splits with PM'. And on it goes.

It is not surprising that Mr Keating does not understand the consequences of the strike because he does not understand the economy of this country. He has moved us from a debt position of $33 billion 6 1/2 years ago, when he assumed responsibility for the Treasury, to a debt of $125 billion with the huge balance of payments deficits that we have. Why, only last week we had a record deficit of $2.5 billion. Mr Keating tells us that this is the price of success! God knows what the price of failure would be if a debt position of nearly $130 billion at the ministration of Mr Keating is success. So it is not surprising that he gets the tourism equation wrong and cannot work out what is happening out there in the marketplace. The best vocation for Mr Keating would be selling real gold watches to tourists and travellers on the streets of Sydney, which he could do with great persuasion and conviction. But he certainly cannot run this country.

Let us get back to this country and the costs of the strike at the present time. The immediate costs are being borne, as I said before, by many small individuals. Everyone would have heard the broadcasts this morning of the protest meeting in Cairns. Cairns is one of the focal points of new developments in tourism in Australia. My advice there is that in the recent past car rentals have been down by 60 per cent in their peak season. The central business district is reporting drops in trading of 40 per cent to 80 per cent. Airport shops are down to 75 per cent of their normal figure and the accommodation occupancy rates are running as low as 10 per cent. The greatest effect of this strike, of course, is in the outlying States. The effect is greatest in Queensland but it is also very significant in Tasmania and Western Australia. I will leave it to my colleagues to go into that in more detail later on. In passing, I comment that for my own State the cost of the strike so far is estimated to be around $90m to $100m.

How did we get into the position that we are in today? We got there because the Government bungled the whole thing. We are in very, very serious trouble. The only way we will fix the trouble is by allowing the airline management and the pilots to talk together. The Government, as I said before, knew the strike was planned months and months ago, and did nothing to pre-empt it. There was no contingency plan. When the strike started all we had were the irrational and intemperate displays of abuse from the Prime Minister at the pilots because they withdrew their labour. That right to withdraw labour is always very dear to the Labor Party. The Prime Minister could not get into this fight fast enough. He had no need to enter it at all but he upped the ante, went in and put his neck on the line. Again I have many cuttings from my files. The Canberra Times on 14 September said:
Hawke's air emergency.
On 14 September the Sydney Morning Herald said:
Pilots: PM puts job on the line.
On 14 September the Australian said:
PM risks all for total victory over the pilots.
On 14 September the Age said:
Hawke puts authority on the line over pilots.
The Age also said:
PM declares an air `emergency'.
On it goes. On 9 September the Age said:
Hawke bashes the pilots for the sake of other unions.

These are not the actions of a reasonable, responsible man. There is now very great community concern in Australia at the actions and judgment of the Prime Minister. There is great concern about his emotional stability. Some very serious judgments are now being made about his ability to handle the job. He is exhibiting all the signs of serious cerebral neuronal impairment at the present time. His judgment is execrable. One example is his wish to compensate the airlines for the position they find themselves in, which is dictated by the ACTU saying there will be no stand-downs. Ansett is losing in excess of $10m a week. By my calculation it has lost around $50m to $60m. It wants to settle and reach agreement but the Prime Minister will not let it. Instead, we have this compensation scheme. No-one knows the details of the compensation-how it is to be paid or how it is to be audited. How can Sir Peter say that he deserves the money? I have been rung up in my office by parents of airline employees who are working as flight attendants. I have been told of the case of one family whose two daughters were stood down on 13 September. Presumably the Government will pay compensation to Ansett for those two daughters who should be working as flight attendants, but at the end of the day the agreement to pay compensation to the airlines only prolongs everything and is grossly unfair.

One of the striking features of the dispute has been the massive disinformation campaign run by the Prime Minister in concert with the airlines. Three weeks ago we heard stories of how the pilots union was collapsing, the strike would be over and the planes would be flying the next day-30 per cent the next week and 50 per cent by the end of the month. We are almost at the end of the month and there is a very long way to go before 50 per cent of aircraft will be flying. Returning to the files, in the Australian dated 9 September, Paul Kelly wrote the following article:
This week Bob Hawke was buoyant, ebullient, radiating confidence in the pilots dispute. He predicted the beginning of the end. Within a few days Hawke would be vindicated or embattled.

That was written nearly three weeks ago. We have also had propaganda from Sir Peter Abeles. I quote from a transcript of the Current Affair program broadcast on 14 September, nearly two weeks ago, in which Sir Peter said:
Next week you won't see just six or seven planes, you will see very rapidly us-whichever way it goes-to have half our fleet flying again much faster than I would have dared to say a week ago.

He said he would have half his fleet flying, and that should have taken place some while ago. He claimed that he had signed on 50 pilots. Very few pilots have signed on. No check or training captains, for example, have signed on. I am advised that those who have crossed the line are having such pangs of conscience that 50 per cent have taken sick leave. Clearly, from the traffic on the Australian air routes, the companies have made no progress in breaking the strike position of the pilots despite the massive amount of propaganda.

On the subject of propaganda I refer to the great disinformation campaign that has been waged about the number of stick hours that pilots put in. A figure of eight to 12 hours a week has been given. That has been obtained by taking every pilot in the companies and dividing the figure into the number of hours flown on the type of aircraft. The reason why that figure is so low is that both airlines are involved in massive re-equipment programs. For example, Ansett is training 100 pilots a year on its 737 fleet. That takes up six weeks of the pilots' time during which they do no productive flying at all. Ansett is training pilots on its A320 fleet as fast as it can, and the same applies to Australian Airlines. The disinformation campaign that has been waged has been absolutely striking.

Yesterday Senator Archer asked a question of Senator Evans relating to safety. He asked whether there had been changes to safety procedures, which required a yes or no answer. There have been changes to safety procedures as a consequence of Government pressure being brought to bear on the airlines. For example, Ansett did not have a training or check captain in one of its divisions. It has certified a captain in that role in breach of its flight manual. A flight manual is a document laid down by the company, approved by the Civil Aviation Authority, and it cannot be broken without approval. The Ansett flight manual provides that the validation of a new check captain requires three legs where he observes and three legs under supervision where he is checked by a check captain, the flight manager of the fleet and, finally, a CAA examiner of airmen. Ansett obtained certification for one of its captains by flying four non-revenue legs under the supervision of a CAA examiner of airmen. The net result might be the same, but the legal significance is that the law was broken. The consequence of this debasement of safety standards means that Australian travellers are seriously put at risk, despite what the Government says.

We then have the humbug relating to contracts. Both Ansett and Australian have offered contracts. I have here a copy of the Australian Airlines contract. It provides a base salary which is an increase on the present salary, and an increment whereby the annual salary is divided by one 660th per hour flown beyond a 55-hour figure. In actual fact, the working of that formula gives the pilots more-by about 15 per cent-than they are asking for. The Australian community is absolutely fed up with this strike. The airlines' management wants to settle. The pilots want to settle. The public wants the dispute settled. Australia is bleeding to death on this issue, yet we have the enormous ego of the brain-damaged Prime Minister, an ego which can be measured as costing Australia $3 billion--

SPEECH.PARA: However, in respect of the Northern Territory, as AAP notes, the loss so far is around $12m. I would say that is a low figure. One of the things that particularly concern me, and I am continually making representations about it to the Government, is the very low level of flights being maintained to isolated parts of Australia such as Darwin, which is currently running at only 15 per cent. It was caused by the totally intractable position of the Air Pilots Federation which it has not moderated by one degree. I refer to the Federation's public statements made only yesterday and again today in its negotiations with the companies.

The solution which the Opposition is suggesting is the simple-minded rhetoric that if the pilots simply sat down with the companies everything would be sorted out. That is precisely what caused this dispute. On day one the Pilots Federation wanted 29 per cent plus, it has not budged from that by one iota, and it repeated that demand yesterday and today.
