The Pilots Federation, crying crocodile tears, says that `it deeply regrets the damage done to the tourist industry, but this is beyond our control'. That is a lie. Not only was it not beyond the control of the Pilots Federation but the document that I tabled here in the Senate, the one that was issued to members of the Federation months before this dispute started, on how to handle a non-income period, indicated just how cold-bloodedly and callously the Federation planned this dispute to inflict the maximum possible damage from day one. It has not budged from that position for six weeks. This dispute will go down as being the most badly handled dispute by union leadership in this country's industrial history.

The terms of the matter of public importance talk about the Government's mismanagement. What is relevant in this debate this afternoon, and it should have been canvassed before, is the degree of mismanagement that has been applied to this dispute by the Air Pilots Federation. It will go down as being the worst handled dispute ever in this country's history. It has been handled in the most juvenile, unbelievable fashion by the leadership of the AFAP. I regret that the membership of the Air Pilots Federation has followed it like sheep. I regret it because I know quite a number of those pilots very well from the time they flew in the Northern Territory. I think they have been very badly advised. What Brian McCarthy has done for the airline pilots of this country is what Bruce Shepherd did for the doctors. I think Brian McCarthy has done a better job on the airline pilots than Bruce Shepherd did on the doctors.

It would have to be the first duty of a union-and I have been a trade unionist all my working life-to protect the jobs of its members. That would have to be the fundamental tenet that members can expect from a trade union. But what has this union done for its members? I will tell honourable senators what it has done. It has cost all of its members their jobs; it has cost all of its members their seniority; it has cost all of its members, who perhaps would have been laid off under the productivity increases which the airlines are not unreasonably wanting from their pilots, their redundancy payments; it has cost its members all of the conditions-and they were considerable conditions-built up over the last 30 years attached to those agreements. Importantly, it has also cost its members the support and the respect of the majority of their fellow Australians. That is a pretty severe price to pay.

I might also add in respect of the jobs that a significant number of the resignations that were handed in by pilots were presigned and undated. If any trade union that I belonged to came to me within one week of the dispute starting and said `Hand me an undated resignation from your job which we will hand in at our discretion' I would tell the union to go and jump in the creek. It is a pity that the Federation members have been led by the nose by these stupid-and they are stupid-tactics.

Legal people said, I noted in the press at the time, what a brilliant move this was legally. It may have been very clever legally in avoiding common law actions. Industrially it was stupid. It was the trump card of the Federation. Unfortunately, it also happened to be the last card of the Federation. There are not many people in this country, there are not many groups of workers, who are in the happy position of being able to resign from their jobs as a weapon during an industrial dispute-within a week of the dispute starting. Only the airline pilots could afford it. But it was a stupid thing to do industrially and they have continued to be stupid ever since.

I offer a piece of gratuitous advice to the Pilots Federation, and this is genuine advice-I am in the public relations business, like every single person in this chamber: if I were a member of that Federation I would be making sure that someone other than Brian McCarthy handled the public relations for me in terms of any future industrial action that I might be taking, because he has been a disaster. Brian `the sphinx' McCarthy. So many people are getting their backs up every time they see that wooden face on television saying, `29 per cent'. He has been saying it for six weeks. If he keeps on doing it I think that the Pilots Federation is going to have to either change its President or send him off for a very intensive course in public relations because he has been an absolute disaster.

A furphy has been put forward which I would like to address-Opposition members have got on to it in the last couple of days and they think it is cute-about strikebreaking by this Government, strikebreaking by the airlines. What a nonsense. Senator Stone first ran it and everyone had a good laugh. Senator Chaney ran it again yesterday and again today, I noted, in the Senate during Question Time. It is a nonsense. There is no strike. People have the hide to compare this dispute with Mudginberri. No-one is more familiar with Mudginberri than I am. It is not in the same street as Mudginberri. There is no strike. Why is there not a strike? There is not a strike because the airline pilots have resigned from their jobs.

I heard Senator MacGibbon saying what a tragedy it is that in this country people can go on strike whenever they like. It is called democracy, Senator. It is the greatest system of government in the world, with all its faults and failings. In exchange for that freedom, there are certain things one has to do within our system that provide limitations on free association and what one can tell individuals about whether they want to stay in work or not. If the airline pilots are stupid enough to hand in presigned, undated resignations to the Federation and say `There are our jobs, there is our seniority, there is our redundancy, there is everything that the Federation has worked for and built up in the last 30 years; it is out the window as far as we are concerned', then so be it. It is their right in this country to do it. No government can stop them from doing it and no government should have the power to stop them from doing it. If they are stupid enough to do it, then be it on their own heads.

But having said that, therefore there is no strike. What is happening now is that the Opposition once again is picking up the rhetoric of the Air Pilots Federation saying that there is a strike, because McCarthy says there is a strike. McCarthy put out a press statement last night in the most extreme and offensive language. Honourable senators opposite talk about offensive language. I will give them a bit in about five minutes from now from the President of the Air Pilots Federation to the President of the Industrial Relations Commission and they can tell me whether they think it is a sensible way to handle a dispute. I will incorporate the letter.

McCarthy says that the Government is using scab labour, that it is strikebreaking. What did the Federation say to the Industrial Relations Commission about that? I will tell honourable senators. In terms of hypocrisy and cant, the Federation is equalled only by members of the Opposition. I will quote from a transcript of the proceedings before the Industrial Relations Commission which I was going through to find out what the positions of the parties were. I found this little gem. It is from Wednesday, 30 August 1989. It is Mr Cox, representing the Air Pilots Federation. The representatives of the airline companies had been using the word `dispute' in relation to this matter, which I did not think was unreasonable. Not only were the airline pilots enraged about the use of the word `strike' but they could not even handle the use of the word `dispute'. This is what the Air Pilots Federation said in front of the Industrial Relations Commission in August. I quote from page 27:
I used the word problem. I deliberately do say not a dispute, because there has been no strike action taken by the federation at any time during the airline area . . .
He goes on to say:

I clearly mention that now because the word has been clearly used as dispute and I have to say the word dispute or its connotations has been that there has been a strike by airline pilots. There has not. And there continues not be a strike by airline pilots.

Talk about two bob each way! The President put out a statement yesterday saying that the Government is strikebreaking; the airlines are strikebreaking. Federation representatives stand up in front of the Industrial Relations Commission-in court-and twice say categorically that they are not on strike. They cannot have it both ways. But they continue to want to have it both ways, not just in respect of how they are handling this dispute, but also in respect of how they handle their own membership.

The Federation should have a talk to the 40 per cent of its membership who are not airline pilots, those pilots who fly for government entities in Australia and those pilots who fly for the general aviation sector in Australia. The Federation adopts a very interesting position in respect of them. They consider themselves to be the forgotten members of the Air Pilots Federation.

What is the Federation arguing? It is arguing that 40 per cent of its members should stay inside the system which it is pouring scorn on and over which it is bringing this country to its knees. It wants 40 per cent of its members to stay inside that system, because it benefits them, and it wants 60 per cent of its members to go outside the system. If the honourable senator wants any evidence of that, instead of simply believing the latest press release that Brian McCarthy puts out, which is what the honourable senator has been doing, he should read the facts. I commend to the honourable senator a reading of the transcript. This is what the representative of the domestic airlines said to the Commission in respect of this matter when it was heard on 30 August:

So the federation is using the processes of the commission seeking arbitration on matters, seeking increases consistent with the commission's wage-fixing principles in this area, taking the benefit of the system, in stark contrast to its attitude to both the commission and its wage-fixing principles-and I might say the public interest-in the domestic area.
He went on to say:

If the commission pleases, the federation cannot have it both ways. In my respectful submission it cannot take the benefits in this area and come to the commission saying, ``Everything is rosy, there is no disputation. In fact we are processing claims through the good offices of the commission.'' And on the other hand take the notorious stance which it is taking in the major dispute.

That is absolutely true. If the honourable senator reads this transcript, he will see that that is exactly what the Federation is saying. It went before the Commission and said, `We do not want to touch anything in the general aviation area that affects 40 per cent of our membership. There is no disputation. All the agreements are holding up. Everybody is doing wonderfully well in the central wage fixing system and before the Commission. We want those members to stay in the system and we want the other 60 per cent to go outside of it'. We cannot have that schizophrenic, stupid attitude responsibly put by a trade union and expect it to be taken seriously. But that is the position of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots which the Opposition is supporting so enthusiastically.
I could quote a lot more but for want of time I will finish with this quote. Mr Parry, who was also representing the airline industry at the same hearing, said:

The position would appear to be that the federation is quite happy to use the commission and the principles in the areas where it has little membership or strength. However, where the federation considered it had some strength it ignored the commission and also ignored the wage fixing system. The airlines that I represent do not consider it appropriate that the federation retains the benefits and protection of the award system under certain awards which are before the commission today when they are not prepared to process claims under certain other awards in accordance with wage fixing systems. Those other awards being the ones that were recently cancelled by a full bench of this commission.

Clearly the federation cannot have the best of both worlds. The position of the companies I represent is that they consider it an appropriate step for the commission to exercise its powers under section 113 and set aside all awards for which the federation are respondent. If the commission pleases, that is the position of the companies I represent.

That is not an unreasonable position. The reality is that the position adopted by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots in this dispute is totally unreasonable and totally untenable. As someone who is an expert in industrial relations said to me this morning when I showed him a certain document which I intend to incorporate, `Who in the bloody hell do these people think they are?'. It is a very good question.

I want to get on to a few things that have been said by Mr McCarthy and his friends in the Opposition about two matters: contracts which were just mentioned by Senator MacGibbon and yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney; and $100m. The President of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots continues to assert on the basis of no evidence whatsoever that $100m of taxpayers' money is being spent by the Government in assisting the airlines in this dispute. That is absolute nonsense. It may well be that if members of the Federation do not wake up to themselves and start behaving responsibly with a bit of consideration for the fact that they are Australians and that they have to exercise some consideration for their fellow Australians who have been devastated by this dispute-the Opposition is quite right about that-it will cost the Government $100m after the 28th of this month. If the Federation does not start showing some sense that it has been called upon to show by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, in here and before the press, it could cost $100m. It has not cost $100m or anything like it.

This morning I read cover to cover the contracts that are being offered by Ansett Airlines of Australia to the airline pilots. I did so because I was not prepared to come in here and say that Senator Chaney's assertions yesterday were false unless I knew that they were. Senator Chaney said yesterday that he had seen a contract and that it provides for a 40 per cent increase in salary on the existing working conditions of the pilots. He is either misleading the Senate or he should go back to law school and do a tutorial in contracts. I have read the contracts and I will tell honourable senators what they offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a contract there.

—You would not name the figure in the contract. I will tell you what they offer. They offer a modest-and I mean modest-increase in salary in exchange for significant increases in productivity. When I read the contracts I found it even more interesting-I hope that if Senator MacGibbon knows something about the airline industry and the history of the negotiations of this union going back to 1959, he will appreciate the significance of this-that they also incorporate very significant changes indeed to the conditions that the pilots are currently working under. The furphy that is continuing to be run by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and the Opposition that these contracts offer massive improvements, better than the airline pilots are asking for, is in fact a lie. It is not true. I have read the contract and I am satisfied that that is the case.
—You have no comprehension of it.
—You table it then, Senator.
—I have it here. I am quite happy to table it.
—Well, do so; table it.
—It shows about a 40 per cent rise.

—Rubbish! Read it, Senator. Do not blind yourself with the airline pilots' rhetoric. Read it. It does, in fact, offer modest increases in exchange for significant increases in productivity. I might add, particularly in relation to things like seniority, that I was fascinated at the changes which were proposed. I would like to conclude on a very sad note. This dispute had a bit of light at the end of the tunnel the other day. Everyone welcomed it. There was a huge sigh of relief around Australia from a lot of people when Mr Justice Maddern said, `Let's have this before the Commission'. Of course, everybody welcomed that, including Senator Chaney. In an interview given on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation on Monday, 25 September 1989, Senator Chaney said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if, as they-
that is, the pilots-
believe, they can each-
the companies and the pilots-
do a better deal outside the system, then they had better start showing the public and the Commission that they can do so.

I agree with Senator Chaney and that is what the pilots should have done. Headlines have appeared all over Australia on this issue and I quote just two: one appearing in the Canberra Times states, `Strike hopes dive: Pilots snub peace deadline . . . ' and the other appearing in the Australian Financial Review of today states, `Pilots snub judge's airline peace move'. It was with total despair that thousands of Australians, including me, saw those headlines. Why have the pilots done this and how have they done it? I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from the President of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots to the President of the Industrial Relations Commission.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN FEDERATION OF AIR PILOTS
26th September, 1989.
Mr Justice Maddern,
President,
Industrial Relations Commission,
Nauru House, 80 Collins Street,
MELBOURNE, VIC. 3000.
Dear Sir,
I refer to your statement made last Monday.

Your statement purports to record the history of the dispute, to make findings and give consequential directions. The Federation wishes to record that your statement was made without any prior disclosure to the Federation of the content of the statement, nor any opportunity being given to the Federation to be heard by you. The Federation does not accept the content of much of your statement. However, no point would be served in canvassing those areas in this letter.

To respond to your statement, the Federation must hold meetings of its members. These are being arranged at short notice in Brisbane, Perth, Melbourne and Sydney over the next two days. The federation will not be able to respond by 3.00 p.m. today. It will respond immediately the meetings have concluded, and there has been an opportunity to formulate an appropriate response. Any delay is not of the Federation's making. Had the Federation had earlier notice of your intentions the matter could have been dealt with at meetings that were held last week.

Your statement records that the airline companies `have employed pilots on individual contracts'. The question of whether any and if so what type of pilots have signed individual contracts has been a contentious issue during the dispute. In order that the Federation can make an informed response to your statement, will you kindly inform the Federation of your understanding as to the number and classification of pilots who have signed individual contracts with each airline, and further indicate the source of the information on which your statement was based.
Yours faithfully,
BRIAN McCARTHY-PRESIDENT.
Member of the International
Federation of Airline
Pilots Associations

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a gratuitously offensive letter, an unbelievably offensive letter particularly in the first and last paragraphs. It should have been written by the head of the Central Intelligence Agency or the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation perhaps. Someone in the industrial relations area on reading this letter said to me, `Who in the bloody hell do they think they are?'. It is inflammatory. It is totally non-productive. It has torpedoed the one chance that people were offering of settling this dispute. In addition the President of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots made it very clear last night and again today that the pilots will not budge one iota from their 30 per cent wage claim-not one cent from it. The pilots have been paying large amounts of money to place nonsense in the newspapers saying, `We are prepared to negotiate on any aspect, pay, productivity or hours'. That is another lie.

—Order! Senator Collins, your time has expired. I note to Senator Collins and other senators that their remarks should be addressed through the Chair, even when occasional interjections perhaps tempt them to speak directly to another senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating a matter of public importance which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The personal suffering and financial hardship inflicted on tens of thousands of Australians, particularly those living in more remote parts of the country, by the Government's gross mismanagement of the airline pilots' dispute.

We debated yesterday the matter of the Government's gross mismanagement and the Senate came to the conclusion that the Government is guilty of gross mismanagement. The Australian Democrats established the fact that it is not only the Government at whose door gross mismanagement may be laid. No one can condone the stance that the air pilots have taken. I have listened to other statements that have been made but I do not think that any inflammatory statements will help the matter at this stage. I also listened very carefully to the speeches by Senator MacGibbon and Senator Collins. I would like to state that hot air in this place will also not solve that dispute. Ultimately the only way the dispute can be solved is by negotiation, however that is finally done.

To turn to the first part of the matter that we are debating, there is a great deal of personal suffering. The effects have been horrendous in many cases. People have been unable to attend events of great importance to them on a personal basis such as weddings and funerals. People have been unable to be near someone who is ill or distressed. People have been unable to take their holidays when planned. Sports teams have been unable to compete. One particular incident of great tragedy which I would like to bring before the Senate was reported in the Hobart Mercury of 12 September when it was claimed that Tasmanian heart patients had died while waiting to travel interstate for surgery. Once we get to suffering on that level, we are into great suffering indeed. The greatest and most devastating effect overall has been felt by the tourism industry and by those who depend on the tourism industry on a flow on basis. Certainly, the more remote parts of Australia have suffered most of all. Some areas have been virtually cut off as far as air travel is concerned. Last week I opened a hotline in my Perth office on the issue of the air pilots dispute. Many of the people who called in were involved in the tourism industry. The picture painted by these people has amplified on a personal basis what has been reported of late in the media and there seem to be similarities in all States. Much of the Australian land mass may be defined as remote. Certainly, I would define as remote the whole of Western Australia, the Northern Territory, Tasmania and the northern parts of Queensland.

As Western Australia is my home State, I would like to start with the situation there. Western Australia has been virtually cut off to air travel since the pilots dispute. We have only to look at the press reports of airline schedules to see that the city of Perth very rarely rates a mention. The Perth Convention Bureau has been monitoring the financial loss suffered by its hotel members as a result of the pilots dispute and the effect on conventions and hotel accommodation. The hotels involved are the Hyatt, the Sheraton, the Perth International, Burswood, the Orchard, the Langley, Observation City and the Transit Inn. As at 18 September the hotels had suffered the following losses: 66 meetings and conventions, 4,129 delegates, 7,253 room nights and more than $1.2m in business. Over $3.6m in business spending has been lost to Perth as a whole. The estimated total loss to the State as a whole in terms of conventions alone is well over $6m.

I spoke to the owner of a women's fashion boutique in Broome, a town which is particularly suffering from the pilots dispute. This boutique sells only Australian made garments and its sales are down by some 70 per cent. Obviously this is another example of a flow on business which is suffering. I guess that as this boutique sells only Australian fashion, this downturn will flow on to the manufacturing industry. Broome has been particularly badly hit. The two French aeroplanes with their French crews which were hired to specifically fly from Perth to the northern parts of Western Australia cannot land at Broome airport. There is no air traffic control at Broome airport and pilots act as air traffic controllers. Because the French pilots either cannot or will not do this, Broome has been cut off from commercial air travel for the whole of the last six weeks. Planes land at Port Hedland, Derby and Kununurra, but not at Broome.

I could tell the Senate a number of distress stories about Broome, but I will not have time to do that today. Other towns in Western Australia, such as Geraldton, Kalgoorlie, Derby, Port Hedland and Exmouth, also have been very badly hit by the pilots dispute. Hotel accommodation, taxi hire and self-drive car hire are down and the tourist agencies have lost out on pre-booked tour trips. I think the only companies in that area which are gaining from this situation are the bus companies whose business is well up. A number of Australian operators have changed itineraries for groups which they are sending to New Zealand after a short stay in Sydney instead of to other Australian destinations such as central Australia or Queensland. This means that, apart from cancellations, the impact of the strike has been particularly felt in Sydney, north Queensland and the Gold Coast, Central Australia-particularly Ayers Rock and Kakadu-Tasmania and Perth. A report from the Alice Springs Regional Tourist Association Inc. says that tourism has virtually halted and it will take months, if not years, for many operators to recover.

As has been already mentioned in this place, the effect has been particularly devastating on the State of Tasmania. The tourists are staying away from Tasmania because holiday-makers require firm schedules and guaranteed connections. The Wrest Point Casino has laid off all casual gaming staff. Other gaming staff now work only four days a week. Launceston's recently opened international hotel has been forced to restructure its management and the Executive Director of the Tasmanian Visitor Corporation Ltd reports that some Tasmanian hotels are suffering occupancy rates of only 5 per cent, which is about the lowest I have heard of.

Tasmania's growing gourmet food industry relies on regular, complete air schedules and is losing millions of dollars while the dispute lasts. Conventions, meetings and conferences have been cancelled in Tasmania, as they have been throughout Australia. Tasmania plays a unique role as the end of the season destination for many Victorian football clubs. One Hobart hotel, which specialises in catering for club visits, has had to suffer the cancellation of all 20 clubs which were scheduled for October. The northern parts of Queensland have also been particularly badly affected. During a rally last night in Cairns some 2,000 people expressed their anger at the pilots dispute.

Although this dispute has continued for six weeks, there seems to be no definitive end in sight. Early in September, representatives of the Australian Tourist Industry Association met with representatives of such peak industry bodies as the Australian Bankers Association and the Australian Finance Conference. In fact, the tourist industry is getting remarkably unsympathetic treatment from banks and the finance industry generally. Members of the tourist industry have told me that the finance industry is slow to move and that any lending is being done at current commercial rates.

At the rally in Cairns there was a call for the Reserve Bank of Australia to release some statutory reserve deposit funds back to the banks and their subsidiary finance companies to assist in the restructuring and continued existence of individual operators. All the businesses in Cairns have been particularly badly affected. One local car rental business, which used to employ 10 people, now employs seven and is likely to employ fewer. Business is down to 60 per cent. Of course, this is the peak time in that part of Queensland. It is a time when people escape from the southern winter. I am told that today the temperature in Cairns is 28 degrees. Some of us here might be envious of that. The car hire firm I mentioned relies almost exclusively on tourism for business.

The tour operators in Cairns, and the hotels particularly, are operating at about only 30 per cent of their normal capacity. In many instances, they are offering 50 per cent discounts. So, in fact, they are operating at only 15 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is happening back home in the west?

—I have talked about some towns in the west. If I have time, I will talk more about that. All over Australia we are looking at poor takings in hotels, motels and convention centres. The flow on from this is affecting sales of petrol, spare parts for the car industry, laundries, catering services, retailers and taxis. It is affecting just about everybody. Revenue is way down and the figures have been explained in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is particularly interesting to look at air fares and I think this matter needs to be raised at this stage. The return air fare from Perth to Sydney is $1,004. The return air fare from Perth to Singapore in the low season is some $690 and in the high season some $800. The air fare from Perth to Bali in the low season is $500 and in the high season $600. Broome has been advertised as an alternative holiday resort to Bali. The building up of that business has decreased dramatically, and the tour operators in Broome are saying that it will take a long time to build it up again. People are losing their confidence in the airline industry in Australia and it will take a very long time for it to return. We read in the newspapers that a series of meetings to plan the recovery of the tourism industry will be held next month in each capital city. It will be very interesting to see what will come out of that. There is talk of people taking the pilots and maybe the airlines to court. We will have to see what comes out of that.

In the time left to me I will give further details of the situation in Western Australia. We read that the takings in Broome are down to such an extent that it is highly unlikely that businesses will be able to recover for years to come. Cable Beach Resort has lost more than $400,000 in the past 1 1/2 months. It reported that 90 per cent of its business comes from incoming flights. Therefore, that business is virtually non-existent. The Mangrove Motel and the Roebuck Bay Resort are up for sale because their turnover is down by some 30 to 40 per cent. Together they have had to put off some 60 staff. Room rates are down from $100 to $25 a night. This is the picture right across Australia. Hotels are having to give special deals in order to have anybody in them at all. One company is having to sell its charter boat service in Broome. Sales are reported as down right across the board in all retail stores. Weekend package holidays in Exmouth have been affected 100 per cent. There is a great fear in Geraldton that the crayfishing industry will be affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pilots dispute has reached such critical proportions that unless a breakthrough occurs this week many decent Australians will be sent to the wall through no fault of their own. It is unforgivable that a strike that was planned with military precision by the pilots well before the event, planning that was well known not only to the airline industries but also the Government, was allowed to eventuate. Why was this allowed? It was allowed because Sir Peter Abeles, Mr Rupert Murdoch and Mr Strong were anxious to use this confrontation for their own purposes. They were determined that by early next year they would have shed 400 pilots without paying redundancy payments so that when the deregulation arrived next year, the new airlines, so far Capital Airlines and Compass Airlines, would be able to compete more readily with Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This dispute has been readily acknowledged by all sides as one that will be long and drawn out and one in which the winner will take all without concern, sympathy or care for those hurt along the way. The Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peter Morris, could not even guarantee that the strike would be over by Christmas. The situation is that the pilots, sitting back on jolly good incomes, and the airlines, with their millions of dollars behind them, are prepared to sacrifice the average Australian worker for their own ends. No dispute can be resolved without both parties giving a little. But instead of allowing, through financial hardship, both parties to get together and talk, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has personally entered the dispute. He had inflamed the situation by stupid, childish, tantrum-type remarks. He has refused to allow the parties to talk and has subsidised the airlines, deliberately permitting them to forgo the financial hardship which is necessary to bring them to the conference table.

In the last few weeks the pilots have offered to go back to work full time so long as the Government allows them to negotiate, through the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, with their employer. It would have to be proper negotiation of wages and productivity. But the Prime Minister has refused to allow this to happen. The Government's mishandling of the pilots dispute is costing this country thousands of millions of dollars, not just in the short term but in areas in which it will take years to recover. I am sure we were all horrified and thoroughly embarrassed by the television news in the early steps of the strike which showed a Japanese tour organiser trying to explain to his tourist group that there was no way they could travel to their promised destination. He said, `All planes are grounded because of a strike'. Finally, he said, `It's unbelievable'. Even to Australians who are used to the worst industrial disputation of any country it is unbelievable. The long term harm to our tourist industry is inconceivable.

While the Treasurer, Mr Keating, maintains that very little damage is being done to the industry, yesterday, Senator Button, during his criticism of the Opposition, which was showing concern about the plight of so many affected industries, said:
The Liberals come back from their electorates having found that the tourist industry is feeling the pinch a bit.

He and his mates obviously do not have the vaguest idea of what is happening in Tasmania. If the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, the only Minister from our State, is not capable of getting our problems across to Cabinet, Senator Button should come down to see for himself just what the situation is.

Let me explain to the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus), who is present, what is happening in our State. The two casinos in Tasmania and the Sheraton Hotel in Hobart are in dire straits. Their occupancy is down to 20 per cent. In the last week conferences at Hobart casino have been cancelled. Others have struggled on with about a quarter of the previously expected numbers. These conferences-one of which, ironically, was a tourist conference-have all lost considerable money which was necessarily spent on planning them. Does the Minister who is present really believe that a conference planner will look favourably on Tasmania next year bearing in mind the loss this year? The Prime Minister and his Ministers say that this situation will only be temporary. Senator Button says, `We're feeling the pinch a bit'. The Government should come to its senses immediately.

As a result of the reduction in the number of guests in these large hotels, 80 casuals have been stood down in one of them. The other two hotels will stand down all casuals on Monday. This includes gaming casuals, housemaids, room service attendants, et cetera. The permanent staff, from management down, will be put on a four-day working week. While permanent staff salaries will be cut by one-fifth the effect on the casuals, many of whom are supporting mothers with several children, will be devastating. Is the Minister too isolated, with his high salary, to understand this? How would he cope if he suddenly lost one-fifth of his salary or lost it altogether? How do these people continue to pay the 17 1/2 per cent or 18 per cent interest rate on home mortgages that this Government has forced upon them through its mishandling of the economy?

Is the Minister aware of the flow-on effect to other Tasmanian industries of the devastation of the tourist industry? The casinos' ordering of liquor and food-meat, vegetables, seafood, yoghurt, custard and cheese-is down 35 per cent on their normal level. Hairdressing and laundry industries are feeling the pinch. Our local industries are not just feeling the pinch a bit; they are being devastated. The local butcher has assured me that his sales are well down. It is not just the big operators which are affected. I will quote from a letter written to me by a small operator-Bushventures 4WD Tours:
As a small family operator totally involved in the Tourist Industry in Tasmania, I feel compelled to write and voice our deep concern . . .
We stand to lose our livelihood, our home, and along with this the stigma of bankruptcy . . . through no fault of our own.
We rely almost totally on mainland and overseas tourists.

Tourism has been promoted as our number-one industry and is increasing and yet our politicians have allowed us to reach a point of losing 90% of our income by not securing exemptions for Tasmania during disputes, and for not even being able to coordinate any proper emergency arrangements.
The banks are very willing to extend our overdraft, but how do we repay them?
Is the Government going to drop our interest rates?
Pay our commitments to the bank?

So the letter continues. If Senator Button could spare a few moments to come down and look at the craft shops around Salamanca Place, he would discover how they are feeling. They are not feeling the pinch only a bit. One shopkeeper told me that the shop had taken $3 for the day and that would not even pay the rent. It is not only the tourist industry that is affected; all our industries are involved. As many honourable senators would know, Tasmania has a salmon and sea-run trout industry worth $40m a year. The salmon harvesting season has just begun and the ocean trout harvesting season has almost ended. To maintain its markets the industry was forced to transport ocean trout by charter aircraft at a loss. Oystas, a new company, is also at risk of losing its interstate, Japanese and American markets. Our crayfish, abalone, fresh cheese, fresh fruit, fresh flowers-what do we do with a week old tulip?-vegetable and meat industries are losing out. We can get our perishable goods to Melbourne, but we cannot get connecting flights. On several occasions flights have missed international connection. That is only part of our State's problems. I have not even mentioned the hire-car and taxi industry. Senator Button and his mates say that we are feeling the pinch only a bit. I believe they should come to Tasmania and have a look at the situation.

I wish to make it quite clear that this situation has occurred as a direct result of the Government's industrial relations policy. It has no legislation, no policy, to force the pilots back to work. It does not matter that the Prime Minister keeps saying that this could occur under our policy. The Australian people know that that is wrong. It has happened right under this Government's industrial relations policy. If we are seeking an independent review of the matter let us consider what the credit rating agency Moody's Investors Service had to say. It gave as one of the main reasons for downgrading our credit rating the persistence of structural weaknesses embedded in Australia's domestic and international position, such as intransigent rigidities in the local labour market and transport markets, as these constrain international competitiveness. In other words, the Government's industrial relations policy is not flexible enough and inhibits our competitiveness.

Let me explain how our policy would work. We would have voluntary unionism so that those pilots who were not union members could negotiate with the airlines in their own capacity. Pilots who were union members could get their union to negotiate on their behalf. If the negotiations fell through they would go to the Industrial Relations Commission, which could make a determination that would have the backing of law. That is not the case at the moment. The present situation could occur only under the Labor Government. I call on Ministers in this Government to take on the Prime Minister-I am sure that not all of them agree with him-and tell him that he cannot continue to sacrifice the average Australian for his own political face-saving. He must retire from the dispute before there is an air tragedy. If a tragedy occurs because of the short cuts in air safety about which we have spoken in this place today, it will be laid right at the feet of the Prime Minister and the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter before us today is indeed an important one. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The personal suffering and financial hardship inflicted on tens of thousands of Australians, particularly those living in more remote parts of the country, by the Government's gross mismanagement of the airline pilots' dispute.

I would be one of the first to agree that a great deal of personal suffering has resulted from the pilots dispute. No doubt many people have suffered considerable hardship because of it. No doubt those Australians who live in remote and isolated areas are also greatly affected by the dispute. I also think that the domestic air travelling public has suffered great inconvenience. Many trips have been postponed or cancelled. Road, rail and bus travel has greatly expanded and, indeed, a large number of overseas tourists have either cancelled or postponed trips to Australia because of the dispute. There can be no doubt that the dispute has cost individuals a great deal of money and cost the country great losses of earnings, and many businesses will no doubt suffer lost profits.

With regard to the alleged mismanagement of the dispute, in my view the Opposition has got it wrong. The Government has a duty to govern in the interests of all Australians and to maintain a balanced system of wage movement, not the anarchy or law of the jungle which appears to be coalition policy. When the Opposition claims that this dispute has been mishandled, it is guilty of some of the worst humbug and hypocrisy. The Government must stand firm behind a wages policy that has established guidelines and seen the reversal of the disastrous Fraser-Howard years when inflation and unemployment went out of hand in 1981-82. In those years Australia experienced a wages explosion and a recession followed that saw unemployment rise to around 11 per cent. The policy of the coalition Government of that time, which allowed collective bargaining and ended centralised wages fixing, gave wages outcomes that threatened to wreck the whole country. Indeed, the industrially strong did very well out of those years, whilst other groups of wage and salary earners copped the inflation and the broken promises. They remembered those failed policies in March 1983.

The coalition's present policy seems to be the same. The coalition does not feel the need to rethink and reassess its position since 1981-82, even through the price of its policies has been the political wilderness ever since. This is an important matter, because the central issue in the pilots dispute is whether a centralised system of wage fixation with checks and balances and benefits for all wage and salary earners can survive. The alternative, which the pilots want, is a wage fixing system which allows them, with their ability, to wreck the tourist industry, dislocate business and cost Australia valuable overseas exchange in order to have wage rises whenever they wish. The pilots can hold a gun at the head of the Government or the airlines and say, `Pay up now or we will cause all the dislocation and disruption that we can'. The pilots know that they can rely on the support of the Opposition.

When the Government and the airlines refuse to pay up, they are accused by the Opposition of mishandling the dispute. Of course, if things were different and the Government did not stand firm, the wage fixing principles would be thrown out of the window. The industrially strong would immediately use the muscle that they have and completely break the wages system that has seen an unparalleled growth in Australian employment. If that were to happen, no doubt the Opposition would be arguing here for quids for its mates and nothing for the rest.

In fact, it is interesting to see the Opposition's real industrial relations policy at work. When Canberra doctors were out after every dollar they could get, the whole world had to come to a stop. The Opposition screamed foul and said that the doctors had to get exorbitant rises immediately. I seem to remember listening in this Senate to how terrible it was that visiting specialists could get only $67 an hour in Canberra but could get $97 in Sydney and how the world would come to an end because of it. All of this was stated here day in and day out by Senators Walters, MacGibbon and Lewis.

I also remember hearing in a debate as recently as this morning how the Government really ought to pay more to the pharmacists. It was a different story when it came to the Mudginberri or Dollar Sweets workers. Every sanction possible was advocated then. The policy was different, but quite clear-cut. If the meat workers and confectioners had been wiped out, no doubt the Government would have mishandled that dispute as well. In that case the Opposition wanted every possible weapon used to break the strike. This time it is the Opposition's mates, so it wants negotiations, pay deals and the whole bit. The hypocrisy of the Opposition's whole industrial relations policy stands out starkly. When ordinary workers are involved, every weapon is used to break them; but when it is the Opposition's mates we must all get together and work out a deal. The Norm Gallaghers of the airline industry can feel safe with the coalition's industrial relations policy.

A recent article in the Age shows quite clearly what the community thinks on this issue. An article entitled `Poll finds most think pilots' pay claim is unreasonable', showed in polling that the public stood firmly behind the Government in the dispute. Three out of four people in Melbourne and Sydney believed the pay claim to be excessive. Even more enlightening in this article was a phone poll conducted in Melbourne with a sample of 400 respondents which showed that 76 per cent of those surveyed believed that pilots should not be a special case; in other words, over three-quarters believed that pilots should not be allowed special dispensation to step out of the wages system.

Looking at the chronology of events is interesting in this case. On 10 August the rolling stoppages started and the Industrial Relations Commission hearing was set for 11 August after the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) refused to answer how the 29.47 per cent wage claim was consistent with the wage guidelines. On 11 August the pilots' federation never attended the Commission but instead organised a 12-hour stoppage in Melbourne. From 12 to 14 August it was the turn of Brisbane, Perth, Cairns and Sydney. On 11 August the AFAP stated quite clearly that pilots saw no point in pursuing wage increases within the wage fixing guidelines. Since that time the pilots' federation has stated that if pilots get the rise and somebody says that it is consistent with the guidelines, it will not worry the pilots. We are dealing with an organisation that is pursuing its goals by all the ruthless means at its disposal. It has shown nothing but contempt for wage fixing principles. It works few hours and has some of the best paid workers in the country. When the Opposition says that the Government is mishandling the dispute, it really means that it supports the pilots. The Opposition seems to wish them well.

On the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program 7.30 Report of 14 September we find some born-again trade unionists. I say `born-again' trade unionists because they spent most of their parliamentary careers scorning the achievements of the trade union movement. All of a sudden they now believe in trade unions, and they say that the Government is aggravating the situation. On that program Senator John Stone, a chief born-again trade unionist, had a few things to say. I quote from that program:
Paul Lyneham: And to save the centralised system you force the pilots to sign private contracts outside the system?

John Stone: Well, I mean, exactly. I mean, the funny thing is that the Prime Minister, that really seems to be the sticking point for the Prime Minister, and indeed Sir Peter Abeles too. I mean, they seem to be prepared to say yes, we will talk to the pilots individually or maybe in groups, small groups, but we're not prepared to have them represented by their trade union. Well, I mean, this is the ex-president of the ACTU talking.
Paul Lyneham: Isn't there some irony, though, in John Stone's suggesting there should be talks with the trade union?

John Stone: No, on the contrary. I've always believed, and every member of the Opposition has always believed in the right of any worker in this country to freedom of association, to form a trade union if they want. And indeed, as you know, our industrial relations policy-which I should say Fred Chaney would explain in much more detail than I-provides specifically for enterprise unions, for unions to be formed of workers within a particular enterprise.

So all the coalition members are now big supporters of the trade union movement. Some honourable senators opposite must be squirming about these revelations. Senator Stone must be a worry to some of his National Party Senate colleagues. Senator McGauran must be getting out of here at the right time.

Yesterday Senator Chaney, when debating the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, stated that so far the dispute has cost half a billion dollars and it could cost $3 billion in a full year. He went on in that same speech to argue that many smaller players would be hurt so badly that they would vanish from the scene altogether. I note that in that speech nothing was said about organisations, such as the AFAP, that ruthlessly hold Australia to ransom, nor did we hear anything about what would happen if the Government caved in to the demands of Senator Chaney's mates. Mr Peacock, who is the current Leader of the Opposition, stated on 31 August:
We are not in government today, and the duty is on this Government to fix the dispute.
So much for constructive opposition! Mr Howard, once more prominent in the coalition, let the cat out of the bag on 3AW's Upfront program on 19 September by saying:
. . . I hope that this dispute is settled and I hope it is settled in a way that permanently weakens the centralised wage fixing system.

The real target in the Opposition's sights is the system of centralised wage fixation. It would prefer the law of the jungle-the law that operated in the last of the Fraser-Howard years that saw disastrous wage and employment outcomes. The born-again trade unionists are saying little about the tactics of the AFAP or what would happen should it be successful and destroy the wages policy.

Finally, I think it is essential that the Government stand its ground and ensure that wage fixation is not a contest of industrial muscle or the law of the jungle. In a rare moment Mr Peacock got it right on the AM program of 25 August. He stated:
It's a classic case where you've got to go beyond the employer/employee fight and look after the national interest. And the Government is correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a matter of public importance put forward by my colleague Senator MacGibbon. I will read this matter of public importance for the Senate again. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The personal suffering and financial hardship inflicted on tens of thousands of Australians, particularly those living in more remote parts of the country, by the government's gross mismanagement of the airline pilots' dispute.

Thousands of Australians are being hurt by this dispute and our national economy is suffering grievous long term damage because the Hawke Labor Government has mismanaged the dispute right from the very start. It has not just made mistakes in the `Yes, Prime Minister' tradition; rather it has deliberately pursued a policy in the interests of the cherished Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) accord that runs against principles of justice, commonsense and the national interest.

Right from the start the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been determined to inflame the dispute. The former great conciliator of the ACTU, whose solution to this kind of dispute was invariably surrender by employers and opposition to any stern measures of previous governments, did not call the pilots bus drivers by accident. He thought there were votes in attacking tall poppies whose real crime is not the 30 per cent wage demand that we in the Opposition never supported when divorced from productivity but the fact that they want to go outside his accord. Once the Prime Minister realised that his abuse was counterproductive his form letter to individual pilots appealing for a return to work tended to lack credibility, not least because Mrs Deborah Wardley, a well known and respected pioneer female pilot, was addressed as Mr. Some personal appeal!

We had the so-called world's greatest Treasurer trying to tell us on 21 September that black was white and that the tourist industry was not being damaged by this Government's prolonged dispute and being publicly contradicted by his colleague, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding). Rhetoric, however irresponsible and destructive, is only one part of the mishandling of this dispute. On 20 August the Prime Minister gave his support to the tactic of the airlines in taking legal action against pilots. They would not have resigned without this prime ministerial threat.

It was interesting to listen to Senator Collins a little while ago. He comes from the Northern Territory, an isolated part of this country. He spent his entire 20 minutes pilot bashing. He did not even mention all of the things that are happening in the Northern Territory-as I said, a very isolated part of this country. It is a shame he did not contact his Northern Territory colleague from the National Party, Senator Grant Tambling. Senator Tambling has pages and pages of information about people who are really hurting in the Northern Territory. People repeatedly tell him that their businesses are 50 per cent. People with a staff of nine are considering laying off four or five staff and believe that the effects of the pilots dispute will be felt for six to 12 months if they still have a business. The list goes on. A business selling opals in Alice Springs had sales for the month of September which equalled $1. Last year at this time the owner was banking $7,000 a week. She has already laid off two people. Another person with a live fish aquarium lost 100 per cent of his business as there were no live shipments for six weeks. It has closed down temporarily. It requires direct flights and rates have doubled. There are outstanding orders in all States except Tasmania that cannot be filled.

Senator Tambling has compiled a very sad list. Of course the list goes on in Western Australia, my own State. The owner of a seafood company sends seafood to the eastern States and requires other products in return. He anticipates that he will lose approximately $50,000 in turnover. He is also considering retrenching staff. Computer software companies and fresh fish suppliers are losing $60,000 per week and have laid off nine people. This is happening across the whole of the industry. Fishermen and their boats are remaining idle and are not earning any income. The cooperative of private limousine drivers is losing between $6,000 and $7,000 a week. It has put off several casual staff. The small shopkeeper reports that sales are down from around $8,000 a week to less than $1,000 a week. The wildlife park relies heavily on tourists and family groups and is losing up to $12,000 a week. Once again, this is just a small sample of people who are getting hurt. There are 26 examples in this small sample. But Senator Collins abuses the pilots and does not for one moment consider the way in which the Prime Minister has inflamed the situation. Would he accuse the other unions, who will not even consider talking to their employers in case of a dispute? No, he would not. We do not agree with that 30 per cent increase without consideration, in tandem, of productivity increases.

On 5 September the Prime Minister admitted in Parliament that his Government had encouraged the airlines to negotiate with individual pilots and to ignore the Australian Federation of Air Pilots that, like so many other unions, is the organisation that the great majority of individual pilots wish to have representing them. This is the person who says that people should belong to unions. This is the person who is constantly contradicting himself, constantly inflaming the situation. This system of representation is the one that the Prime Minister has condoned, developed and fostered as recently as yesterday at the ACTU Congress. But where it applies to the pilots is a different kettle of fish altogether.

Then we have the action of the Hawke Labor Government providing financial subsidies to airlines through the waiving of fees, an action designed to encourage the airlines to tough out the dispute to the immense damage of the tourist industry and the national economy. It even had the cheek to pretend that the waiving of charges, a $14m loss to revenue per week, did not constitute spending public money. Well, whose money is it? No government has any money other than that which the taxpayer provides. The Prime Minister is saying that it is not public money. Whose money is he bailing the airlines out with?

TALK.START.PARA: —The taxpayers'.

—That is right. It is certainly not his own and I think this is what the people need to realise. They are paying more each year in personal taxation for this Government to prolong this dispute. Australians should realise that this Labor Government had the practical means at its disposal to have brought the parties together weeks ago if it wanted. But one major airline is owned by the taxpayer and the undoubted personal friendship and rapport between the Prime Minister and Sir Peter Abeles of Ansett Airlines of Australia could have been used with constructive effect rather than the reverse which exacerbated the problem. The Prime Minister wilfully allows Australia to be damaged because the ACTU accord cannot be allowed to fail. There might be a case for the armoury of award cancellations, resort to civil law remedies, use of both the armed forces and foreign strike-breaking workers and the denial of representation from a particular union if the accord truly did operate in the national interest, but does it?

SPEECH.PARA: Why should Australians be asked to grovel before a corporate sweetheart deal whose bottom line result is a 0.2 per cent fall in productivity each year when the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development nations are posting an average of 1.2 per cent annual productivity improvement? The accord is actually denying Australians the real benefits of improved productivity that would arise if employers and employees as individuals or represented by chosen unions were free to negotiate their own productivity-based agreements. That is all we are calling for in this dispute. Under a coalition government we would see the Australian Federation of Air Pilots sitting down with the airlines and talking productivity. If they had chosen to remain in the central system they would be subject to swift and accepted legal procedures. Will the Government do that? No, it just wants a exacerbate this problem until Australia bleeds to death.

This brings me to the other great weakness of this Government's desperate attempt to enforce the accord, the fact that it has no real legal basis. When did this Parliament ever vote to enforce it upon the Australian work force? The Government does not have the courage to bring that forward. It has no legal shape because the ACTU does not want the rule of law and the Prime Minister bows down before it. It is kept in being by extra-parliamentary pressure tactics. We all have reaped the reward of an institutionalised 7 per cent inflation rate. There is serious discontent among important sections of the work force who feel that they have been made more equal than others. In order to preserve a system that is the worst of both worlds, with the rigidities of centralism without just legal regulation, with the refusal to provide for constructive agreements outside it, the Hawke Labor Government is fighting to the death-the death of the tourist industry in this country.
I come back to the problems of isolation associated with a State like Western Australia. Monday's Australian, under the heading `Today's interstate air services', states:
Today's domestic flight schedules, released by the airlines, are printed below. Ansett's proposed services were not available.

There is not one mention of a flight to Perth, the capital of Western Australia, on the whole list. It could be suggested that Ansett had flights. But I am told repeatedly that Ansett and Australian Airlines share on a fifty-fifty basis each flight that goes in and out of Perth. According to the list, Australian Airlines did not have one flight going to Perth. In the north-west, businesses are closing down at a rate of knots; they are losing business. The airlines certainly are not very forthcoming with the extent of their services to Perth, or any other area for that matter. Statewide, one-year's tourism growth has been wiped off in six weeks. Of course, the damage is far greater in Broome where the well-respected Cable Beach Club resort has lost $400,000 in this same time.

In the short time that I have left, one other issue I wish to cover is the question of safety. My colleague Senator MacGibbon, in his address to the Senate a short time ago, mentioned many areas of safety. If he is wrong, I challenge a member of the Government to come in here and unequivocally-unlike Senator Evans yesterday-state that there have not been any compromises in the world's safest airline record in history. This Government is compromising that safety record. Aircraft are being allowed to fly over 30,000 feet altitude with no drop-down oxygen masks but with a few oxygen bottles in the plane. If such an aircraft lost pressurisation, people would be dead in a matter of seconds. The Government is allowing that to happen. If I am wrong I wish someone from the Government would say so and give me the reasons why I am wrong.

Equally, if the Government has not compromised the accreditation of pilots in air space, it can tell me that I am wrong. I am reliably informed that airline pilots from overseas have to undergo far less stringent tests than Australian airline pilots. They do not have to have familiarity with where they are flying. There are enough problems with the congested airspace without additional problems. If an overseas pilot fails his test, he is allowed to re-sit that test in 48 hours; but Australian pilots have to wait 14 days. Where is the justice in that? I do not wish to be alarming at all. I am concerned about this aspect. If I am wrong, please let the Government tell me so. We should not be compromising Australia's fine safety record that the pilots have delivered to this country over the eternity of flying in Australia. What the Government is doing is absolutely and utterly hypocritical in the extreme. The Prime Minister should be told to make these two parties get together to resolve this dispute at the earliest possible time. He should not be seen to extend and exacerbate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is discussing a matter of public importance-indeed, it is a matter of public importance-proposed by one of the Opposition's front bench spokespersons, Senator MacGibbon, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The personal suffering and financial hardship inflicted on tens of thousands of Australians, particularly those living in more remote parts of the country, by the government's gross mismanagement of the airline pilots' dispute.

This is a matter of supreme importance. It is a matter of importance to each and every citizen and resident of Australia. Despite what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) says, this dispute with the commercial airline pilots of the major airlines in Australia is a matter of national interest and national importance. However, despite the rhetoric we have heard this afternoon from three Opposition spokespersons, there is a denial by the Leader of the Opposition that this dispute is of national significance. I quote from an interview on the Good Morning Australia program of 20 September, just a few days ago, with Mr Peacock, the present Leader of the Opposition, when he said:

When in fact the national interest is threatened then there is a role for the Government and here, of course, I don't think any of you would argue that there's, the national interest is not being impaired.

We have heard many statements not only from the Opposition but also from the Government as to how the national interest is being impaired. We have seen numerous media comments about this dispute. In fact, it has led the front pages of most of Australia's media for the last six weeks. We have also seen in those newspaper comments evidence of some confusion within the Opposition ranks. The previous speaker, Senator Knowles, was taking to task in the chamber her leader here, the Opposition's spokesman for industrial relations, Senator Chaney, asking him to set out clearly the Opposition's position on the airlines dispute. Again the Opposition's spokespersons this afternoon have continued to identify the confusion that reigns within the ranks of the Opposition on this most important public issue.

The matter of public importance proposed by Senator MacGibbon refers to the Government's mismanagement of the airlines dispute. Yet Senator Walters, the second speaker for the Opposition, put the blame not on the Government but on Sir Peter Abeles, Mr Murdoch and Mr Strong. She clearly named those three people as being responsible for it. Senator MacGibbon said-I think I am right with these words but he can correct me if I am wrong-that this dispute was planned with military precision.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wasn't me.

—I am sorry. It was obviously Senator Walters. I withdraw the implication against Senator MacGibbon. Senator Walters said it was planned with military precision-not by Mr Murdoch, not by Sir Peter Abeles, not by Mr Strong, not by Mr Hawke or any Government Ministers, but by the airline pilots. We have also seen in the media of Australia numerous advertising, such as came from the Leader of the Opposition on 21 September in the Australian: `Mr Hawke, for Australia's sake, sit down and talk'. How far removed can the Opposition be from reality to pay out money to put in an advertisement like that? The Opposition does not know the group we are dealing with. The group we are dealing with is the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) led by Mr McCarthy. Mr McCarthy will put a new slant on the word `McCarthyism' which many of us, and all free democratic thinking persons, fear and dread. Indeed, there will be a new slant on that term in future years, particularly from an Australian point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that the confusion that exists in the minds of the Opposition actually comes from what is happening within the Opposition parties at the moment. There is clear evidence of just what has been happening. The New Right in Australia has been slowly but surely taking over the Opposition parties. It did not need to do a great deal within the National Party of Australia because that Party was already a captive of it. Senator Stone will ensure that its captivity remains and continues. It had some problems with some of the wets in the Liberal Party, but many of them have been rolled or, like Senator Puplick, put in unwinnable positions on the various party tickets.

A lot of advice has been given to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. Although I do not know for certain, I suspect that the voice of one Peter Costello is very close to the ear of Mr McCarthy when it comes to giving advice. Certainly, there are a number of parallels between this dispute and others that have been mentioned and used in arguments in this place. For example, I mention the dispute at Dollar Sweets, which Mr Costello had a great deal to do with, and the dispute at Mudginberri.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are we going to solve it?

—Until yesterday, I think there was some hope of bringing a degree of reality and rationality into the situation. However, I think the public statements and public utterances by Mr McCarthy yesterday should show each and every one of us just what that individual and the executive of the Federation are about.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware of the Opposition's policy and attitude towards the Industrial Relations Commission, and I will deal with that in a short time, but whatever the attitude to Mr McCarthy is, the Industrial Relations Commission is a part of our system and has got a role and authority. That authority has been accepted to a degree by Opposition spokespersons-and I have got the press releases here if we want to follow them through and prove it.

TALK.START.PARA: —But no teeth.

—It has got teeth and it has used its teeth on a number of occasions. As a trade unionist, I am aware of when its teeth have been used. It does not always need six-figure fines to show when there are teeth in the determinations of the Industrial Relations Commission. I suggest that, until yesterday, there was a degree of respect from most sources within the community towards the role of the Industrial Relations Commission. I say `until yesterday', because yesterday, 26 September, the Australian Federation of Air Pilots actually showed what it was about. One press statement castigated Mr Crean, the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Mr McCarthy has clearly said that the Federation of Air Pilots is on its own, that there would be no national wage guidelines or prices and incomes accord for the Federation. The 1,600-odd pilots will make determinations for themselves, irrespective of the cost to the community, the cost to business, the cost to tourism or the cost to Australia. It will do it for itself-an exercise in greed and avarice that, I suggest, has never been witnessed from any trade union in Australia. I do not believe that this particular organisation deserves to be credited with the name `trade union'.

SPEECH.PARA: The second action undertaken yesterday was the letter which Mr McCarthy wrote to Mr Justice Maddern, the President of the Industrial Relations Commission. As Senator Collins said, it was perhaps the most advanced exercise in arrogance that we have ever witnessed in the industrial relations scene in this country and, indeed, we have witnessed many on both sides of the dispute. I said previously that unions are not necessarily faultless in this.

TALK.START.PARA: —It makes me look like a boy scout.
—I did not get Senator Bolkus's interjection, but I hope it is productive. I think it is worth reading the last paragraph of Mr McCarthy's letter into the record:

SPEECH.PARA: Your statement records that the airline companies ``have employed pilots on individual contracts''. The question of whether any and if so what type of pilots have signed individual contracts has been a contentious issue during the dispute. In order that the Federation can make an informed response to your statement, will you kindly inform the Federation of your understanding as to the number and classification of pilots who have signed individual contracts with each airline, and further indicate the source of the information on which your statement was based.

If that is not thumbing one's nose at the Industrial Relations Commission, I do not know what is. There were a few interjections earlier asking me to suggest how the dispute can be resolved. I suggest that the time for negotiations has now concluded. The Australian Federation of Air Pilots has clearly put on record that it does not want advice from anybody other than its New Right companions and advisers. I suggest that Sir Peter Abeles, Mr Murdoch and, indeed, the successor to Mr Strong in Australian Airlines-and I do not forget the other airlines involved in the dispute too-ought to make a decision now that there will be no further contact with Mr McCarthy or the executive of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. That body, by its letter and its statements, has proved that it does not want to talk; it does not want to resolve this dispute. It wants to drag Australia down; it wants to destroy the tourism industry. The airline executives ought to realise and accept that.

Another matter I want to address in my contribution this afternoon is the question of individual contracts. I know it is a concept that is accepted within the Liberal Party's industrial relations policy. It is not a concept that I have advocated in the past. I suggest it is one concept that will go some way towards resolving this dispute. But it cannot be left just at the question of individual contracts, because that can end up in a dog eat dog situation and may in the long term create much larger problems than those which we have at the moment, although it will be hard to overcome what McCarthy and his cohorts have done to the airlines of Australia and the economy of Australia. There are some pilots who are signing contracts, although I do not know their names. Even if I did, I certainly would not be exposing them or putting their names on the public record so that they could have their arms and legs broken by the thugs of the AFAP. It is imperative that those pilots who are signing contracts become members of a union; not the AFAP. It may be that the Transport Workers Union of Australia has applied for coverage of their awards. In my own State of Western Australia, it may be that the Australian Tramway and Motor Omnibus Employees Association, under the leadership of my good friend Bernard Terry, which is the union that covers the bus drivers in that State, could afford some protection.

I make one comment about my own State of Western Australia. I heard Senator Knowles's comments and I understand her care for the State from which we both come. I also listened intently to what Senator Jenkins of the Australian Democrats had to say. I remind Senator Jenkins that Western Australia covers one-third of Australia and that there are more towns and places in Western Australia served by airlines than just Broome. Unfortunately, her remarks this afternoon will be used in argument on the location of a new airport for that town. There is some degree of contention concerning that at the moment. I conclude my remarks here this afternoon by again condemning McCarthy and McCarthyism as it is impacting and affecting the economy of Australia. I point out to Senator Panizza, who is attempting to interject, that farmers are actually being affected as well.

I wish briefly to comment on the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) annual report 1989.
