This report from the Australian Science and Technology Council entitled Profile of Australian Science is a bit like the curate's egg. It is a very strange report in many ways and fairly poorly written in other ways. Embedded in it at various stages are some excellent recommendations and observations. Indeed, much of the compilation of the material towards the end provides a very good basis for ongoing work in this area.
In the short time that I have available I wish to refer to one item only. On page XV, the report states:

It is impractical to allow unrestrained growth in the number of academics who are allowed to conduct research. Unless there is a loosening of the link between teaching and research in universities, any new academic staff (and hence research staff) will be concentrated in areas of growing student demand.

First, I take strong exception to the notion that we will allow or not allow academics to do research. This item is developed in more detail on page 37. In a saving exercise, the report seeks to make a distinction between teaching, scholarship and research and, quite correctly, says that a scholarship is often tied in with research because `the conduct of research requires a knowledge and critical examination of developments in a given area of research'.

While that is true, some extraordinary statements are relied upon in getting to this conclusion. For example, the report points out quite clearly the very large growth in full-time student equivalents between 1975 and 1985 when the student load increased by 14.4 per cent in universities and 38.7 per cent in colleges of advanced education. In that time, however, the increase in academic staff has been only about 4 per cent. Hence, the quite unexceptionable comment is made that an academic's time will probably be spent more on teaching. If increases are loaded at such an enormous rate and the staff numbers are increased at a lower rate, obviously more time will be spent on teaching. But then this statement is made:
The likely outcome will only be changed if universities learn to teach more efficiently.

First, no explanation is given about how we can teach more efficiently. Presumably, we can stuff more bodies into lecture theatres or have more in tutorials. I find it a most extraordinary statement to appear in a learned report coming from some of the eminent people who signed it.

The tradition of teaching and research, contrary to the suggestion on page 37 that it has a short history, has a very long history. The notion of research at a university level is intimately linked to teaching. A person is expected to push back the frontiers of his speciality. University teaching staff are expected to write papers for publication in learned journals. Indeed, the report says quite clearly that advancement is dependent on writing papers. Someone who writes papers is presumably engaging in something other than simply looking at what everybody else has said. He is contributing to the ongoing exercise, to the ongoing understanding, in that area. He is engaged in research.

The rather sloppy exercise of saying that there can be a neat division between teaching and research will bedevil the education debate for some time to come, particularly as the Dawkins approach to the exercise is that we will fund many people to do teaching and many other people to do research. It will not work; it cannot work by the very nature of university teaching. This attempt to get the argument up and running is to be regretted. There needs to be far more careful examination of what people actually do in universities. Glib statements of the kind that are set out on page 37, from which other conclusions are then drawn, should not be made. They are faulty because the premises upon which they are based are not in accordance with the reality of university teaching and research.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER HERITAGE PROTECTION ACT 1984

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This has been a matter of considerable public interest in Western Australia and, I think, more widely. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) describes how on 21 June he made a permanent declaration under section 10 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 in respect of a significant Aboriginal site located on Reserve 39880 in the State of Western Australia. This particular site became the subject of an application for protection because of its significance to Aborigines and the threat of injury which the development of the old Swan brewery posed to that area, which is associated with the Waugul or rainbow serpent.

The site in contention was not actually the brewery site, which is reclaimed land, but land very close to it-just across the road, in fact. It is at the base of Mount Eliza and close to a permanent spring. This is understood to have been a camping area recognised certainly early in the colonisation of Western Australia and probably for much longer. It would be surprising if it were not a site of some significance because of its geographical location and the fact that it is very close to the Narrows, the easiest method of crossing the estuary from Mount Eliza to the South Perth side of the river. The Minister describes how he was required to be satisfied that the area was of significance to Aborigines, and commissioned a report from Dr Clive Senior of Northmore Hale Davy and Leake. He also consulted with the relevant State Minister and took into consideration advice provided by the Attorney-General's Department in respect of the interpretation of `particular significance' within the meaning of the Aboriginal tradition. The Minister describes how, having been satisfied that the site was of particular significance to Aboriginal people, and that the development of the old Swan brewery posed a threat of injury, he decided to make a declaration, which occurred on 21 June.

Developments since then have included consultations between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Premier of Western Australia. Happily, an agreement has been reached regarding the area that is the subject of the application. On the basis of this agreement and further assurances given by the Western Australian Premier the Minister, Mr Gerry Hand, has been able to revoke the declaration of 21 June. The agreement with the State Government means that the Government will be bound by the State Aboriginal Heritage Act. There was some confusion about whether that was actually binding on the State. Before any further excavations are made at the site, including the proposed sewerage and electricity works, the State Government will act as though its legislation requires it to comply and will introduce legislation to bind the Crown by the Aboriginal Heritage Act. It seems to me that this is a satisfactory conclusion to what has been a very vexed question in Western Australia, clouded by the fact that there is not a lot of consensus in Western Australia about whether the brewery should be retained or developed. It is extremely rewarding to discover that agreement has been reached between our Federal and State governments on this matter, and it should be to the satisfaction of the Aborigines who have been so concerned about the fate of their significant site.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is the result of the efforts of a number of people, most notably former Senator George Georges who for many years was a senator in this place and the guiding light of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. This report is very much the result of his efforts.

SPEECH.PARA: The Animal Welfare Committee, under Senator Georges, has been a catalyst for the improvement of the welfare of animals in this country. The report is an important document. Even during the stages when evidence was being gathered I think the Animal Welfare Committee contributed to the issue by offering a forum for debate for all sides. This was important. We were able to give people who perhaps ordinarily would not have the means of speaking out a platform on which to express their views, some of which were considered to be radical and some of which were not.

We had to address the problem of animals' rights. What are the rights of animals? Do they have the same rights as, or even more rights than, people? We took a great deal of evidence on this subject. I lean towards the view that animals do have a great number of rights in many areas, probably as many as human beings do. However, in my own mind I had to come down on the side of allowing animal experimentation to continue, so I have not made a dissenting report in this animal experimentation compendium. I basically agree with the recommendations set out in this report. I wish that all those who experiment on animals would take an enlightened view towards those experiments and limit the use of animals as much as possible. I am happy to say that just about all of the witnesses who appeared before us who were involved in animal experimentation in any way claimed to recognise the rights of animals, and many of them told how they had been reducing the number of animals used in their experiments. Frankly, I hope never to have to go into another animal house. We went through animal houses in all the States, and I still have that--

TALK.START.PARA: —I know what you mean.

—Senator MacGibbon says he knows what I mean. There is a combined smell of fear and urine which sticks in the nose when one goes into those places. The Animal Welfare Committee, with great fortitude, went into a number of these houses. Some were better than others. Most of them, if not all, were managed by sincere people, but many of those people were not well-enough trained. This is one of our concerns. One of the recommendations in the report is that training programs be instituted for those people who take care of animals in animal houses.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major stumbling blocks we found in our deliberations is one which faces all Australians in almost all matters, and that is the issue of States' rights. Our recommendations 13.46 and 15.57 deal with that issue. We recommended that all States and Territories upgrade animal welfare legislation and establish animal welfare advisory councils and departmental animal welfare units, as has been done in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. At 15.57 the Committee recommends that the system of controlling animal experimentation in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia be extended to the other States and Territories. This system is based on upgraded legislation. It would be a wonderful thing if, in this country, we could legislate federally to bring the States into line on issues such as animal welfare. We found that New South Wales especially, and Victoria and South Australia, were enlightened in their legislative programs. Other States and Territories have not seemed to follow suit. There is a national concern for animal welfare. Ethics committees have been set up in each university in each of the States, but there is as yet no overall Federal control. I think it is time we faced the fact that we are a nation and should implement this type of control.

Throughout the examination of this issue of animal experimentation we found that the animals themselves were generally pretty well looked after. The exceptions to this were rare. We did encounter one situation in Adelaide where some animals were checked out by a medical experimenter without the knowledge of the people who ran the animal house. In fact, our Committee stumbled across this when the experimenter brought the animals back. They were rabbits which had been under anaesthetic and were still anaesthetised. The experimenter just dropped them on the table and left. We brought this up with the university officials concerned and, to their credit, they took steps to ensure that it never happened again.

In general, animal experimentation in this country has come a long way, certainly in the last five or 10 years. At the moment, the welfare of animals undergoing experimentation in Australia matches or exceeds that of any other country. So I think we can be proud of the progress made in Australia in animal welfare. There is probably still more to be done. Certainly the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare is still looking at new references. But this report will stand as an excellent reference work on the state of animal welfare at this time. We still have some ways to go but in general I think we can take some comfort in the fact that our animals are now being treated with the dignity that they deserve.

to preserve our sovereignty over the AAT,-
the Australian Antarctic Territory-

to maintain Antarctica free from strategic and/or political confrontation;-
that is a laudable goal-
to protect the Antarctic environment, having regard to both its special qualities and its effects on our region-

to take advantage of the special opportunities Antarctica offers for scientific research;
to be informed about and able to influence developments in a region geographically proximate to Australia; and-

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have a statement to make on this matter. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Termination of the Inquiry

It is with considerable regret that I make this personal statement about the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration into the sale of Australian Dairy Corporation (ADC) shares in an Indonesian subsidiary, PT Indomilk. I inform the Senate that the Committee has resolved not to make a substantive report on this matter. I recently reviewed the large body of evidence produced by a considerable investment of Committee and staff time in this inquiry over a period of several years. I concluded that it would not be possible for the Committee to report properly on the basis of the evidence to hand and that I could not justify the further effort required to produce a conclusive report with which I could be satisfied, if indeed the job could be done at all so many years after the events in question. The Committee accepted my recommendation that the inquiry be wound up. In making this decision, the Committee had regard for the fact that the matter had not been referred to it by the Senate but had been adopted by the Committee of its own volition under a standing reference. It would have been possible quietly to allow the inquiry to lapse but I thought it proper to make a firm decision before the end of this Parliament and to advise the Senate and interested parties. I think it desirable that I explain the basis of the decision and give some background on the inquiry and the issues examined.
Background to the Inquiry

The inquiry began in 1982, when the Committee, then called the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, was chaired by Senator Peter Rae. It followed a 1981 Committee report on the affairs of the Australian Dairy Corporation and a submission subsequently received by Senator Rae from an Indonesian citizen who was involved in litigation with the ADC. The litigation concerned an attempt by the ADC to sell the 50 per cent shareholding it held in the Indonesian company PT Indomilk. An initial delay in the Committee's inquiry occurred with the 1983 election in which the Government changed, as did the membership and chair of the Committee. Although the new Committee decided to continue the inquiry, it immediately encountered difficulty because cases were current in both the Indonesian and Australian courts which bore directly on the subject of the inquiry. After delaying for 19 months, the Committee agreed to take evidence in camera, but it was clear that there would be serious difficulties in reporting before the court cases were settled. An incidental effect of the litigation was to prevent the ADC, including the departmental nominee on the Board, from discussing certain matters with the Minister for Primary Industry. The Committee was thus placed in the unusual position of taking in camera evidence from officials on matters they were not free to discuss with their Minister.

There were other difficulties in the evidence gathering. Firstly, the ADC strenuously sought delay and/or a high degree of confidentiality in the Committee's inquiry because it was engaged in commercially sensitive negotiations on the sale of its PT Indomilk shareholding. Secondly, the Committee required access to records of the Department of Foreign Affairs and the then Minister for Foreign Affairs was concerned-very properly as the Committee accepted-to preserve the confidentiality of that material. The Committee therefore took most evidence in camera and gave assurances that it would not be released without due notice and consideration of continuing commercial and national interests.

A further problem arose when a former senior officer of the Department of Primary Industry who had been significantly involved at the time of the attempted sale of the PT Indomilk shares was unable to give oral evidence to the Committee for medical reasons. Although the Committee obtained written answers from the officer to some of its questions, that procedure cannot be regarded as satisfactory.

The evidence gathered by the Committee and its staff between 1982 and 1988 comprises transcripts of one short public hearing and 14 hours of in camera hearings as well as copies of official and other documents totalling several thousand pages. Consideration of this evidence by the Committee was disrupted by two more elections and extensive changes in Committee membership and staff. Also, the Committee continued to receive many new references from the Senate over the period and initiated further inquiries under its standing references. This new work repeatedly diverted the Committee's resources and interests away from the PT Indomilk inquiry.

I am now the only member of the Committee who was a member when the inquiry began. Senator Black, who was present at the last of the Committee's hearings in September 1985, is the only other current member of the Committee to have attended any hearing in the inquiry. We have been assisted by four permanent Committee secretaries and one acting secretary over the period. Further, since 1981, there has been a complete change in the board membership and substantial changes in senior staffing of the ADC. Other changes to the institutional environment occurred with the reforms to statutory marketing authorities implemented by the Government since January 1986.
Decision not to Report

The Committee persisted with its review of this matter for as long as it did, largely at my insistence, because some aspects of the evidence raised concerns and because we did not wish to waste the already substantial investment of time and effort. We finally reached the decision not to report with great reluctance. That decision was based on three considerations.

Firstly, we believe that the Government's reforms to statutory marketing authorities reduce the scope for future problems of the type encountered by the ADC. That is, what would have been our recommendations for the future has already been implemented.

Secondly, it would be an extremely difficult and time consuming exercise for the current Committee members to familiarise themselves with the large volume of complex evidence collected when there was a different membership and different staff. The potential benefits of a full report would be unlikely to justify the necessary effort, and the time until a report could be tabled would extend even further into the future.

Thirdly, and very importantly, although the evidence raises concern about the wisdom and propriety of actions by certain individuals, the lapse of time and procedural problems related to some of the collection of evidence would make it very difficult to report on those matters with fairness to the individuals concerned.

It would at least be necessary to call or recall certain individuals to give evidence. This process would involve questioning of witnesses on events that are now mostly eight years in the past and, in some cases, as old as 13 years. In the case of witnesses recalled to give evidence, the gap between their first and last appearances would be of the order of five years. I do not consider that the benefits of producing a definitive history of the PT Indomilk affair would justify the risks of unfairness to some of the individuals involved. But, within the limits imposed by the last consideration, I would like to outline briefly the circumstances reviewed by the Committee and draw some general conclusions.
Summary of Events

PT Indomilk was one of several subsidiary companies established in various Asian countries by the Australian Dairy Produce Board in the late 1960s and early 1970s in developing new markets for Australian dairy products. The capital for the Asian subsidiaries was supplied from the Dairying Industry Stabilisation Fund, that is from industry rather than public sources. The Dairy Board and its successor, the Australian Dairy Corporation, subsequently experienced difficulties in the management of several of these companies and its general performance was criticised in the 1981 report of this Committee which also foreshadowed a closer examination of the Indonesian subsidiary.

PT Indomilk was a company set up under Indonesian Law pursuant to a joint venture between the Dairy Board and a local company, NV Marison. The joint venture agreement gave the Dairy Board a majority shareholding in, and control of, the company. But there was provision for Marison to lift its holding to 50 per cent if arrangements could be made to retain Dairy Board control of the joint venture.

PT Indomilk was the first manufacturer of reconstituted milk products in Indonesia and was initially profitable. But by 1976 competition from other joint ventures and some operational difficulties were beginning to emerge. In that year, however, the ADC sold to its partner sufficient shares to give Marison an equal shareholding in PT Indomilk. The conditions of sale of the shares to Marison purported to retain ADC control through a voting trust in respect of one share. But the ADC had legal advice at the time that the trust was of doubtful validity under Indonesian law. The ADC's legal advisers in fact expressed strong initial opposition to the sale and the reasons for the Corporation's decision to proceed are unclear.

After the sale of shares, PT Indomilk suffered further financial reverses and there were serious disputes between the Australian and Indonesian partners. By 1981 PT Indomilk had fallen far into arrears in its payment for Australian raw materials and the ADC risked a large financial loss if the company had collapsed.

In September 1981 the ADC received a very generous offer from one of PT Indomilk's Indonesian competitors for the ADC's 50 per cent holding in the joint venture. Although the Dairy Produce Act required ministerial approval for a contract of that size, a sale agreement was signed by ADC representatives. The agreement obliged the ADC to seek approval for the sale both from the Australian authorities and from a shareholders' meeting of PT Indomilk. The ADC representatives negotiated the sale in conditions of considerable secrecy, being aware that their Indonesian partner, Marison, was likely to object. It was clear from the beginning that there would be difficulties in obtaining the approval of a PT Indomilk shareholders' meeting.

The ADC devised a strategy which mainly involved generating publicity in Indonesia, that would, it hoped, deter Marison and the Indonesian authorities from blocking the sale. In fact, Marison objected strenuously to the sale and the Indonesian authorities, in accordance with their well-established practice, required the agreement of both existing partners before approving the share sale. Australian diplomatic and trade representatives in Jakarta and their departments in Canberra became involved in the issue at this point, conveying information between some of the parties and expressing certain opinions on the ADC's sale strategy.

The then Minister for Primary Industry, Peter Nixon, advised the ADC that he would not grant his approval to the sale, required under the Dairy Produce Act unless he had an assurance that the Indonesian Government would give its approval to the share transfer. The ADC subsequently abandoned its attempt to conclude the sale. The ADC argued that any losses incurred as a result of its withdrawal from the sale agreement should be borne by the Commonwealth. The ADC representatives maintained that their failure to conclude the sale resulted from intervention by the Minister, his Department and Foreign Affairs and Trade representatives. The former Government rejected that claim and the present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, has also rejected it.

Negotiations between the ADC, Marison and other parties in 1982 led to the ADC signing a considerably less generous agreement with a different Indonesian buyer acceptable to Marison. The first prospective buyer then sued the ADC, seeking compliance with the original agreement. The matter was finally settled in 1987 when a third Indonesian buyer, a subsidiary of a large commercial and financial group which had earlier taken over Marison, succeeded in purchasing the ADC interest in a settlement agreeable to all parties to the litigation. This settlement was endorsed by the Indonesian authorities.

The terms of the sale effectively handed the ADC shares to the purchaser in return for the latter paying most of the debt owed by PT Indomilk for supply of Australian raw materials. Fortuitous movements in exchange rates cushioned the financial loss to the Australian dairy industry but the Australian holding in PT Indomilk, which the ADC had previously written down to a value of $1, was effectively given away, though raw material supply agreements continued.
Issues of Concern

This summary of the events gives only some idea of how complex were the issues in the inquiry. The evidence taken by the Committee raised four areas of concern that the Committee might have addressed had it continued with this inquiry. Firstly, it is clear in hindsight that the 1976 sale of shares was a costly error. The Committee heard of serious allegations concerning the propriety of that sale and such allegations were also made by a member in the House of Representatives on 5 April 1984. There is no documentation in support of the claims. There has been a total change in senior personnel and extensive institutional reform at the ADC since 1976. Given the public criticisms already made by this Committee and others of the former board and management of the ADC, there would be little value in pursuing these allegations to the end, if, indeed, it were possible to do so.

Secondly, there is concern about the wisdom and propriety of ADC actions during the 1981 sale attempt. I do not consider it unfair to say that the whole basis of the sales strategy was and is open to question. It was, at best, a high risk strategy and the possibility exists that the ADC representatives were misled into actions that ultimately damaged the ADC's interests. There appear to have been procedural lapses during the sale attempt, some of which I consider to have been serious. In particular, the whole sale strategy was kept secret within a small group of ADC officers and members to a degree which I regard as unwise if not improper.

However, to report fully on this issue while being completely fair to everyone concerned would have involved the Committee in significant additional work. The lapse of time and difficulties with some of the documentation would probably have made it impossible to resolve the issue in a fair manner. I do not consider that the effort involved in fully investigating this complex matter would produce commensurate benefits given the changes in the ADC board and management since 1981.

The third major area of concern relates to the actions of the then Minister and the three Public Service departments involved. This was of particular relevance because of the claims for government compensation to the dairy industry that were pushed for some years after the first sale attempt. The ADC's good fortune with exchange rates has removed the pressure for compensation. My own reading of the evidence suggests that any revival of such pressure would be a forlorn hope. I would be most surprised if any comprehensive review of that aspect of the debacle were to support the claim that government or bureaucratic intervention was crucial to the failure of the sale.

I believe that it could be argued that some interventions by the then Minister and three executive departments in the affairs of the ADC, a statutory authority, were unwise and procedurally flawed. But I judge these to have been irrelevant to the outcome; I believe the sale attempt was doomed from the start. Repetition of such interventions, I believe, would be precluded by the Kerin reforms to statutory marketing authorities. The notion that statutory authorities are open to private or informal dabbling by Ministers or departments should now be dead.

It is probably fair to note here that Ministers and departments normally deal with more than one issue at a time, often under extreme pressure. On the same day that Peter Nixon acceded to the ADC's sale strategy, for example, the Committee's highly critical report on the administration of the ADC was tabled. In the same week, his Government was establishing a royal commission into the Australia meat industry following a breakdown in the administration of meat inspection by the Minister's Department.

In evidence to that Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems, Mr Nixon was critical of the lack of professionalism in his Department. The Royal Commission subsequently found the criticism to be justified but also criticised the Minister. I suspect that the findings of the Royal Commission about the situation in the Primary Industry portfolio in 1981-82 would be reinforced by the events surrounding the ministerial and bureaucratic interventions in the PT Indomilk sale. There seems little point, however, in now exploring the past failings of organisations that have since undergone extensive change.

The fourth significant issue that I see as arising from this sorry story relates to accountability to Parliament. The versions of some events given to the Committee by certain individuals at in camera hearings contained contradictions. Honest mistakes and disagreements may account for some of the discrepancies. Evidence by some individuals, when compared to official file documents, also suggested that those persons, while not being untruthful, had been less than fully forthcoming with the Committee.

It is crucial to the operations of the Senate and its committees that witnesses give truthful and complete answers to questions. The Committee took its evidence in camera and gave reasonable undertakings regarding subsequent use of that evidence precisely so that witnesses could speak fully and frankly. I believe that we were unusually considerate and scrupulous in that regard. The attitude of some witnesses is all the more disappointing for that reason. I cannot say, however, that I consider any actions by witnesses to have been so serious as to justify further action by the Senate. Lapse of time as well as the complexity of the issues involved would, in any case, make an investigation of this matter very difficult and probably fruitless.
The Committee's Role

I feel obliged to say that the outcome of this inquiry reflects to some extent on me and the Committee as well as on the agencies and officials involved. It is clear in hindsight that this inquiry, if it was to be resolved at all, should have been settled well before this. I could have done it, but only if I had had no other duties in the Senate or in the electorate. However, the whole situation was not conducive to an early and full report on the affair. That we did not report resulted partly from changes in Committee membership and staffing, partly from the pressure of other work and partly from a concern to ensure the rights of individuals to a just hearing. It also should be emphasised that events continued to unfold during the period. I do believe, however, that the Committee's inquiry was one of several catalysts to beneficial change in the Australian Dairy Corporation.

I would like to thank all those members and former members of the Committee and current and previous staff, certain of whom laboured mightily on the inquiry of various times during the last seven years. It was a massive task. I have agonised about this matter for years. I wish that, instead of pressing on, I had canned the inquiry at the one or two appropriate points during recent years at which that could have been done. So it is with a mixture of disappointment and relief that I have made this statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health Amendment Bill 1989 is a very simple and short Bill. It merely increases a patient's contribution for pharmaceutical prescriptions from $11 to $12 and indexes the contribution according to, I presume, future rises in the consumer price index. Before the debate was interrupted by the suspension of the Senate for lunch, we had discussed the tormented state in which pharmacists find themselves at present as a result of the Government's administration in recent years, particularly recent months. Previous speakers gave a very detailed account of the many problems that pharmacists face and referred to their ability to carry on.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a wide scattergun attack on the health industry in general. Earlier this year pharmacists were attacked when their prescriptions fees were reduced by 10c a time. That measure taken by the Government was challenged in the courts and the Government lost the case. Similarly, pathologists came under attack. Half the items on their schedule were crossed off unilaterally by the Government. They had to take the challenge to the court and they won their case. The arbitrary cost-cutting measures taken by the Government over recent months have created no end of havoc in the industry. As I have said before in the Senate, this kind of thing is to be expected because the Government promises that health care will be free at the point of delivery, which creates an unlimited demand for its services, but it has a limited budget with which to satisfy the unlimited demand. The two cannot meet. As the budget gets spent and the demand goes up the two move away from each other and create no end of dissatisfaction among not only patients but also doctors, pharmacists, hospitals, administrators and nursing staff. There is dissatisfaction throughout. That is the position in which the whole industry finds itself. In the Senate today we are discussing the tumult that exists in the pharmacy industry.

As I said before, the Bill is a trifling one. The Opposition does not oppose it. However, we are moving an amendment in relation to the decision made by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal last August. As has come out in the debate here, the Tribunal was acting under Government instruction to reduce the cost of dispensing pharmaceuticals by about $20m or $30m. It used a survey of pharmacists' practices which was entirely inadequate. Only 53 of the 5,600 or so pharmacists in Australia were surveyed. Less than one per cent of pharmacists were surveyed. In spite of the fact that there were some telephone surveys to follow it up, which undoubtedly would have been inaccurate-they are noted for that-the Tribunal went ahead and recommended a further reduction in dispensing fees to pharmacists.

Socialist governments are always putting their professional people under attack-not only doctors but everyone who contributes to the intellectual development of the society in which he lives. Probably socialists realise that they need these people to run the economy, so they try to get them working for the government. In the present case the pharmacists have finally realised that this is the last straw. Only within the last couple of weeks they closed their shops for an afternoon across the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Strike.

—It was not exactly a strike as their shops were open for the rest of the day. They withdrew their labour for a couple of hours one afternoon to show the degree of their protest, hoping that the Government would take some notice of the plight to which they had been reduced. Pharmacists are professional people and some of the extra services which they provide have been mentioned today. For example, they give advice on drugs-prescribed medications by doctors-particularly to the elderly.
—They have a very hard job.

—It is a responsible job. An interesting question posed today was how the reduction in pharmacy incomes will affect women because women are more involved in the industry than anybody else. Women comprise 80 per cent of pharmacists' customers and 80 per cent of the people employed in pharmacies. These figures are quite revealing. Here we have a government which regards itself as enlightened and progressive in women's issues, yet it is taking action which disadvantages women a lot more than men.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we heard in the debate that pharmacists do not generate huge costs in the dispensing of pharmaceuticals; they merely dispense the prescriptions that are written by doctors. If we had one pharmacy or one million pharmacies in Australian dispensing the same number of prescriptions, the cost would be the same. I notice that the Government is taking action in another way, perhaps to help with the reduction in the number of prescriptions that are written. A Bill which recently passed through the Senate for the vocational registration of general practitioners was brought in because doctors were supposed to be writing too many prescriptions, and writing too many prescriptions for expensive drugs, referring too many patients to specialists, and referring too many people for tests and X-rays. When this whole concerted attack gets going perhaps that will help with the reduction in pharmaceutical costs. None of this is designed to produce better health care for the people. The Government is taking a restrictive cost-cutting action which has nothing to do with better health for the patients who form the main part of the health system and provide the reason why the whole organisation exists.

Pharmacy operations have been squeezed more and more. Honourable senators would have noticed that many pharmacies are now looking more like supermarkets than dispensaries. In fact, pharmacists have been reduced to the role of spruikers standing outside their shops with microphones selling their wares. I nearly said `hawking their wares' but I would not want to introduce any pun in this debate. Pharmacists have been turned into spruikers and pushers and pedlars of pills. They have come under considerable attack from the Government as if they were a bunch of money-grubbers who were not interested in their patients.

This same argument has been used against the doctors. The Government has confused the argument. It has referred to an increase in patient rebates as an increase in salaries for doctors. It is not. The patients are getting the rebates, not the doctors. The same applies to this legislation. The increase in patients' contributions from $11 to $12 will not increase the chemist's remuneration one bit; all that money goes to the Government. It is just an additional tax. As I mentioned earlier in my speech, it is tax on the people who are sick; the people who will require medication.

We have now reached the crucial point where the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal has made an inadequately low assessment of dispensing fees, based on an inadequate survey, that will disrupt our entire pharmacy network throughout Australia. The Government has talked about wanting to rationalise the industry. It has said that we have too many pharmacies and it wants uneconomic pharmacies to close. A pharmacy which might be marginally economic could still be a very busy pharmacy, particularly if it is in an area where there are a lot of pensioners. It might be a busy pharmacy which is not making big profits but is providing a good service. Similarly, there could be pharmacies that are marginally economic in country areas but the chemist is prepared to provide a service because he wants to do a professional job. But those pharmacies in particular will be the first to go under the stringent rules that the Government is applying to chemists at the moment. That will cause no end of dislocation. Honourable senators on both sides must have been heavily lobbied by pharmacists on that issue of the closure of pharmacies alone. Of course, the single pharmacy town will be terribly disadvantaged if these low remuneration figures are implemented.

As a matter of fact, from the time when this debate was interrupted until now, I have received a letter from the chemist at the Health Spot Pharmacy at Lismore. That chemist is going on a week's holiday. Before doing that he has to employ, by law, a locum pharmacist to cover for him. She will be paid $19 an hour-I notice that the Remuneration Tribunal puts pharmacists' wages at $14 an hour-for a 58-hour week which will be a total of $1,100 for the week. She has to be assisted by a part-time dispensary assistant who will be paid $203 for a 24-hour week. The rent for a dispensary size area of 25 square metres is $296 a week. Other sundry expenses shared between the shop and the dispensary, such as electricity, will come to approximately $275 a week. On average, the locum pharmacist should dispense nine scripts an hour which represents about 522 for the week. At $3.50 remuneration per prescription, as determined by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, income from dispensing for the week will be $1,827. However, as the expenses which I have mentioned will come to $1,876, that will represent a loss of $49 for the week. On top of this the chemist has to run a computer, put in at his expense to improve his productivity and enhance the service to his customers. He has to maintain a dispensary stock costing $17,000 in order to provide an adequate supply of prescription items for consumers. The letter from the chemist provides a practical example of what happens. This chemist knows that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal does not want to reduce him to that degree of penury. Chemists know that the Tribunal, which has been acting under orders from the Government, has come up with an unrealistic recommendation.

The cost effects of high cost drugs have been mentioned. Certainly pharmaceuticals are getting more sophisticated these days, but this is mainly in the area of preventive medicine-for cardiovascular reasons and metabolic disorders-which will keep people out of hospital and delay the onset of severe illnesses that require expensive treatment. It costs a lot to keep these drugs on the shelves. The arrangements that the Government has come to are not really conducive to the proper practice of modern pharmaceutical dispensing. This attack on the doctors, that they should be more thoughtful in what they are prescribing-this Government does not want doctors to be more thoughtful; it wants doctors to prescribe cheaper drugs-is not conducive to the practice of good medicine.

We want to try to get this Bill through tonight. We are not opposing it but we wish to move amendments to it. I hope that the Government will come to its senses in regard to the overall administration of health in Australia because this is not the only area that is suffering because of the recurrent and persistent restrictions that the Government is placing on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the National Health Amendment Bill, which will increase maximum general patient contributions for prescribed drugs supplied under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) from $11 to $12. This is designed to take effect from 1 October. But the Bill will not affect free pharmaceutical benefits for all pensioners and the concessional beneficiary rate of $2.50, or free scripts for the chronically ill. However the Bill does provide for annual indexation of the general patient contribution in line with the March quarter all groups consumer price index.

SPEECH.PARA: I have much pleasure in supporting an amendment to be moved by my colleague Senator Puplick which would mean that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal determination will have no effect. As a result of the initiative of my Liberal colleague Senator Puplick, from New South Wales, the Government has scurried off suddenly to meet with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, and at a hastily held meeting this afternoon certain arrangements were made. It does appear that, while the Government and the Guild will make a joint submission to the Tribunal to defer the effect of the decision from 1 October to 1 November, there are some areas of dispute. On reading a joint statement put out by the Government and the Guild, it does appear that there is conflict on some features. While they both say they accept the Tribunal decision and the fact that the integrity of the Budget is to be preserved, the Guild does emphasise that it reserves the right to pursue the reinstatement of the mark-up with the Tribunal. I see these as certainly being points of conflict.

The Government has certainly expressed its displeasure about the legal actions the Guild is taking and has sought to have them withdrawn, but those legal actions will not be withdrawn unless the parties reach agreement. There are to be negotiations during October to examine the range of options for pharmaceutical remuneration-and this is an unusual term-`outside the scope of the Tribunal'. I would imagine a lot of pharmacists around Australia would be concerned about the term `outside the scope of the Tribunal'. It will be interesting to see the reaction of the mass of pharmacists who have put up such a fight to date. On the other hand, it is too early to say whether the Guild has weakened to the Government's overtures.

We have to emphasise that the objectives for the PBS today, in 1989, are not in keeping with the contemporary service requirements expected by the community. The Government has failed to acknowledge that. There is nothing in the findings of the Tribunal to encourage pharmacists to spend more time on patient counselling. Maybe it is discussion on these sorts of matters that it is intended should take place. The briefing from the Government and the Guild is not sufficiently adequate to indicate the scope of those areas of negotiation. One problem with the findings of the Tribunal is that the Government is seeking to implement a mechanism whereby pharmaceutical dispensing will effectively become a factory-type operation, like a sausage machine, with little intervention by pharmacists in an effort to provide the patient with advice on, say, preventive health care. There is certainly a myth around about the great profits in pharmacy. It is distressing to see Labor members of parliament going around the country and misrepresenting gross margins as net profit. I do not think that does their integrity any good at all. It is unfortunate that one member of this Parliament has made that misrepresentation in Tasmania.

Up till now the Government has not been prepared to acknowledge that the Tribunal has been at all wrong. It is interesting to note that Professor Barry Hughes of the University of Newcastle until 1989 was an economic adviser to Mr Keating. Some of his criticisms are quite significant. He suggests that the Tribunal has badly miscalculated the true costs of dispensing. He maintains that if pharmacies in Australia were as profitable as the Tribunal decision suggests we would see the numbers of pharmacies in this country increase rapidly as more and more pharmacists open pharmacies in order to take advantage of the profitable situation.

What has actually happened, however, is that the number of pharmacies in Australia has fallen since the early 1970s. The Australian population has increased by over 30 per cent in the same period. This shows that Australian pharmacies have had moderate incomes over nearly two decades. This is a very strong indication that the Tribunal decision is simply wrong if we examine it purely on a market forces basis, apart from the earlier misgivings I mentioned and which I will not repeat today. At least the Government has now admitted that the Tribunal's inquiry has had some major problems. But despite this it still insists that the Tribunal should reduce pharmacy dispensing fees. It strongly encourages the Tribunal to make the latest decision. I think it is very important that there was pressure on the Tribunal to make this decision which has this particular effect.

Basically up to now the Government has not given away 1c. There has been some arrangement with wholesalers. Basically that is a robbing Peter to pay Paul type principle and merely involves a change in the relaxation of wholesale margins. The promised assistance to country pharmacists will not help all pharmacists in remote areas, particularly those where there is one pharmacy right out in the middle of Australia-for example, Bourke or anywhere else-which handles more than 15,000 scripts. He is going to see his remuneration completely brought down as a result of the Tribunal's decision. This extra allowance that is going to be given for under 15,000 scripts will not be available. So the incentive to that pharmacist in the future will be to reduce his range of operations and just work a few days a week. Again, this shows that the Government does not understand how this particular scheme is working.

I was rather dismayed to see the Government obviously respond to the pharmacists' action by placing a statement in yesterday's newspapers headed `Is your local chemist leading you down the garden path?'. There was a 008 number and no authorisation. It is a pretty poor ad. When people rang this particular number the person who answered said, `I am sorry, we cannot answer your questions, sir', or madam, whoever it was, `I am just employed to take your concerns to the Minister but I have been instructed to send you a brochure that should explain everything to you'. This is just a simple brochure. When asked for the details of this brochure the standard reply was, `I am sorry, sir, I have not got it in front of me; I cannot give you any details'. What was the whole purpose of this ad? It was a facade and a fake. When people inquired a little more deeply the lass said, `It is the intention of the Government that chemist shops will not close down'. I hesitated there because those words are important.

A further inquiry revealed that in relation to the supply of needed drugs such as insulin the words used were, `There is no worry; the supply will be assured'. I would advise anybody listening to this debate that it is really up to the pharmacist to decide what range of stock he is going to hold. If there is no profit in it, or a loss, the pharmacist will be reluctant to carry the whole range. I will give an example. I understand there are three principal types of insulin available which go out of date very quickly. There is limited demand from patients, so the advice to them is, `Do not leave your requests for insulin too late because there may be some delay in availability as not all pharmacists will stock the whole range in future because of the low profitability and the fact that they go out of date quickly, et cetera'. It was disconcerting that the people at the other end of the telephone were unable to answer people's concerns adequately, despite the fact that people were asked to ring up. When asked to give examples of where our local pharmacist could be leading us down the garden path, the answer was, `I am sorry, sir, we do not have any examples. I cannot answer your question but I will pass on your concern to the Minister because that is what I am employed to do'.
This is a very unsatisfactory situation. The whole thing is quite misleading. I now refer to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal's database inquiry statement. Item 13 states:
Finally it has been recommended that there should be an inquiry-
another inquiry-
undertaken to consider an appropriate re-structure of pharmacy outlets with the object of achieving greater efficiency and reduced cost of dispensing.

After all these findings based on flawed data, what sort of confidence will that give to pharmacists? That does not even suggest who will conduct that inquiry. The whole thing has been handled very badly. As it stands, the decision will directly affect the level and standard of service that pharmacists provide and that people have come to expect across Australia. Under the new scale of charges, some pharmacists will lose money if they dispense some of the more expensive drugs. No reasonable person could expect a pharmacist in future to stock the whole range of an item such as insulin that I mentioned earlier.

The sad fact is that not only will incomes be cut; employees will be retrenched. Those pharmacists who do not go out of business, those who remain, will have to trim their variable costs. Of course, labour is the first component to be affected. One Tasmanian pharmacist has estimated that, on average, one full time worker, whether it be in the form of a locum pharmacist or pharmacy assistant, will have to be retrenched from each of the 153 businesses involved. At this point, I should perhaps indicate that I have an interest in this matter. My wife is a locum pharmacist. Certainly, she is concerned about the future welfare of the pharmacy business in Australia. I spoke to her this afternoon and she said that she has been inundated today by people concerned about the impact that these changes will have on their medication and its timely availability.

I conclude by saying that the Government is now starting to respond to pressure. The Opposition has had a small victory with the Tribunal's having revised part of last month's ruling which appeared to threaten supplies of vital but expensive drugs, such as insulin for diabetics. The mechanisms still have not been spelt out adequately. It is not surprising that the pharmacists have taken to the streets because this whole thing is a disaster for community pharmacists. In fact, it is an outrage against the community. The Government is responsible because it urged the Tribunal to take this course. It is now up to the Government, having taken this initiative, to try to meet with the pharmacists to negotiate an honourable way out of this. I commend the action of my colleague Senator Puplick who has forced the hand of the Government, which until now has said that it is independent and that the matter is out of its control. The action of the Liberal Party has forced the Government to make a decision on this Tribunal. We have seen the Government today for the first time, having had initial discussions with the Guild, wanting to try to meet some of the concerns. I certainly hope that the Guild has not been conned, but I certainly look forward to a satisfactory resolution of this very unsatisfactory public relations campaign by both the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples, and the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly in support of my colleagues on the National Health Amendment Bill. I am pleased to see that the Australian Democrats are supporting us in this matter. I want to take up a short time of the Senate just to reiterate some of the concerns in this matter that have been put to me over the last few months, and particularly in the last couple of weeks, in my own State. I have heard tonight that the Federal Court has set down a hearing on this matter for 9 October .As a result of the action taken by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia over the cuts Mr Justice Jenkinson set the date, having been told that the case was urgent. It certainly is urgent. The concerns of the pharmacists and the people who use pharmacists for their primary health care and rely on them so much are being expressed, and they severely criticise the Government. It is because of this that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples, and the Government are looking at the matter again.

SPEECH.PARA: One does not need to be reminded of the action of the pharmacists. Last weekend, in an unprecedented move, pharmacists took to the streets in the marginal seat of Denison in Tasmania. I do not recall any action like this being taken before. It was a protest about the cosmetic changes being made on the run by the Government over this matter. There has been the flagging of the $5m rural subsidy and the recent announcement of discussions with wholesalers over surcharges on drugs. But the basic question relates to keeping these pharmacies open, particularly in rural areas.

I travelled around Tasmania last week and spoke to pharmacists, particularly on the east coast of Tasmania. For those honourable senators who do not know much about the east coast, it is primarily a very nice area for people to retire to. I would hazard a guess that over 50 per cent of the people who live on the east coast of Tasmania are people who chose to go there for their retirement. There are three or four pharmacists in the whole area. If any one of those pharmacies closed, it would mean those retired people having to rely on mail order pharmacies for their drugs. That is not good enough. These particular people are not very well served by either pharmacies or other health care sources.

As has been said by Senator Sheil, a bushfire is raging out there as result of the length of time this attack on the pharmacists has been going on. First, pharmacists were required to change to computer-based payments systems. If they did not change, payments were going to be delayed. They are still being delayed. When I went around the State last week I heard many complaints about delays in payment. Fifty-three drugs have come off the pharmaceutical benefits list to be replaced by generic brands, and that in itself has had an effect on old people. The latest action of reducing dispensing fees is the final nail in the coffin.

When one talks to pharmacists, as I did at Beaconsfield, St Helens, Bicheno, Swansea and Triabunna, one finds that they are all concerned about the fact that they are required to keep such a large stock of drugs at no cost to the Government. They are required to keep $20,000 or $30,000 worth of drugs so that they can provide the primary health care that people have come to expect over the years.

One only has to look at local papers to see the letters from ex-pharmacists refuting claims made by the Government. For instance, the honourable member for Denison, Mr Kerr, stated that pharmacists have an average net income of $98,000. This was refuted quite strongly by Tony Wiss from Lindisfarne. He estimated that a 50-hour week produced a net income of between $24,000 and $38,000. Geoff Deacon from Lindisfarne queried the fact that the Government could find $60m for Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd but it could not find a few million dollars to support the pharmacists who look after the old people in our community. Mr Ian Huett, a Deloraine chemist, rang me about a terrible problem of a person requiring insulin. If it had not been for the fact that he had put in a computer at his own cost and had a record of who was receiving insulin in his district, there is a good chance that a life would have been lost. The Harley Johnstone Pharmacy at Penguin on the north-west coast said it will close next May unless the Federal Government defers its decision. Ralph Tapping, one of our leading pharmacists and spokesmen in Hobart, made the point that the aim of the doorknock was to ensure that Mr Kerr knew how seriously the move to reduce payments for prescriptions would impact on the community.

Finally, one of our better known pharmacists, Kevin Corby, who has moved to Cygnet, publicly stated that he earned $84,000 and was left with an income of $26,000. They are the types of comments being made. They make no sense at all of the Government's arguments that pharmacists are well paid. I support the other speakers supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the National Health Amendment Bill and an amendment to be moved by Senator Puplick. The Government is totally confused in this matter. The second reading speech of the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) tells us that the patient contribution will rise from $11 to $12. This is estimated to achieve a saving of $10m in 1989-90 and $17m in a full financial year, allowing for indexation. Either the Minister's figures are wrong or he expects a lot more sickness in the coming year because, allowing for indexation, next year's saving should be around $14.63m, not $17m.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the heading `Financial Impact Statement' in the explanatory memorandum of the Bill. Again, it states that this increase is estimated to achieve a saving of $10m in 1989-90. But then it states that with indexation of the patient contribution, estimated savings are $35m in 1990-91, $55m in 1991-92 and $78m in 1992-93. Unless there is to be a great upsurge in sickness in the next few years, I need someone to explain those figures to me; I am in total confusion. The hardest hit will be the country pharmacists-not those in the large remote areas but those in the small remote areas. For example, there are 1,200 people in my town with a total of 3,000 people in the district. We have a small pharmacy, which will not survive even with a subsidy. The closest pharmacy will then be 100 kilometres away. These are the sorts of pharmacies that will be affected the most. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am advised of the contributions made by honourable senators in debate on the National Health Amendment Bill. I thank all honourable senators who have seized the opportunity to make known their views on pharmaceutical benefits in Australia. This is a Budget Bill and, as such, has connotations for revenue. Therefore, some of the remarks that have been made are not directly relevant or pertinent to the purposes of the Bill. However, it is necessary to indicate that while this debate has been afoot, there have been further discussions between my colleague, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Peter Staples, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. As a consequence of those talks today, the ideal of further discussion yielding a productive result has to some extent been achieved. A statement was issued this afternoon by Peter Staples which it would be appropriate for me to read into the record. It is headed `Pharmacy Breakthrough' and it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Federal Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Peter Staples, today welcomed agreement with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia which paves the way for a resolution of the current remuneration dispute.

Mr Staples said that following announcements in the last few days regarding the Essential Pharmacy Allowance and the removal of surcharges on high cost drugs, today's development further supports the Government's commitment to maintain the provision of medications to the community through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

In those circumstances, it is entirely appropriate that the legislation before the chamber be enacted. Perhaps for the sake of completeness, I should--

TALK.START.PARA: —Our amendment is to keep you honest.
—I would like to dissuade the Opposition from moving that amendment, not because it would keep us honest-we are manifestly honest-but because the amendment--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—This is a serious interchange, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—I note the interjections. All honourable senators, including the honourable senator on his feet, should direct their remarks through the Chair even when responding to interjections.

—Through you, sir, I respond to the interjection. I hope that the amendment is not moved, but it is up to the Opposition whether it is moved. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have sought leave to move both of the Opposition amendments together because they are integral, one actually inserting a clause and the other one relating to the date of the commencement of the clause. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, clause 2, lines 7 and 8, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Commencement
``2. (1) Subject to subsection (2), this Act commences on 1 October 1989.
``(2) Section 6 shall be deemed to have commenced on 30 September 1989.''.
(2) Page 3, after clause 5, add the following new clause:
PBRT determination to have no effect
``6. The determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal dated 28 August 1989 and made under section 98b of the Principal Act is and shall be of no force or effect.''.

The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) has correctly drawn attention to the fact that some progress has been made today in the discussions between the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I believe that those discussions took place as a result of the initiative taken by the Opposition, supported by the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine today, that we would proceed with amending this legislation. There are slight but insignificant differences between the statement which the Minister has read and the statement issued by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. I make only two comments about them. The first is that in the press release issued this afternoon by the Pharmacy Guild the President of the Guild, Mr Matthews, indicated that the Guild had not been persuaded by the Government to withdraw its pending legal proceedings in this matter, and the second is that the Guild emphasised that it reserved the right to pursue the reinstatement of mark-ups and presumably other issues with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal.

We welcome those negotiations. We recognise that they have occurred as a result of the pressure which the Senate has put on the Government. We do not, of course, know what, if anything, will arise from those discussions. The legal action is still on foot. We believe that the passage of this amendment, striking down the determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal dated 28 August 1989 and made under section 98b of the principal Act, the National Health Act 1953, is necessary because it will restore the playing field to the level of being an even playing field. In other words, if no satisfactory result is achieved by these negotiations, if we do not pursue this amendment, the Government stands with a club over the head of the pharmacists-the determination of the Tribunal. If, however, nothing arises as a result of those negotiations and this amendment has been passed, we are back to an even playing field and the determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal will have been struck down.

We intend to pursue the amendments because we believe that we should take away from the Government the threat that no progress means the maintenance of the Tribunal decision, that we should bring about a situation where the threat is against the Government, and that no agreement means that the pharmacists are not the losers in the whole process. I have moved the amendments. I commend them to the Senate. I trust they will receive the support of the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine. I believe that all of the arguments about the substantive merits of the amendments were adequately canvassed on the last occasion that this matter was before this chamber and I shall not repeat them further.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will continue their support for the amendments moved by the Opposition to the National Health Amendment Bill 1989. Clearly, if the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and the Government are engaged in negotiations regarding changing the nature of remuneration for pharmacists under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme the Tribunal's determination will be altered in some sense. In that case I cannot understand the Government's inability to recognise that, in accepting these amendments-and I hope it will accept them when this Bill reaches the House of Representatives-it is clearing the way for an open negotiation with the Pharmacy Guild. I was surprised to hear this afternoon that Mr Staples-I hope he did not mean it-told one of my colleagues that nothing would change during the month's negotiations in relation to the Tribunal's determination. Clearly, one cannot go into negotiations over a period of a month with a mind closed against the possibility of changing some or all of the elements of that determination. For those reasons I think the Government's position is illogical. I hope it sees reason and will come round to supporting these amendments when this Bill reaches the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to reinforce all that has been said by Senator Puplick and Senator Coulter. SPEECH.PARA: Given the announcement that has been made today following discussions between the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the announcement by Senator Cook in the dying stages of this debate, if the Government is genuine in its announcement that negotiations are to be held over the coming month, it has nothing to lose by agreeing to the amendments moved by the Opposition. TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my intention to delay the Committee. The issues have been canvassed both within this chamber and outside it. The Government is committed to the integrity of its Budget parameters. The savings lost because of this action-the action in delaying the adjustment of the payment to $12-will have to be deducted from the amount that would otherwise have been available to pharmacists. Pharmacists will only have the Opposition and the Democrats in this place to blame if there is an additional loss to remuneration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to speak further about the all-women's scientific expedition to Cooper Creek. I mentioned this matter in the Senate a couple of weeks ago because at that stage I wanted to inform the Senate that such an expedition was taking place and also to inform the Senate of my regret at being unable to join those women. However, over the weekend I was able to take the opportunity to go to Cooper Creek and join the expedition as it started its scientific work in the desert. This seemed to me to be a matter of considerable importance and I could not miss the opportunity of telling the Senate about the pleasure and interest that I had in being able to join those women at their camp at one of the bores not too far from Cooper Creek.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is very important that we celebrate and acknowledge the achievements of women in all fields of endeavour but particularly in the area of science where the work of women is so often overlooked. I have heard it said in this place and I certainly read in the newspaper very often that Australia has no women scientists. That is certainly not the case. I know from my own experience of very many capable women in the fields of all sorts of science. In particular on this occasion I want to talk about the women who have met to explore scientific questions about botany, aquatic botany, archaeology, anthropology, biology, geology and ecology, to name just a few of the areas of scientific investigation by the expedition in the Cooper Creek basin.

As I said before, that expedition is being led by Major Fran Conlyn. There are 44 women in all, a number of whom are senior and significant scientists from around Australia. A number of women joined the expedition as explorers; that is to say, they are not scientific experts necessarily but they will be assisting the scientists in their work. The women were aged from 22 years to 65 years. They possess a range of skills and talents in one place that will be of great benefit to the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the South Australian Museum, which are both sponsoring the work being done. We have to appreciate that the expedition is doing very significant and serious scientific work.

The other great benefit of our trip was that we were able to go and watch the headwaters of the Cooper Creek advancing down the dry river bed some two miles above the Birdsville Track. I believe that today or tomorrow the waters will be cutting the Birdsville Track in northern central South Australia. Senator Panizza corrected me in this place the last time I spoke about this matter. He said that the waters had already reached Lake Eyre. I am pleased to be able to tell Senator Panizza that that was not the case this time as I was there as the water was advancing down the dry creek bed and Lake Eyre has filled from the south lake and from local rains far more than it has from the waters of the Cooper Creek that have not yet reached Lake Eyre.

The mystery of the water and the whole flow of water in the Cooper Creek is still up for grabs. Nobody quite knows how it does happen. The rains that fell in the Channel Country in Queensland last Easter are now the waters that are flowing down through South Australia to Lake Eyre. Why that water continues to advance to Lake Eyre without either seeping into the ground or being lost by evaporation is still something of a scientific wonder, if not a mystery. It is quite interesting to watch the waters advance. They do not burst, gush or flood along; in fact, they are best described as creeping. It may be that the number of lakes, lagoons and side flows that the creek waters venture into does prevent a gush of water. It was again very interesting to watch this very slow creeping progress of water that once fell in Queensland and is now about to flow into Lake Eyre and benefit the wildlife, to say nothing of the local area, in South Australia.

I think it is also very interesting to note that the last time the waters crossed the Birdsville Track was in 1974. It is very significant that some 15 years later we have had sufficient rains in Queensland and central Australia for this event to happen again. It is quite a significant or momentous occasion for those of us who were there and able to appreciate the piece of history that we were watching.

I would also like to advise the Senate of the fact that the talents the women brought to this group were not only scientific. Amongst the group were women with artistic skills, so there is a painter and a drawer. There were also a number of women with musical skills, so it was very entertaining around the campfire at night. There were writers, lawyers and a photographer and of course the skills of logistics, organisation and administration that are so necessary to transport 44 women in at least six different directions, maintaining four-wheel drivers and Unimogs and all the necessary back-up equipment and, in particular, the provision of water that is so critical in the desert at any time, but certainly at this time.

We were able to enjoy the hospitality and support of the Oldfield family-Mary and Kevin in particular-who maintain the Mungeranie roadhouse on the Birdsville Track. A lovely sign outside says, `Last pub in South Australia'. That is presuming that one is going north on the Birdsville Track and heading towards Birdsville. Those people are also a back-up support for the Royal Flying Doctor Service. For those of us who had the opportunity to get out into rural and isolated Australia, I think that we can acknowledge the importance of the people maintaining the Flying Doctor Service and the back-up support-the people on the ground who see that facilities such as airfields are maintained as well as petrol supplies and other resources that might be needed in that area. Many of those people are unsung heroes and heroines in the maintenance of this great country. I certainly want to place on record their contribution. I appreciated very much meeting the Oldfields at their roadhouse. They had a very likely bunch of visitors while we were there, too, but I will not take the Senate's time describing all the visitors in detail.

In particular, I congratulate Major Fran Conlyn and the other women who have gone to the bother of organising and carrying out this expedition on behalf of a serious scientific investigation that will benefit the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the South Australian Museum. As I said, it is important that we acknowledge the contribution of women as scientists in this country. It is very often overlooked and, if not overlooked, it is disregarded. We have had a wonderful group of scientists in Australia-inventors, designers and planners-many of whom have been women. The fact that they are written out of the history books or not celebrated sufficiently is no reason for that to continue to be the case. It is for those reasons that I am particularly pleased to have had the opportunity to have joined the expedition, albeit it very briefly, and to tell the Senate and place on record an acknowledgment of the achievements of women in science in Australia.

It is also very important to promote science and maths for girls in Australia. We have a special project, which was instituted by the Federal Labor Government and picked up by a number of State governments, to encourage girls to consider maths and science as alternatives to the career plans they might have thought of. We can encourage young girls to consider those fields of study by letting them know the sorts of exciting opportunities those fields can present, the exciting questions they can ask and the areas of investigation they can develop. For many reasons it is important that we recognise and acknowledge this all-women expedition into the desert and in particular that we celebrate their achievements. I will be looking forward to the report from the expedition. It will remind young women and girls that there are opportunities there for the taking in this splendid country.
