TALK.START.PARA: —It is well recognised in history that from the Great War of 1914-18 a certain Australian character was born that has influenced this nation ever since-a character of unconquerable determination in adversity and very deep loyalty towards those men and women who served in that war. Over 300,000 Australians served in that war, and as many as 55,000 died. They are remembered in Australia by the numerous shrines in our cities and country towns right across the nation. It is also significant to remember that next year we commemorate 75 years since Gallipoli. Notwithstanding the significant and unique place Gallipoli has in Australian history, we should forget the Australians who served in other campaigns of the Great War, in particular France, in such battles as Dernancourt, Villers Bretonneux and Hamel, and the defence of Amiens. At the third battle of Ypres, in France, over 10,000 Australians were killed and over 30,000 Australians were wounded-a number greater than was the case at Gallipoli. So great was Australia's contribution to the defence of France that to this very day our nation is remembered by the French as having saved their country. I made reference to this in my maiden speech in the old House, on 21 September 1987. I said then:

SPEECH.PARA: If Australians should ever doubt the respect in which they are held in the world today, let them remember that in the east of France, in the quiet township of Amiens, one can enter a quiet and picturesque chapel dedicated to the Australian diggers who so gallantly defended their beliefs and fought for freedom not just for themselves but for all people in all places.

It has been brought to my attention that the magnificent cathedral, in which Australia is given a very special place, is in some disrepair. There is presently a restoration program under way, though it is very slow and probably insufficient. The chapel in this cathedral dedicated to Australians is also in some disrepair. The flag that proudly stands in the chapel was presented by the Australian Government, and it too needs replacing. I ask Senator Evans, who is in the chamber, to investigate the state of the flag with a view to providing a new flag to the French Government for that chapel, and perhaps to investigate also any other appropriate contribution towards the restoration of that memorial. It is important that every visitor to that chapel, and in particular Australian visitors, feel a sense of honour; after all, that is what every shrine of remembrance in this country asks of us-lest we forget.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the levels of tar and nicotine in cigarettes fixed by legislation or by voluntary agreement.
(2) What reductions have there been since 1980 in both tar and nicotine levels.
(3) What are the planned reductions for the next 10 years, or for such period as an agreement covers.
(4) Is any consideration being given to introducing legislation for the further reduction of tar and nicotine levels in cigarettes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Maximum tar and nicotine yields are governed by a voluntary agreement between the Commonwealth and all domestic cigarette manufacturers and major importers. The agreement came into effect in August 1982 and is reviewed regularly.

(2) The 1982 agreement set the maximum tar and nicotine yields at 18 milligrams per cigarette and 1.6 milligrams per cigarette respectively. In 1987, maximum tar and nicotine yields were reduced to 16 milligrams per cigarette and 1.5 milligrams per cigarette respectively. By 1988, the maximum tar and nicotine yields had been reduced to 14 milligrams per cigarette and 1.4 milligrams per cigarette respectively-among the lowest in the world.
(3) Discussions are scheduled for 1990 with the cigarette manufacturers to consider further reductions in tar and nicotine yields.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 June 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (a) In regard to the allegations of fraud in the clothing field and barracks section of Headquarters Logistic Command, was the AFP investigation into these allegations initiated by the Minister for Defence;
(b) When did the Minister first become aware of these allegations;
(c) What immediate action did the Minister take in regard to these allegations;
(d) Does this investigation mean that the investigation into the allegations by the Management Audit Branch of the Department of Defence was inadequate or deficient;
(e) What were the circumstances which led to the AFP conducting a review of Defence Department fraud in 1988;
(f) What was the result of the review;
(g) Why has there been such a long delay in accepting the offer of AFP to provide 2 officers to look at contract tendering processes;
(h) What are the terms of reference (or equivalent) and the scope of the investigations being conducted by the officers;
(i) When will the 2 AFP officers commence work.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) No. I understand that the Public Servant who made the allegations independently approached the AFP with information, including the audit report, obtained under FOI.
(b) In June 1987 when the Public Servant wrote to the Minister with general allegations.
(c) The matter was referred to the Department and the Public Servant was interviewed in June 1987 by a senior Defence officer who then referred the matter to Management Audit for examination.

(d) No. The matter was examined as part of a wider ranging audit and, then separately, following discussion between the Public Servant and the Head of Management of Audit. The audit examination was based on normal audit practice and procedure. The result of the audit report did not indicate that fraud had occurred therefore it was not considered necessary that the matter should be referred to the Australian Federal Police. Although the Public Servant making the allegations has been asked to provide further evidence no further information has been received which would warrant the matter being referred to the AFP.

(e) I am advised the Department is unaware of any review undertaken in 1988 into potential fraud in Defence by the AFP or approach to the Department for any information or assistance which would support the conduct of such a review.
(f) Not applicable.

(g) When the Issue of AFP assistance to the Defence Department was first raised in September 1988 it was to support preparation of the defence fraud control plans. However, the AFP could not help in that regard. In June 1989 the Minister for Justice and I agreed the attachment of 2 officers to look at contract tendering processes. The AFP and the Defence Department are at present settling arrangements relating to the attachment.

(h) The two AFP officers will be attached to the Commercial Investigations and Review section of the General Investigations and Review Branch. Together with departmental investigators they will investigate alleged commercial frauds perpetrated on the department according to a program of investigations determined by the Inspector-General in consultation with the AFP.
(i) It is proposed that they commence on 1 October 1989.
